Companies last month added the most workers to payrolls since June on pickups in services and manufacturing jobs, with private payrolls climbing by 246,000, data from the ADP Research Institute in Roseland, N.J., showed Wednesday.The payroll increase was well ahead of a forecast for 168,000, and it came after a revised 151,000 gain in December. Goods-producing industries, which include manufacturers and builders, increased headcounts by 46,000, the most in two years. An increase of 4,000 service providers boosted payrolls in that sector by 201,000 following a 147,000 gain.With demand rising throughout the economy, companies are likely to continue adding workers at a steady pace, especially following a jump in business optimism on the heels of President Donald Trump's election victory. Hiring occurred across all business sizes and most industries, figures that could provide insight on the labor market ahead of Friday's release of the government's monthly payrolls report, which is projected to show a 170,000 increase in private jobs."(The year) got off to a strong start in the job market," Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics in West Chester, Pa., said in a written statement. Moody's produces the figures with ADP."Job growth is solid across most industries and company sizes," Zandi went on to say. "Even the energy sector is adding to payrolls again."Hiring in construction totaled 25,000, the most in four months. Factories added 15,000 workers, the most since December 2014. And companies employing 500 or more workers increased staffing by 83,000 jobs.Payrolls rose by 102,000 at medium-sized businesses, or those with 50 to 499 employees, while small companies' payrolls gained 62,000 workers, the most since July.

Michael Clarfeld has helped steer $5.6 billion ClearBridge Dividend Strategy Fund (SOPAX) to solid performance by pursing high-quality stocks that provide price appreciation with improving dividends.The fund he co-manages has returned an average annual 8.89% in the three years ended Jan. 31, topping 80% of the diversified income-oriented stock mutual funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. The fund's 12-month trailing dividend yield is 1.12%.His bull's-eye is dividend growth, not high dividends. He and co-managers Harry Cohen and Peter Vanderlee favor stocks that are financially healthy enough to pay dividends that rise. They avoid those with yields that are inflated either by companies desperately trying to attract investors or by falling share prices.The bonus is that the financial strength that provides a launchpad for dividend growth inoculates stocks against the risks of a rising interest rate environment, he says."Stretching for yield is risky," he warns. "Dividend growth is the place to be. That growth can offset the negatives of rising rates."Dividends can be shock-absorbers, smoothing investors' rides during market turmoil. Yet their stock holdings still offer the potential of price gains, the thinking goes.Just look at some of his fund's holdings. Among the fund's four holdings with the highest Composite Ratings from IBD, Texas Instruments (TXN) is up 43% in the past 12 months ended Jan. 31; it has an annual dividend growth rate of 15.3% in the past three years, according to dividend.com. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) is up 42%; its dividend growth rate is 10.6%. Automatic Data Processing (ADP) is up 22%; its dividend growth rate is 6.8%. UnitedHealth Group (UNH) is up 41%; its dividend growth rate is 31.2%.IBD'S TAKE: UnitedHealth is No. 1 in IBD's Medical-Medical Care industry group. To see how the company's growth metrics — like its strong 87 IBD Composite Rating and four straight years of earnings per share (EPS) growth — stack up against its rivals, visit IBD Stock Checkup.That volatility antidote of dividend-paying stocks might come in handy sooner rather than later. The market has traded sideways since mid-December as investors wait to see how the newly installed president's policies play out and whether a Republican-controlled Congress makes good on the business friendly actions investors expect from it.Stocks offering dividend growth also might fare better than bonds if the Federal Reserve makes good on its signals that it intends to raise rates multiple times this year.From his office in Manhattan, 39-year-old Clarfeld talked with IBD about whether it's wise to own a dividend-paying portfolio in a rising rate environment and his fund's overall investment approach.IBD: Do you ever give in to temptation and buy high-yield stocks?Clarfeld: If you buy only stocks with high current dividends, you miss out on some good stocks. We own American Tower (AMT), for instance, which is a wonderful business. (Its share price is up 34% since the end of 2012. Its dividend yield is 2.2%.) But it only began to pay dividends in 2012. So you have to be open-minded.We used to own Heinz (now part of KraftHeinz (KHC)). Several years ago it was much easier to find great companies with solid growth and high dividends like Heinz. But then it got taken over. We couldn't find a replacement that was as good a company with a good growth rate and a high current yield, so we ended up tilting more toward dividend growth and a little less toward high current yield as the impacts of quant easing became more pronounced over the last many years.IBD: Dividend growers are among the most stable companies. Why not buy shares in them directly and avoid a fund's expenses?Clarfeld: There are a couple of reasons. One is diversification. It would not be particularly efficient for an individual to buy 4o to 50 stocks. The broker commissions would add up.And the average person who has a job and a family does not have time to follow 50 different companies, industries, competitors and figure out which to buy, the correct time to buy, and so on.IBD: You began a stake in JPMorgan Chase (JPM) not long ago, but well before its recent Trump bump. What's your thesis?Clarfeld: We bought it early in the year when it was yielding north of 3%. (Yield now is 2.3%.) Pre-election, there was so much investor fatigue toward large banks, prices were very beaten down. And the prospect of interest rates going up, it seemed like it would never happen. And it seemed like regulatory pressures would persist forever. We just thought the valuation was too pessimistic. And JPMorgan has lots of franchises that are valuable.IBD: Texas Instruments' (TXN) earnings per share growth has accelerated for four straight quarters. What's driving it?Clarfeld: We like their emphasis on analog chips. If you think about Texas vs. Intel (INTC), which we also own, Intel makes the brains of computers. They are high performance, high dollar value. Texas focuses on the other end of the spectrum. Their chips sell for 10 to 20 cents. They are basic but high quality. And they're attractive because they are the largest player in that space.Anyone designing a new alarm clock or refrigerator or car and needs basic chips knows that Texas Instruments has them. And once those chips are designed into something, it rarely changes. So they provide a recurring revenue stream like an annuity.High performance chips require huge R&D spending. Texas Instruments' chips are much less capital intensive. So they can direct 100% of their free cash flow to shareholders.IBD: Automatic Data Processing (ADP) got a nice Trump bump. But you've owed this for years, right?Clarfeld: It's been a core holding for 10-plus years. It's a business we think can compound earnings for years. And payroll processing provides recurring revenues. Once you get a company's payroll, the business is sticky. This company benefits from job growth in the economy. It is taking share. And it provides ancillary services. They help companies deal with Affordable Care Act compliance, although a potential repeal or replacement is now a risk for them. Still, the ACA is not a core driver of this business.And recently it's benefited like a lot of financials from rising interest rates. They earn a float on payrolls they handle. Rising rates mean that float will increase.IBD: You reopened your stake in Alphabet (GOOG) after closing it. What brought you back?Clarfeld: We're a dividend portfolio. We don't go looking for nondividend-payers, but we don't want to be overly dogmatic. We wanted this exposure and there is no other way to get it.Over the past 10 years, we've owned three nondividend-payers: Apple (AAPL), Berkshire Hathaway (BERKB) and Alphabet. There is no search company like Google. There is no company like Berkshire Hathaway, which won't initiate a dividend while Warren Buffett is alive. After he's gone, who knows? And we think Alphabet will likely initiate a dividend in the future. We're not forecasting that, but we think they will.IBD: You trimmed your Waste Management (WM) stake. Why is that?Clarfeld: Actually, it's an example of a business we like. The business is stable and predictable. It's cyclical with the economy. There's been enough consolidation to make the industry rational. In fact, they've been able to drive prices higher despite a relatively weak economy. We have trimmed some just on valuation.IBD: What distinguishes Walt Disney (DIS) from other media names?Clarfeld: Their ability to create properties and then monetize them. They make movies, then turn it into a theme park attraction and then sell merchandise from it to kids. They show an ability to do that in a way few other companies can.And they own ESPN, which is dominant in sports. The biggest piece of ESPN is monthly subscription income, not advertising, and their paid subscribers are growing. So their revenue is stable and predictable. They have multiyear contracts with (cable) systems, with built-in (price) escalators.IBD: Is Home Depot (HD) a play on an expected pickup in economic growth?Clarfeld: What we like about it is not what's going to happen to the economy in 2017. We don't own a lot of retailers because they're hard to understand. And they have a fashion element, which can become unpopular suddenly. Home Depot is not like that. They're not trying to call a fashion fad. And they don't need to spiff up their stores, which are warehouses. It took a huge step down in the financial crisis. We bought it back then. Our cost basis is below 30. (Now it's trading around the high 130s.) It's a play on people spending on their homes.IBD: UnitedHealth Group (UNH) has trended higher since the election. Is this a play on the expectation of reduced health care regulation?Clarfeld: They have diversified their operations. The stock has done well because people expect reform or changes under the new administration that will be market based. Company management is very commercially oriented.RELATED:Where Vanguard's CEO McNabb Sees Fund Giant Headed In 2017Where Mutual Fund Bigwigs Expect To See Stocks Gains In 2017After 2016 Ends On Strong Note For Mutual Funds, What's Ahead For 2017

It was a strong start for the stock market Wednesday as the Wall Street cheered a strong quarter from Apple (AAPL). Early gains faded, but the Nasdaq composite and Dow Jones industrial average held modest gains in afternoon trading.The Nasdaq was up 0.4% after popping 0.8% early, the Dow added 0.2% and the S&P 500 was mostly flat. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking higher than Wednesday's levels in the stock market today, more so on the Nasdaq due to heavy volume in Apple.Breadth was negative with Nasdaq decliners having a slight edge over advancers. On the NYSE, losers topped winners by about 3 to 2.The stock market might've given back early gains, but Apple didn't as shares jumped nearly 7%. Earnings and sales topped expectations and halted three straight quarters of declining growth. Wall Street seemed enthusiastic about the fact that the company sold 1.3 million more iPhones than expected. Several Apple suppliers moved higher on the news, including Cirrus Logic (CRUS) and Qorvo (QRVO). Both report after the close today. Cirrus jumped 4%. Qorvo edged higher as it tries to clear a long consolidation with a 64.90 buy point.Heavy volume gainers included pipeline firm Oneok Partners (OKS). Shares surged 19% on news that Oneok (OKE) will buy the rest of the company for $9.3 billion. As a result of the deal, Oneok's quarterly dividend will increase 21% to 74.5 cents, giving it an annualized yield of around 5.6%.On the downside, U.S. Steel (X) reversed lower despite a big earnings beat. Shares slumped 4.5%.Steel producers have been under pressure lately, but one bright spot in the group is Posco (PKX). Shares rose more than 3% to 59.90 in heavy volume. Shares have been volatile, though, as the stock gets closer to possibly clearing a 60.23 cup-without-handle buy point.Facebook (FB) added 1% ahead of its earnings report after the close. It's still in buy range from a 129.37 cup-with-handle buy point. In economic news, ADP reported that private payrolls increased by 246,000 in January, well above the consensus estimate of 168,000. Meanwhile, the ISM Manufacturing index came in slightly ahead of expectations.The two-day Fed meeting concluded and the FOMC left interest rates unchanged. In December, the Fed forecast three rate hikes in 2017, but it still sees GDP growth in the 2% area for the next three years.RELATED:5 Takeaways From Apple's 'Outstanding' Q1 ReportPayrolls Climb 246,000 For Biggest Gain Since June, ADP SaysStock Market Today: When Did Apple Initially Break Out?

Treasuries pared losses and were slightly lower in late trading Wednesday after the Federal Open Market Committee's statement proved more dovish than some traders anticipated, helping push two-year yields down from the highest levels of 2017.Yields were higher by less than a basis point across the curve at 3:18 p.m. in New York, after rising as much as five to seven basis points in morning trading on stronger-than-expected U.S. employment and manufacturing data. Two- to five-year yields led the retreat after the FOMC statement left intact expectations for two rate increases this year, while acknowledging improvement in consumer and business sentiment over the past six weeks."There were some remote concerns that the Fed might set the table for a March hike," said William O'Donnell, U.S. rates desk strategist at Citigroup in New York. When that didn't happen, "the front end rallied back toward unchanged on the day."The two-year yield rose as much as 5.6 basis points to 1.26%, its highest since Dec. 28, after the January ADP Employment Change topped the most optimistic estimates and the ISM Manufacturing PMI rose to a two-year high.The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note added four basis points to 2.49%. It fell four basis points on Tuesday. The U.S. yield curve steepened Wednesday in the minutes after the Federal Reserve left its benchmark lending rate unchanged. The difference between two-year yields and those on 30-year bonds widened to about 186 basis points, from about 182 basis points before the announcement, as shorter-maturity Treasuries pared losses.

Stocks rallied early Wednesday, fueled by Apple (AAPL) postearnings and positive jobs data, but the major averages saw their early gains fade. Walt Disney (DIS) also boosted the Dow Jones industrial average.The Nasdaq rose 0.2% in today's stock market action, the Dow climbed 0.1% and the S&P 500 fell fractionally. Volume swelled across the board vs. the same time Tuesday.Steel, bank and telecom-related plays were among the biggest gainers; software, department stores and gold miners lagged.Apple gapped up and soared nearly 6% in massive volume to its highest level since November 2015. Shares are now extended well past a 118.12 cup-with-handle buy point cleared on Jan. 6. The company reported fiscal Q1 results late Tuesday that beat forecasts on both the top and bottom lines, thanks to better-than-expected iPhone sales. It sold 78.3 million iPhones, up 5% from last year and above views for 77 million. RBC Capital Markets raised its price target to 140 from 125, with an overweight rating.Among other Dow stock, Disney rose fractionally while Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM) were each up more than 1%. Disney marked a new 52-week high and is just barely in range from a 106.36 buy point of a cup with handle. Morgan Stanley on Monday raised its rating to overweight from equal weight and its price target to 124 from 101.Facebook (FB) climbed 0.5% in brisk trade ahead of its Q4 results due after the close. Shares remain in buy range from a 129.37 handle entry. Analysts expect the social network's earnings to jump 66% to $1.31 a share on 46% higher revenue of $8.51 billion.United Parcel Service (UPS) slid 3% in heavy turnover, extending Tuesday's 7% drop. The stock is still technically in flat-base range with an 11% correction from the left high to low, but the high-volume gap-down below its 50-day and 200-day lines is bearish action. The package delivery giant's Q4 results missed estimates Tuesday and its full-year guidance disappointed.Private-sector employers added 246,000 jobs in January, ADP reported, well above economist forecasts for 168,000 and December's 153,000. U.S. manufacturing growth accelerated to its fastest pace in more than two years, ISM said.RELATED:Apple Crushes Fiscal Q1 Estimates, Stock Jumps LateU.S. Manufacturing Accelerates As 'America First' Trump Takes OfficeFacebook, Fed, Top Chipmakers, Auto Sales Lead Investing Action Plan UPS Dives On Q4 Miss, Outlook; Amazon Plans Kentucky Air Hub

The Federal Reserve held its key interest rate steady on Wednesday, as expected, as it waits for clearer evidence that rising economic confidence will fuel an upturn in growth.The Fed, which was unanimous in its decision, noted that "business fixed investment has remained soft" although "measures of consumer and business sentiment have improved of late.""The Committee expects that economic conditions will evolve in a manner that will warrant only gradual increases in the federal funds rate," the Fed said in a statement.Treasury yields trimmed their gains and stocks wobbled up and down after the Fed signaled no rush to hike, meaning it's unlikely the next hike will come at the mid-March meeting. Apple (AAPL) pushed the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite slightly higher. Apple itself rose more than 7% following its strong holiday quarter earnings late Tuesday. The S&P 500, fractionally lower before the Fed announcement, closed slightly higher.Investors had been on guard for more hawkish signals after strong economic reports on Wednesday morning. The Institute for Supply Management Index rose 1.3 points last month to 56, the fastest pace since November 2014 and well above the 50 neutral level. Meanwhile, payroll firm ADP estimated that U.S. companies added 246,000 jobs in January, much stronger than the 168,000 that Wall Street expected.Those reports outweighed news that General Motors (GM), Ford (F) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) saw sales fall in January after a big December. GM, Ford and Fiat Chrysler shares fell slightly on the stock market today.Signs of faster growth and prospects for higher interest rates, good for banks' net interest margins, helped lift bank stocks in Wednesday trading. Bank of America (BAC) rose 1.1%, while U.S. Bancorp (USB) advanced 0.7% to an all-time high.IBD'S TAKE: President Trump's agenda faces a large degree of uncertainty. If the WTO found the border tax backed by House Republicans — and increasingly by the White House — to be illegal, the GOP would face three difficult choices that could throw the ruling party into crisis.Fed policymakers caught markets off-guard in December when a number of them built President Trump's planned fiscal stimulus into their hawkish forecast for three rate hikes in 2017. Fed Chair Janet Yellen has said that it's not clear the economy needs stimulus to reach full employment.But after a tumultuous first week and a half of his presidency, Fed policymakers are likely done trying to predict what Trump will do and how his policies will affect the economy. Now the Fed, like investors, is in wait-and-see mode to watch what can get through Congress, when it will affect the real economy, and whether Trump's immigration and trade policies curb or offset the force of his pro-growth moves.For now, markets still expect just two rate hikes in 2017, coming in June and December. After the Fed's announcement, markets were pricing in just 17.7% odds that the next hike will come on March 15.RELATED:U.S. Manufacturing Gears Up As 'America First' Trump Takes Office Ford, GM, Fiat Chrysler U.S. Sales Decline In January

U.S. manufacturing growth accelerated to a fresh two-year high in January while private-sector hiring was robust as Donald Trump entered the White House, pledging an "America First" policy of promoting U.S. jobs, especially in manufacturing. But General Motors (GM) and Ford Motor (F) reported a slight decline in domestic auto sales.The Institute for Supply Management Index rose 1.3 points last month to 56, the fastest pace since November 2014. Economists had expected a reading of 55. Readings over 50 signal growth.Separately, U.S. companies added 246,000 jobs in January, much stronger than the 168,000 that Wall Street expected and up from 151,000 in December.The ADP jobs data has an uneven track record of forecasting the Labor Department's employment report, with the January nonfarm payrolls due on Friday.Manufacturers added 15,000 jobs as the goods-producing sector overall boosted payrolls by 46,000.Trump's plans for tax cuts and deregulation helped push the Dow Jones Industrial Average and other major averages to record highs, but manufacturerMeanwhile, Ford's January U.S. sales fell 0.6% vs. a year earlier, though that was slightly better than expected.But General Motors' January U.S. sales fell 3.9% vs. a year earlier, defying forecasts for a 1.2% gain. General Motors raised its 2017 guidance last month after reporting a robust 10% U.S. sales gain for December. That bullish news helped send GM shares to a 22-month high recently.Ford shares dipped 0.3% toclose at 12.32 on the stock market today. GM stock fell 1.3% to finish at 36.14, trying to find support at its 50-day moving average.President Trump has criticized GM, Ford and other automakers for Mexico factories and exports, urging them to set up more facilities in the U.S. But with U.S. demand plateauing at record levels, Ford says no more domestic plants are needed.One U.S. automaker that is rapidly expanding is Tesla (TSLA), which announced Wednesday it is changing its name to Tesla Inc. from Tesla Motors. Tesla has plans to ramp up from delivering 76,320 vehicles last year to making 500,000 in 2018. It's expanding its Fremont, Calif.-based plant and continuing to expand its just-operational battery Gigafactory outside Reno, Nevada. Tesla shares have formed a cup-with-handle base that goes back nearly nine months, with a buy point of 258.57. Tesla shares fell 1.1% to 249.24 at the close.Meanwhile, aerospace giant Boeing (BA) reported stronger-than-expected profit last week, with the 787 Dreamliner finally cash flow positive. Despite somewhat cautious guidance, Boeing stock, part of the Dow industrials broke out of a base to hit all-time highs. Boeing advanced 0.3% to close at 163.97.On the flip side, fellow Dow stock General Electric (GE) has fallen in 2017, especially after GE reported mixed Q4 profit results. GE gave back a penny to 29.69 Wednesday after falling Tuesday to its worst levels in nearly three months.RELATED:Ford, GM, Fiat Chrysler U.S. Sales Decline In January

Shares are now extended well past a 118.12 cup-with-handle buy point cleared on Jan. 6. The company reported fiscal Q1 results late Tuesday that beat forecasts on both the top and bottom lines, thanks to better-than-expected iPhone sales. It sold 78.3 million iPhones, up 5% from last year and above views for 77 million. RBC Capital Markets raised its price target to 140 from 125, with an overweight rating.Among other blue chips, American Express (AXP), Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM) each held gains of around 1%.Facebook (FB) pared a 1.5% gain to 0.4% ahead of its Q4 results after the close. Shares remain in buy range from a 129.37 handle entry. Analysts expect the social network's earnings to jump 66% to $1.31 a share with revenue up 46% to $8.51 billion.United Parcel Service (UPS) sank 4% in heavy turnover, extending Tuesday's 7% drop. The stock is still technically in flat-base range with a 13% correction from the left high to low, but the high-volume gap down below its 50-day and 200-day lines is bearish action. EPS missed views by a penny, but revenue beat. Shares of the transportation equipment maker are more than 35% extended from a 14.82 buy point cleared in December.Nvidia (NVDA), up 3%, was also a big IBD 50 winner. The correction from the left side high to the bottom is 17%, which puts the stock out of flat-base range. A cup base needs a minimum of seven weeks. Meanwhile, U.S. manufacturing growth accelerated to its fastest pace in more than two years, ISM said.RELATED:Apple Crushes Fiscal Q1 Estimates, Stock Jumps LateU.S. Manufacturing Accelerates As 'America First' Trump Takes OfficeFacebook, Fed, Top Chipmakers, Auto Sales Lead Investing Action PlanUPS Dives On Q4 Miss, Outlook; Amazon Plans Kentucky Air Hub

The Apple (AAPL) effect boosted the stock market Wednesday, aided by data showing a hiring spike among U.S. employers in January.The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, the Dow Jones industrial average 0.5% and the S&P 500 0.4%. Small caps also kicked into gear, sending the Russell 2000 up 0.7%.A busy session on multiple fronts includes the Federal Open Market Committee's policy announcement, set for 2 p.m., and January sales reports from automakers. Those come ahead of Facebook's (FB) quarterly results, due after the close.But Apple was the early center of attention on the stock market today.Apple's fiscal first-quarter report delivered after Tuesday's close sent shares up nearly 5% at the open Wednesday. Apple shares are now extended from a 118.12 cup-with-handle buy point.Chip developer Marvell Technology (MRVL) rose 3.5% at the open as UBS raised the stock to buy from hold. Shares climbed back above the 15.09 buy point of a flat base.U.S. Steel (X) forged a 3% advance after a healthy fourth-quarter earnings beat and guidance for 2017 revenue that was above analyst targets. Shares have been below the 50-day moving average for about a week.Fourth-quarter revenue and earnings that beat estimates sent Marathon Petroleum (MPC) 2% higher at the open. Shares are finding support at their 10-week moving average.Natural gas pipeline operator Oneok (OKE) rumbled up 6% after announcing it would acquire the remaining shares of its master limited partnership, Oneok Partners (OKS), in a deal valued around $9.3 billion. Oneok currently owns about 40% of the partnership. Management also released 2017 earnings guidance well above analysts' consensus targets. Oneok Partners shares spiked 31%.Tupperware (TUP) fell 5%, as strong full-year guidance weighed against mixed fourth-quarter results. The stock fell back below its 50-day moving average as it scales up the right side of a five-month basing pattern.On the IBD 50 list, Broadcom (AVGO) rose 2%. The Singapore-based chipmaker's shares  are  extended from a 178.12 alternative buy point from a flat base.Private-sector employers added 246,000 workers in January, the ADP National Employment Report said. The number beat December's tally of 153,000 new hires by more than 60%, and it was 46% higher than economist expectations for 168,000 new jobs. Service-sector employers made the big number of hires, adding more than 200,000 workers. Manufacturing employers expanded payrolls by 46,000 jobs.Researcher Markit reports its January manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index at 9:45 a.m. ET. The Institute for Supply Management releases its January manufacturing index at 10 a.m., and the Commerce Department provides construction spending numbers for December.The Energy Information Administration delivers its weekly oil inventories report at 10:30 a.m., and the Federal Open Market Committee wraps its two-day meeting with a policy announcement at 2 p.m. No press conference is scheduled following the announcement.Europe's markets rallied, with the CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt' DAX trading more than 1% higher. The FTSE 100 in London traded up 0.6% in its afternoon session.In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 notched a 0.5% gain, ending a two-day decline. Hong Kong's market reopened after a four-day holiday with the Hang Seng down 0.2%. The Shanghai exchange remains closed through Thursday.In India, the Bombay Stock Exchange's Sensex Index rocked a 1.8% gain Wednesday, in response to the release of the country's proposed 2017 budget by its finance minister.RELATED:Apple Crushes Fiscal Q1 Estimates, Stock JumpsFacebook, Fed, Chipmakers, Auto Sales Lead Investing Action Plan

Broad adoption of Clovis Oncology's (CLVS) PARP inhibitor, Rubraca, could depend on trials of rival drugs from AstraZeneca (AZN) and Tesaro (TSRO), Janney analyst Debjit Chattopadhyay said Monday.In the stock market today, Clovis stock fell 1.1% to 61.83. Shares, though, have run up nearly 40% this year vs. a 5.3% climb for the SPDR S&P Biotech (XBI) exchange-traded fund. IBD's Biomed/Biotech industry group is up less than 1% in 2017.Chattopadhyay credited Takeda Pharmaceuticals' plan to acquire Ariad Pharmaceuticals (ARIA) for $5.2 billion and Merrimack Pharmaceuticals' (MACK) $575 million divestiture of an oncology asset to Ipsen for driving up the valuation of oncology biotechs and for Clovis' stock run-up.IBD'S TAKE: Tesaro and four IPOs led the biotech sphere in terms of gains in 2016. See how those five stocks and the broader industry group performed on IBD's Industry Themes.Clovis shares have traded well above their 50-day moving average since early November. Chattopadhyay classified the rise as "too far, too fast." Clovis could wait some time before getting a takeover bid with its premium wrapped in an at-risk asset, he said."Despite the premium being placed on commercial-stage oncology assets and the potential synergies of PARPi with checkpoint inhibitors, a near-term Clovis buyout may not materialize until key competitive readouts settle the debate on the equivalency/superiority of the various PARPi," he said.Poly ADP ribose polymerase (PARP) are enzymes used to repair damaged DNA. Companies including Clovis, AstraZeneca and Tesaro are testing whether inhibiting those enzymes could help treat ovarian and other cancers. AstraZeneca and Clovis both have approved drugs.Clovis' drug was approved in December for ovarian cancer patients whose tumors have a deleterious BRCA mutation and have not responded to chemo. A day later, Tesaro's New Drug Application for an ovarian cancer drug won priority review from the Food and Drug Administration.Readouts from AstraZeneca's SOLO-2 trial and Tesaro's PRIMA are likely to affect Rubraca's adoption and Clovis stock, Chattopadhyay wrote in a research report. An earlier phase three trial from Tesaro, called NOVA, showed PARP inhibitor niraparib significantly improved progression-free survival in ovarian cancer."If SOLO-2 is not in the same ballpark as NOVA, questions on interchangeability of PARPs could impact Clovis shares heading into ARIEL-3 readout," he wrote. ARIEL-3 is a Clovis trial looking at Rubraca as a maintenance treatment in patients with ovarian fallopian tube or primary peritoneal cancer.Chattopadhyay suggested trials from AstraZeneca and Tesaro could change the role of PARP inhibitors to front-line treatments from second-line, thus reducing the pool of Rubraca patients. He kept his neutral rating on Clovis stock."Based on the near-term uncertainties, we would wait for a better entry point," he said.RELATED:Tesaro Ovarian Cancer Drug Gets Priority Review After FDA OKs Clovis MedBiotech Stocks Might Catalyze, Or Plunge, On 4 Key Sectors In 2017Tesaro Stock Rebounds Despite FDA Hold-Up On Anti-Nausea Med

Filings for U.S. unemployment benefits declined to their lowest level in eight weeks, but other data showed companies added fewer jobs than forecast in December.Showing volatility typical around the holiday period, jobless claims dropped by 28,000 to 235,000 in the week ended Dec. 31, a Labor Department report showed Thursday in Washington. The median projection of economists surveyed by Bloomberg called for 260,000.Meanwhile, data from the ADP Research Institute in Roseland, N.J., showed Thursday that private payrolls climbed by 153,000, below forecasts of 175,000. That came after a revised 215,000 gain in November. Goods-producing industries, which include manufacturers and builders, reduced head counts by 16,000, while service providers boosted payrolls by 169,000."Job growth remains strong but is slowing," Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics Inc. in West Chester, Pa., said in a prepared statement. Moody's produces the figures with ADP. "Smaller companies are struggling to maintain payrolls while large companies are expanding at a healthy pace."ADP found that businesses continue to add workers to meet sales, helping to sustain the progress that has put the job market at or near the Federal Reserve's maximum-employment objective.The slower pace of hiring underscores the challenge for companies in finding skilled workers as the labor market tightens, one reason wage growth may accelerate.The data provide more clues on the employment situation ahead of the Friday release of the Labor Department's monthly payrolls report, which is expected to show the economy added positions in December to cap another solid year of gains.Hiring in construction fell by 2,000 while factories subtracted 9,000 workers. Companies employing 500 or more workers increased staffing by 63,000 jobs. Payrolls rose by 71,000 at medium-sized businesses, or those with 50 to 499 employees, while small companies expanded payrolls by 18,000.The Labor Department figures, meantime, usually show swings around the year-end holidays. Firms generally have avoided firings as the job market tightens and the supply of available workers shrinks.Filings have remained below 300,000 for 96 consecutive weeks, the longest streak since 1970 and a threshold economists say is indicative of a healthy labor market. An average 263,000 Americans filed for benefits each week in 2016, down from 278,000 in 2015.The number of people continuing to receive jobless benefits rose by 16,000 to 2.11 million in the week ended Dec. 24, the highest since early September. The unemployment rate among people eligible for benefits held at 1.5%. These data are reported with a one-week lag.Estimates in the Bloomberg survey for initial claims ranged from 250,000 to 275,000. The Labor Department revised the prior week's reading to 263,000 from an initially reported 265,000. Last week's figure was close to the four-decade low of 233,000 from the week ending Nov. 12.Six states including Virginia and Wisconsin had estimated claims last week, as did Puerto Rico. There was nothing unusual in the overall data, according to the Labor Department. The four-week average of claims, a less-volatile measure than the weekly figure, decreased to 256,750 from 262,500 in the prior week.

Treasuries rallied across the curve, driving down benchmark yields by the most since the days after the June Brexit vote, as traders across financial markets backed away from crowded bets.The benchmark 10-year U.S. yield plunged nine basis points to 2.35% at 4:14 p.m. in New York, touching the lowest level since Dec. 8, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader data. It's set for the biggest decline since June 27. The 10-year break-even rate, a market measure of inflation expectations, fell from close to the highest level since 2014.Across financial markets, trends snapped Thursday as investors weighed the risk of a lackluster payrolls report Friday and the prospect that trades based on Donald Trump's impending presidency had gone too far. Data from the ADP Research Institute on Thursday indicated that companies added fewer jobs in December than forecast. The figures come a day before the Labor Department releases its monthly payrolls report."A bunch of the widely predicted trades for this year are all being broken at the same time, with oil going lower, investment-grade corporates widening out, TIPS break-evens tightening, and then rates rallying as a result," said Mike Lorizio, a Boston-based senior trader at Manulife Asset Management, which oversees about $343 billion. "Some key levels being broken just inspired further buying."In other markets, the dollar tumbled, while the S&P 500 retreated for the first time in 2017. The move in Treasuries was exacerbated by extended short positioning in futures, traders said, and marked by heavy futures volumes.

Bank stocks retreated, dragging down the Dow industrials, as Treasury yields fell Thursday on ADP's employment gauge.The 10-year Treasury yield, which helps determine the rate on mortgages and other debts, was down nine basis points to 2.35%, after hitting a recent peak above 2.6% in mid-December. The two-year yield, which influences credit-card debt and other key loans, rose five basis points to 1.17%. A flatter yield curve is not good news for bank profitability.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) shares closed 0.9% lower on the stock market today, while Bank of America (BAC) dropped 1.2% and Citigroup (C) 1.7%. Wells Fargo (WFC) retreated 1.55%. Goldman Sachs (GS) pulled back 0.7%, and fellow investment bank Morgan Stanley (MS) lost 0.9%.JPMorgan and Goldman are part of the Dow Jones industrial average and are a key reason why the blue-chip index is lagging Thursday.ADP said the private sector added 153,000 jobs in December, below expectations, according to MarketWatch, and lower than the 215,000 added in November. The government's December jobs report is set for release on Friday.Bank stock charts generally look healthy, with share prices leveling off in recent weeks following a long run-up after the election of Donald Trump. Wall Street has been betting that a combination of tax cuts, regulatory cutbacks, an infrastructure overhaul and higher inflation under Trump and a Republican-controlled Congress will benefit banks in the years to come.The economic growth and infrastructure investment have led to anticipation of higher inflation, which has pushed longer-term yields up as investors try to make up for the dollar's declining buying power over time. When the Fed raises rates, a prospect more likely under higher inflation, banks can more easily raise their own, helping to pad their finances.The Federal Reserve has already offered more bullish signals on rate hikes for this year. According to minutes from the Fed's December meeting, policymakers "indicated that the upside risks to their forecasts for economic growth had increased as a result of prospects for more expansionary fiscal policies in coming years."IBD'S TAKE: The Fed can raise its own benchmark interest rate in an attempt to curb inflation and economic overexpansion and make borrowing more expensive. With investors banking on Trump's fiscal policy jolting the economy, Fed policymakers may get more aggressive on raising rates. JPMorgan, Bank of America and Wells Fargo report quarterly earnings next week.RELATED:More Than Bitcoin: Blockchain's Links Reach JPMorgan, IBM, Wal-MartAs The Dow Nears 20K, These 5 Stocks Have Led The WayU.S. Banking Giants Gain As Deutsche Bank, European Financials Teeter

Major stock indexes were in the red again near midday Wednesday, but losses were tame, as investors awaited the conclusion of the Fed meeting and policy statement at 2 p.m. ET.The S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite gave up 0.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.2%. Small caps underperformed again, with the Russell 2000 down around 0.7%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking higher than Tuesday's levels — more so on the Nasdaq.Health care and mining stocks outperformed. Oil and gas names lagged again amid another sharp drop in oil prices.December West Texas intermediate crude oil futures were down around 3% to 45.12 a barrel after an industry group reported a huge stockpile build ahead of official data. The 10-year Treasury yield slipped 2 basis points to 1.80%.In the stock market today, investors liked the look of Alibaba's (BABA) earnings report early in the session, but shares reversed sharply, falling 2%.Meanwhile, shares of Broadcom (AVGO) rallied 1% on news it's acquiring Brocade Communications (BRCD) for $5.9 billion, including debt. Shares of Brocade jumped 10% to 12.36.The Stocks On The Move screen on the home page of Investors.com highlighted several earnings winners rising in heavy volume, including Wingstop (WING), Papa John's (PZZA), Electronic Arts (EA) and Inphi (IPHI). Activision (ATVI), a group peer of Electronic Arts, reports Thursday after the close.On the downside, Paycom Software (PAYC) crashed 16%. An earnings and sales beat late Tuesday wasn't good enough as Wall Street focused on quarterly sales guidance of $85 to $87 million, pretty much at the midpoint of the consensus estimate of $85.94 million.In economic news, the private sector added 147,000 jobs in October, according to the latest data from ADP. Economists expected growth of 170,000. The data come ahead of Friday's nonfarm payroll report for October, which is expected to show job growth of 178,000.The two-day Fed meeting concludes today, with the policy statement due at 2 p.m. ET. Wall Street isn't expecting much from the meeting so close to the election, but Chairwoman Janet Yellen could take the opportunity to prepare the market for a rate hike before the end of the year. The market is already expecting one. According to the CME Group FedWatch took, the chances of a rate hike are near 70%.RELATED:Alibaba Earnings, Revenue Growth Beat On E-Commerce, Cloud BusinessBroadcom To Buy Brocade For $5.9 Billion, Reaffirms Q4 GuidanceOil Extends Slide As Industry Group Sees Massive Stockpile Gain

U.S. stocks opened lower Wednesday as the major indexes flirted with their seventh consecutive daily decline.The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 were down 0.4%, while Dow Jones industrial average inched down 0.2%. Volume in the stock market today was slightly lower on the NYSE so far and accelerated on the Nasdaq.Online retail marketplace Alibaba (BABA) jumped as high as 104.10, moving back above the 50-day moving average. But shares have reversed lower, trading down 0.8% to 100.30.The stock rose sharply enough to retake its key 50-day moving average, keeping a rally from an early August breakout past an 85.10 cup with handle buy point intact.However, the market has been under intense selling pressure; on Tuesday, both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 got hit with an 8th distribution day in recent weeks, as noted by Tuesday's Big Picture column.The China-based company reported fiscal Q2 quarterly results that topped the Street's views on the top and bottom lines. Earnings grew 39% and were roughly 15% above the consensus estimate. Revenue beat by 1%.Alibaba's cloud-computing revenue more than doubled sales and almost broke even, Bloomberg News reported. The stock holds a top-notch 99 Composite Rating from IBD Stock Checkup. The EPS Rating has been improving and is currently at 89, but following the latest results it's likely to go up.Stocks reporting after the close include Facebook (FB) and Qualcomm (QCOM).Economic data before the opening bell was mixed. Bears could point to the ADP National Employment Report that showed 147,000 jobs were added in the private sector in October, 13% less than the consensus target of 170,000. But bulls could point to an upward revision in September data. The September total was revised to 202,000 from 154,000, an upward adjustment of 31%.Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve is expected to wrap up its meeting at 2 p.m. ET. The Street expects the Fed to stand pat on interest rates. CME Group's FedWatch Tool puts the odds of a rate hike today at 7%. The question is whether the Fed will raise rates in December. That's still likely, but the odds have fallen in recent days.RELATED:Time Warner Lifts Views After Q3 BeatNext President May Toss Money Northrop's WayCloud Revenue Helps Alibaba Fiscal Q2 Results Soar

Paychex (PAYX) on Wednesday reported fiscal first-quarter results that beat Wall Street estimates, but the company trimmed its full-year profit and payroll-service outlook.The payroll-services provider expects net income to rise around 7% during fiscal 2017, down from an earlier forecast for roughly 8% growth. The new forecast reflects "the impact of the discrete tax items recognized in the respective first quarter of fiscal years 2017 and 2016."The company said full-year payroll-service revenue would rise 3%-4%. In June, the company said it expected payroll service revenue to rise "approximately 4%."Shares gapped down 4.6% to close at 57.50 in the stock market today, piercing a flat base with a 61.97 buy point and breaching support at its 50-day line. The stock had been inching closer to that buy point in recent days.Still, the company held to its earlier forecasts for total service revenue and interest on funds held for clients.Shares of rival Automatic Data Processing (ADP) closed down 1.7%.IBD'S TAKE: Paychex fell through a flat base and a key support metric on Wednesday, but the stock still maintains a good IBD Composite Rating of 88. Here are four other highly-rated stocks in flat bases. For the first quarter, Paychex's total revenue rose 9% to $785.5 million, topping views for $782.8 million. Earnings per share rose 3% to 60 cents, beating expectations for 57 cents.RELATED:HR Software Firm Paylocity Reverses Despite Solid Beat, GuidanceTo Outsource Or Not To Outsource? New Options Offer Better Choices

On a strong day for the Nasdaq Tuesday, Paycom Software (PAYC) showed tepid price action, but don't let that be a deterrent because it's trading tightly near highs as it works on a flat base. Paycom, a member of Tuesday's Sector Leaders screen, has more than tripled from its April 2014 IPO at 15. It's a member of IBD's strong-performing…

Service-sector activity picked up strongly in September, according to ISM's nonmanufacturing index. But a separate report from ADP showed companies are slowing the pace of hiring.The Institute for Supply Management's service-sector gauge shot up 5.7 points to 57.1, an 11-month high. That's a huge jump from August's 51.4, which was the weakest since February 2010. Economists had expected a smaller rise to 52.9. Readings over 50 signal growth. New orders led the way in the ISM services report.On Monday, ISM's manufacturing index rose 2.1 points in September to 51.5, back into positive territory and slightly above analyst estimates. New orders also were strong.Earlier, ADP estimated that private payrolls rose by 154,000, below views for 170,000 and the smallest gain in five months. That follows a revised 175,000 gain in August. Manufacturers shed 6,000 positions but construction firms hired 11,000 workers. Service firms added 151,000 jobs.Economists expect the Labor Department's employment data Friday to show a gain of 168,000 nonfarm jobs, with the jobless rate holding at 4.9%.Also, factory orders for August fell 0.2%, the Commerce Department said, in line with views. Core capital goods orders, a proxy for business investment plans, rose 0.9%.

U.S. stocks advanced confidently Wednesday as several economic reports topped expectations and crude oil prices surged.The Nasdaq padded its cushion above the 50-day line as the index rose 0.5%. The S&P 500 remained below its 50-day line while rising 0.4%. The blue chip Dow Jones industrial average popped 0.6%. Volume in the stock market today ran slightly higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the NYSE.Oil stocks were among the day's best performers. Five of the day's top 10 gainers among industry groups were from the oil patch. Big gainers in the sector included contract driller Transocean (RIG), up 6%; drilling services provider Halliburton (HAL), up 3%; wellbore products provider Baker Hughes (BHI), up 3%; and oil and gas explorer Resolute Energy (REN), up 17%.The Energy Information Administration reported that crude oil stockpiles fell for a fifth consecutive week, catching the Street by surprise. West Texas intermediate crude oil rose 2% to just under $50 a barrel.In the IBD 50, a list of the best stocks by fundamentals and technicals, winners and losers were about evenly matched. The day's biggest gainer was Acacia Communications (ACIA), up 10%. Acacia raised earnings guidance for the second time in less than two weeks. The worst performer was Gigamon (GIMO), down 6%. Two investment banks downgraded Gigamon.Three economic reports helped set the market's upbeat tone. Factory orders for August, the Institute for Supply Management's nonmanufacturing gauge for September, and U.S. Services PMI for September each topped the Street's consensus number.A fourth report disappointed. The ADP employment report fell short of the Street's estimate. However, the private ADP report doesn't always match the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics' report. The government data will be released Friday before the opening bell.RELATED:Big Banks Breaking OutAmazon Stock Hits High As Prime Users Ramp Up

The stock market extended gains Wednesday as Wall Street took in more economic data, another round of earnings reports and a big jump in oil prices.The Nasdaq composite and Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.7% while the S&P 500 advanced 0.5%.In economic news, private employers added 154,000 jobs in September, below expectations of 170,000, according to the latest data from ADP. The data come ahead of Friday's jobs reported where economist expect nonfarm payrolls to rise 168,000. But ISM's nonmanufacturing index surged to an 11-month high in September.WTI crude oil futures for November delivery rose nearly 2% to $49.69 a barrel. The Energy Information Administration reported that U.S. inventories fell for a fifth straight week.In the stock market today, Acacia Communications (ACIA) soared 11.5% to 113.77 after finding support at its 50-day moving average Tuesday. The fiber-optic networking technology firm was showcased in Leaderboard in mid-June and re-entered the Leaders list of premium-quality growth stocks on Tuesday.Global Payments (GPN) added just over 1% to 77.66 after reporting strong earnings before the open. It's near the top of a flat base with an 80.03 buy point. Demand for shares had been sluggish in recent weeks as evidenced by an up/down volume ratio of 1.8 and Accumulation/Distribution Rating of D-.IBD'S TAKE: Global Payments' industry group ranks in the bottom half of IBD's 197 industry group rankings, but a couple of other names in the group continue to act well. See who they are with IBD Stock Checkup.Meanwhile, strong earnings from Constellation Brands (STZ) fueled a breakout for the stock. Shares rose 2.5% to 170.02. The stock cleared a flat-base entry of 168.78.A couple of other earnings reports made early headlines. Micron Technology (MU) rose 1.5% after initial selling off. A quarterly loss of 5 cents a share handily beat expectations but sales fell 11% to just over $3.2 billion. Headed into this week, Micron showed 13 straight weekly price gains.LED lighting expert Acuity Brands (AYI) slumped 4% -- but rebounded from an intraday tumble below its long-term 200-day moving average -- despite reporting its third straight quarter of 20%+ earnings and sales growth.Inside the IBD 50, Broadcom (AVGO) got a lift after Bernstein initiated coverage with an outperform rating and price target of 215. Shares rose nearly 3% to 174. The semiconductor giant is working on a flat base with a 179.52 buy point.RELATED:Acacia Hikes Q3 Earnings Guidance Again After Stock Passes Key TestConstellation Brands, Global Payments Up On EarningsNetflix, Broadcom Started With Top Ratings; Micron Gets PT Boost

General Motors (GM), Toyota Motor (TM), Ford Motor (F) and a number of car dealer and parts maker stocks are powering higher Wednesday, even as the auto industry is seen reaching a plateau near record highs.Other trends would seem to act as headwinds on the auto sector as well, such as higher oil prices weighing on truck and SUV sales and expectations for an interest rate hike denting the easy financing that buyers have enjoyed. September sales tallies from individual automakers also fell short.But Autodata's industrywide sales figure of a 17.76 million annual rate last month topped forecasts. And while U.S. sales are unlikely to exceed 2015's robust 17.5 million pace, they won't dive and may even hold steady. GM's head of North America operations told Bloomberg on Monday that he sees the industry plateauing, albeit near or at record highs, echoing similar comments from Toyota.The hefty incentives offered to car buyers could be a sign of flagging demand, but workers are also seeing bigger wage gains. Affordable gas prices and a "favorable economic environment" are pushing up transaction prices, even with higher automaker incentive spending, said TrueCar's (TRUE) chief industry analyst, Eric Lyman, in a Monday statement.More recently, the Institute for Supply Management's September manufacturing index on Monday signaled a return growth, despite stalling auto production, and the ADP National Employment Report on Wednesday showed private sector job gains, reflecting a strong labor market.GM shares were up 1.6% to close at 32.68 and Toyota gained 1.5% to 117.07 on the stock market today. Ford rallied 2.3% to 12.48, retaking its 50-day line. Fiat Chrysler Automobile (FCAU) climbed 2.7% to 6.58 but is still hitting resistance at the key 50-day moving average.IBD'S TAKE: Ford and other automakers don't have strong fundamentals. But graphics chipmaker Nvidia is making a wave in the auto space, debuting a new artificial-intelligence supercomputer chip for self-driving cars.Dealership stocks and the auto parts sectors are both rallying as well Wednesday.Group I Automotive (GPI) and vehicle auction services provider Kar Auction (KAR) were in buy territory Wednesday as both stocks climbed out of cup-with-handle bases. Group I was up 3.2% to 65.45 while Kar added 1% to 43.88Dealer Penske Automotive Group (PAG) is on the verge of breaking out as it looks to clear a 50.17 entry from a more-than-yearlong cup-with-handle base, rising over 3% intraday Wednesday. And AutoNation (AN) decisively popped above its 200-day moving average as it forms a flat base with 54.25 buy point.Meanwhile, parts maker Gentex (GNTX), Amer Axel & Manufacturing (AXL) and Superior Industries (SUP) climbed above the 50-day as they build flat bases. Gentex was up 2.7% to 17.89, Amer jumped 3.3% to 17.65 and Superior tacked on 1% to 29.42.Cooper-Standard (CPS) is also finding support at its 50-day as it closed up for the fourth straight session, rising 1% to 103.19. Allison Transmission (ALSN), which is also working on a flat base, added 1.2% to 28.66. Tenneco (TEN) shot up 2.8% 59.25 to re-enter buy range.All six are part of IBD's Auto-Truck Original Equipment industry group, which is collectively hitting a 10-month high.RELATED:U.S. Auto Sales Sluggish, But Top Views On Strong Truck DemandISM Manufacturing Index Signals Return To Growth As New Orders Jump

Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) have broken out this week on growing Federal Reserve rate-hike speculation and relief over Deutsche Bank (DB).After AFP reported that Deutsche Bank could settle a mortgage-securities case for far less than the Justice Department asked for, potentially warding off a bigger shock to the global banking industry, Bank of America and Citigroup on Friday bounced off their 50-day lines. Meanwhile, Fed officials' comments and recent economic data have reinforced expectations for central bank tightening by the end of the year.Banks and bank stocks should do well if the Fed raises rates because it allow them to increase the spread between its lending rates and borrowing costs. Banks' net interest margins have been squeezed in recent years.JPMorgan Chase (JPM), meanwhile, also rebounded off its 50-day. JPMorgan broke out in early August from a handle in a consolidation and remains within range of the 66.58 buy point. JPMorgan rose 1.6% to 67.69 Wednesday.Citigroup climbed 1.9% to 48.65 in the stock market today, hitting its best levels since early January. Citigroup cleared a 48.28 buy point in an 11-month consolidation.Bank of America advanced 2.% to 16.11. BofA is 4.9% above its 50-day line, still within the chase zone. Ideally, for a stock to be within buy range, it should be no more than 5% above the 50-day line.Wells Fargo rose 2.8%, but from a two-and-a-half-year low. Wells Fargo is still reeling from the cross-selling scandal.IBD'S TAKE: The Banks-Money Center industry group, which includes the big banks, moves in tandem with the Federal Reserve's announcements on interest rates. To learn more about top industry groups and taking profits quickly rapid changes in the market, see this story about Swing Trading strategies. Meanwhile, some super-regional banks also have broken out. SunTrust Banks (STI) broke past a 44.71 buy point of a consolidation pattern begun in late May on Tuesday. On Wednesday, SunTrust rose 2.2% to 45.73, still in range. SunTrust had found resistance several times just above 44 in recent months.Meanwhile, Comerica (CMA) rose 2.8% to 49.21 Wednesday, extended from buy range but still performing solidly.Wednesday's bank stock gains come as ADP reported that companies added 154,000 jobs in September, short of estimates for 170,000 but still solid. Meanwhile, the ISM nonmanufacturing index shot up to an 11-month high last month. On Monday, ISM's manufacturing index signaled a return to factory expansion.RELATED:New High Analysis: Session Yields Slew Of Financial BreakoutsU.S. Banking Giants Gain As Deutsche Bank, European Financials TeeterBank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain EmbraceJPMorgan, Goldman, Citi Waver As Rates To Stay Lower For Longer

Stocks opened higher Wednesday as oil prices climbed and investors braced for a heavy slate of economic news.The Dow industrials rose 0.5% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq climbed 0.4%.Overseas markets were mixed, with Europe's leading benchmarks down about a half percent in afternoon trade. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ended its session with a 0.5% gain. In China, the Hong Kong Hang Seng Index rose 0.4%.Leaderboard stock Acacia Communications (ACIA) spiked 8.5% at the starting bell. The maker of fiber-optic networking gear hiked its third-quarter earnings outlook for a second time in the past several days. The stock ended Tuesday in a buy zone as it rebounded from support at its 10-week moving average.Global Payments (GPN) rose 1% in early action. The payment processor reported its fiscal first-quarter sales and earnings narrowly topped analyst consensus views. Management raised its full-year EPS and revenue guidance in line with expectations.Constellation Brands (STZ) rose 3% after beating second-quarter forecasts. It announced Tuesday it would acquire craft whiskey distillery High West for $160 million. Constellation has been shaping a flat base with a 168.78 buy point since August.Micron Technology (MU) fell 2%. The Idaho-based chipmaker reported late Tuesday that revenue fell and its bottom line swung to a loss, as expected by analysts, in its fiscal fourth quarter. First-quarter guidance appeared to be above analyst expectations, but was complicated by changes to the company's accounting method.  Micron shares have advanced for 13 straight weeks, putting them 90% above a May low at the end of Tuesday's session.Twitter (TWTR) climbed 3% on speculation that the company moved closer to a buyout. Analysts have named Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), Facebook (FB) and Salesforce.com (CRM) as possible suitors. Salesforce.com dropped 7% at the open.Acuity Brands (AYI) crumbled 8% after reporting fiscal fourth-quarter results well short of analyst expectations.Employers added 154,00 workers in September, according to ADP's National Employment Report, far below the 170,000 new hires expected by economists.The Commerce Department reported the trade balance widened slightly, to $40.7 billion, in August, vs. July's $39.5 billion gap.Researcher Markit reports its September services Purchasing Managers Index at 9:45 a.m. and, at 10 a.m., the Institute for Supply Management reports its non-manufacturing index and the Commerce Department delivers August factory orders.Oil prices will also be in focus in the stock market today ahead of the Energy Information Administration's weekly inventories report at 10:30 a.m. ET. Oil traded up nearly 2% early Wednesday, following weekly data from the American Petroleum Institute showing U.S. oil inventories declined by 7.6 million barrels in the week ended Sept. 30, a fifth straight weekly decline. Futures for the West Texas Intermediate benchmark traded above $49 per barrel. Europe's Brent benchmark traded near $52.Comments from Federal Reserve officials will also be on investors radar. Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari speaks at 9:30 a.m. ET. Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker speaks at 1 p.m. ET.RELATED:Constellations Brands, Global Payments Up On Earnings

Smaller biotech companies Cempra (CEMP) and Lexicon Pharmaceuticals (LXRX) could get the biggest bang for expected fourth-quarter drug-trial results among drugmakers covered by Needham & Co.'s Alan Carr, the analyst said Tuesday.Acadia Pharmaceuticals (ACAD), Alnylan Pharmaceuticals (ALNY) and Intercept Pharmaceuticals (ICPT) are among others expected to release trial results before year-end."We believe the best opportunities in our coverage universe into early 2017 are around regulatory events" for Cempra and Lexicon, Needham analyst Alan Carr said in a research note Tuesday in which he briefly outlined some of the key actions expected this quarter.Cempra stock, though, fell 2.3%, to 22.59, in the stock market today, while Lexicon fell nearly 1%, to 17.85. Cempra stock was testing its 50-day line, after touching a nine-month high of 26.95 on Wednesday. Lexicon stock touched a nearly three-year high of 19.62 on Sept. 21.Cempra is expected to receive both U.S. Food and Drug Administration and EU approval for its drug Solithera to treat community-acquired pneumonia, or CAP, the most common type of pneumonia (as opposed to hospital-acquired pneumonia)."We expect a positive vote in favor of Solithera approval at the FDA Advisory Committee meeting (on Nov. 4), despite liver safety concerns (that) arose in the (phase-three) Solitaire-IV trial," Carr wrote. He expects commercial launch in the U.S. in Q1 2017."We expect Cempra to have moderate success in commercializing the drug independently, due to challenges for a small biotech company in penetrating urgent and primary care settings," he wrote, saying peak U.S. sales might be less than $1 billion a year, while a bigger drug company might see $2 billion-plus in sales.As for Lexicon, Carr this quarter expects results from a second phase-three trial for its diabetes drug sotagliflozin. "We assume a similar outcome to first trial, which

met primary endpoint," he wrote.Meanwhile, Carr says Lexicon and U.S. partner Sanofi (SNY) could see regulatory approval by year-end for telotristat, a rare disease that can cause tumors and cancer in the neuroendoctrine system. Carr estimates peak annual U.S. sales at $300 million. Ipsen is Lexicon's EU partner on this drug.Acadia this quarter is expected to release phase-two trial results for Nuplazid  (pimavanserin) to treat Alzheimer's Disease Psychosis (ADP), says Carr. The company released the drug for the treatment of  Parkinson's Disease Psychosis (PDP) in May, with Carr estimating Q3 sales at $3 million and Q4 sales at $10 million.Alnylam this quarter could provide data for several phase-two programs, including treatments for hemophilia, high cholesterol and amyloidosis, a rare disease that results in abnormal protein deposits in body tissues.As for Intercept, Carr this month expects a European regulatory decision on Ocaliva, its drug to treat the liver disease Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC). Ocaliva was launched in the U.S. in May. Carr estimates Q3 sales at $3 million and 2016 sales at $11 million.IBD'S TAKE: Biotech companies have feature prominently in the IBD 50 ranking of top-performing stocks over the past 52 weeks. Currently, though, only Biogen, at No. 35, makes the list, though the Medical-Biomed/Biotech industry groups ranks No. 10 out of 197 groups tracked.RELATED:Sanofi-Backed Lexicon Soars On Diabetes Drug Trial ResultsAmgen, Biogen Pitted In M&A Scenarios; Acadia Among Possible Targets

Stocks opened slightly lower Wednesday, despite better-than-expected August jobs data.Dow industrials and the S&P 500 were down 0.2% and the Nasdaq slipped 0.1%.In the Dow, Pfizer (PFE) rose a fraction. Exxon Mobil (XOM) fell less than 1%.Veeva Systems (VEEV) bolted 13% at the open after its second-quarter results easily topped analysts' targets. The IBD 50 and Leaderboard stock pulled back nearly 3% in heavy trade Tuesday, setting up a rebound from support at its 50-day moving average.China-based internet portal Sina Corp. (SINA) opened 1% lower. JPMorgan reiterated the stock's overweight rating in a Wednesday morning note.H&R Block (HRB) dropped 6% at the start of trading. The tax services chain reported earnings and revenue fell more than was expected by analysts during the second quarter.Palo Alto Networks (PANW) dived 8% at the open. The cybersecurity firm's fiscal fourth-quarter report late Tuesday showed earnings and revenue just above expectations. But Palo Alto's first-quarter earnings and revenue guidance stopped short of the consensus estimates.AstraZeneca (AZN) slipped more than 1% after the Securities and Exchange Commission announced that the drugmaker had agreed to pay $5.5 million to settle charges it had paid bribes to state workers and doctors in return for increased prescriptions at its Russian and Chinese operations.Deutsche Bank (DB) shares rose 3% after the company's chief executive said European banks were in need of consolidation, but dismissed rumors of a possible tie up with Commerzbank.The week's first shot of jobs data was a bit better than expected, with the ADP National Employment report showing U.S. nonfarm private sector employers added 177,000 workers in August. ADP also revised its July new jobs tally to 194,000, up from an initial 179,000 estimate.  Economists had projected a slowdown to 175,000 positions added. The Services sector added 183,000 jobs during the month, while manufacturing sector employers trimmed payrolls by 6,000 jobs. Notably, construction sector employment contracted by 2,000 workers.Jobs numbers continue with the Challenger Job Cut report for August, due out Thursday morning, followed by the Labor Department's August payrolls report on Friday.At 9:15 a.m. ET, Kingsbury International reports its Chicago Purchasing Managers' Index for August. July pending home sales numbers are expected from the National Association of Realtors at 10 a.m. ET, and the Energy Information Administration gives its weekly oil inventories report at 10:30 a.m. ET.Oil prices slumped more than 1% ahead of the morning weekly storage data, sending West Texas Intermediate below $46 per barrel and tracking toward a second straight weekly decline. Gold traded down a half percent to below $1,310 an ounce. The dollar gained vs. the euro and the yen. The 10-year Treasury yield edged up 1 basis point to 1.58%.China markets turned in a narrowly mixed finish while, in Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 climbed 1%. In Europe, markets were also tightly mixed, with the CAC 40 in Paris up 0.4% and Frankfurt's DAX and the FTSE 100 in London showing narrow losses in afternoon trade.RELATED:Investing Action Plan: Five Below, Ollie's, Salesforce EarningsPalo Alto Falls On Guidance, Veeva Systems Rallies

U.S. stock indexes sagged midday Thursday, and moderately higher volume added some concern.The Nasdaq trimmed 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average retreated 0.4% and 0.5%, respectively. The small-cap Russell 2000, which has been leading the market, dropped 1.3%. Volume was running modestly higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today.Blue chips were mostly down in the Dow. The two banks in the Dow — Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) — fell more than 1.5% each. Payment processor Visa (V) scored the best gain, rising 1.2%. Visa is consolidating, but recently retook its 50-day moving average line. In the S&P 500, one of the day's best gainers was gold miner Newmont Mining (NEM). The big-cap stock gapped up almost 6% as it reclaimed its 200-day line. Newmont remains beaten down, 19% off its high even with the day's gap up. The biggest loser in the S&P 500 was retailer Kohl's (KSS), down 19%.The retail sector has done little in the so-called Trump rally. Just before the election, retail was No. 26 of 33 sectors. Going into Thursday's session, retail was No. 25.In the Nasdaq 100, retailer Urban Outfitters (URBN) was the worst performer, down 5% in heavy volume.In economic news, payroll firm ADP reported that businesses added 153,000 jobs in December, which was 11% fewer than the Street expected. First-time jobless claims rolled in at 235,000, which was almost 10% fewer than expected.Internationally, services gauges tilted toward the bullish side. China's services sector picked up to a 17-month high. The United Kingdom reported the fastest growth in the services sector since July 2015. Japan's services sector grew at the fastest pace in 11 months. Ireland's services index popped to a five-month high in December.But in India, the services gauge for December contracted for a second straight month. About a third of India's economy is informal, which makes official statistics and economic gauges imperfect.RELATED:Microsoft Price Target Raise; Surface Booms Vs. AppleIntel Promises Progress On Virtual Reality

The employment report out on Friday at 8:30 a.m. ET is expected to show that the economy added 175,000 jobs in December, continuing the solid trend of recent months.But the real focus will be on wage growth and the jobless rate, which both delivered big surprises in last month's report.After the rise in average hourly earnings hit a seven-year high of 2.8% in October, wages backslid in November, slipping 0.1% and bringing the annual rate down to 2.5%. Friday's report could indicate whether that was just a statistical quirk.The consensus view is that December's report will show a 0.3% rise in average hourly earnings from November. Jefferies economists Ward McCarthy and Thomas Simons expect a 0.4% jump, lifting annual wage gains to a new cycle high of 2.9%.In November, the jobless rate surprisingly fell to a nine-year low of 4.6% from 4.9% amid a drop in workforce participation. The volatile household survey had been showing that more workers had been coming off the sidelines to participate in a stronger job market. Economists expect Friday's report to show the jobless rate rising to 4.7%, indicating that November's report somewhat overstated how tight the labor market is.Wage gains and the unemployment rate are both key indicators for the real question on everyone's mind: Can the job market accommodate President-elect Donald Trump's fiscal fuel without overheating? That won't be clear for some time and depends greatly on the size of the fiscal package that comes out of Congress, but Friday's report will offer some clues and could affect expectations for how fast the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates in the coming year.IBD'S TAKE: The Federal Reserve, long worried about paltry growth, has shifted to the role of traffic cop. Now the key question is whether Donald Trump's fiscal fuel will raise the economy's speed limit, allowing for faster growth without pushing inflation much above the Fed's comfort zone.On Thursday, ADP reported that private employers added 153,000 jobs in December, somewhat less than expected. The ADP has an uneven record of predicting Labor's nonfarm payrolls. Meanwhile, initial jobless claims tumbled by 28,000 to 235,000 in the week ended Dec. 260,000.Incoming evidence from corporate earnings reports suggests that wage pressures are continuing to rise moderately.On a Dec. 6 earnings call, Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) said it expected wage inflation of about 5% in the fourth quarter, up from its September projection of 4% to 4.5% for the second half of 2016.Casey's General Stores (CASY) highlighted "increased wage pressures" on a Dec. 8 earnings call as the prime factor behind a 4.9% increase in same-store operating costs.Casey's management also said they would stick by a planned annual salary increase of $10 million to avoid overtime pay under the Obama administration's Labor Department rule that was to take effect on Dec. 1., even though the election and an eleventh-hour injunction mean it's unlikely to be implemented without major changes.While it would be hard for any company to retract commitments for pay hikes once announced, Chief Financial Officer Bill Walljasper said the decision is in keeping with Casey's goal "to be the employer of choice in our market area, and so part of that for us is to have competitive wages at competitive benefits."Wal-Mart (WMT) boosted minimum salaries for assistant store managers to $48,500 from $45,000, effective in September, to avoid being liable for overtime pay."Labor is under some pressure," Darden Restaurants (DRI) CEO Gene Lee said on a Dec. 20 earnings call, when asked about the company's guidance for modestly higher labor inflation."We're operating in a low unemployment situation and in that environment we're going to continue to see wage increases," Lee said, according to a Seeking Alpha transcript. But he added that such environments have been "great for our business" in the past, and he's optimistic that "this wage inflation that we're seeing is going to turn into discretionary income and some of it's going to end up back in our restaurants."RELATED:Jobless Rate Dives To 9-Year Low; Is Labor Market Too Tight?How Overtime Pay Ruling Affects Wal-Mart, Dollar Tree, Fast Food

Stocks opened narrowly mixed Thursday following a mixed bag of employment news.The Nasdaq rose less than 0.2% while the S&P 500 and Dow industrials lost less than 0.1%.The Nasdaq launched into Thursday's session up 1.7% in the holiday-shortened week. The S&P 500 holds a 1.4% gain and the Dow is ahead 0.9%. But the Nasdaq is carrying a heavy load of distribution days.Department stores were active, with Kohl's (KSS) down 18% and Macy's (M) taking a 13% hit as analyst downgrades followed the stores' weak holiday sales reported late Wednesday. Deutsche Bank downgraded Macy's to hold from buy, and slashed its price target to 34 from 47. Telsey Advisory Group cut Kohl's to market perform from outperform.Wal-Mart (WMT) dipped 1% on the Dow.Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) rumbled up 9% at the opening bell. The Connecticut-based biotech filed its third-quarter 10-Q report late Wednesday, marking the end of an internal accounting investigation. Alexion shares rose 31% from a June low and began basing in early November. There is a potential buy point at 134.16, but the stock has been contained by resistance at its 40-week moving average for the past year.Corporate research firm CEB (CEB) bolted 24% after information technology researcher Gartner (IT) said it would acquire the company in a $2.6 billion cash-stock deal. Gartner shares dropped 2% in early trading.Halozyme Therapeutics (HALO) spiked 12%. The San Diego-based biotech reported positive results in a Phase 2 clinical trial of its pancreatic cancer drug PEGPH20.U.S. employers trimmed payrolls by 33,627 workers in December, according to the monthly Job Cut Report from consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas.  That was a 25% increase over November layoffs, which marked the lowest number of reductions during 2016. For the year, employers announced a total of 526,915 job cuts, 12% below 2015 levels and the annual 539,581 layoffs averaged since 2010.U.S. employers added a weaker-than-expected 153,000 workers in December, the National Employment Report from ADP estimated. Services sector employers added 163,000 positions, while goods-producing companies reduced their workforce by 16,000.First-time unemployment claims dropped to 235,000 in the week ended December 31, the Labor Department reported. That was down from 263,000 claims in the prior week and well below consensus views for 260,000 claims. the four-week average dropped to 256,750, its second straight decline after five weeks of increases.London-based researcher Markit offers up its December services Purchasing Managers' Index at 9:45 a.m. ET and at 10 a.m., look for the Institute for Supply Management's December Non-Manufacturing Index.Oil bumped up almost 1%, putting West Texas Intermediate near $54 a barrel. Gold climbed 1.1% to $1,177.60 an ounce. Platinum advanced almost 3%, trading up more than 7% so far this week. The dollar backed down sharply, while the 10-year Treasury yield slipped 3 basis points to 2.41%.In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng Index leapt 1.5% in a rally boosted by Wednesday's Fed minutes and led by energy and insurance companies. The Shanghai Composite added 0.2%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dipped 0.4%, easing after Wednesday's rally.European markets were mixed in afternoon trade, with the CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX down 0.1% apiece but sitting atop a four-week rally. London's FTSE 100 traded up 0.1%, briefly topping its prior high set in April 2010.RELATED:Disney, Netflix Climb Into Buy Zones: Investing Action Plan

Treasuries whipsawed between gains and losses after minutes from the Federal Reserve's December meeting showed officials focused on a gradual pace of interest-rate hikes, while seeing risks stemming from fiscal policy spurring faster economic growth and a stronger dollar providing a headwind.The benchmark 10-year U.S. yield fell about one basis point to 2.43% at 4:12 p.m. in New York, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader data. It fell as low as 2.43% and rose as high as about 2.47% after the release of the minutes of the Dec. 13-14 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, when officials raised rates for the first time in a year.The Fed minutes were "less hawkish, but not dovish," said Ian Lyngen, head of U.S. rates strategy at BMO Capital Markets.About half of the FOMC participants incorporated an assumption of more expansionary fiscal policy in their forecasts; however, several others pointed out that a further rise in the dollar might continue to hold down inflation. At least two bearish elements drew focus: the risk of "a sizable undershooting of the longer-run normal unemployment rate" that could force the Fed to raise rates faster, and the possibility that a change to the fed funds rate path "could also have implications for the reinvestment of proceeds" from maturing debt on the Fed's balance sheet.Bonds declined in most eurozone markets, led by France into the European close. U.S. economic data due out later this week include the December ADP employment change and the government's monthly labor report.
