Here's your Investing Action Plan for Friday: What you need to know as an investor. The Labor Department reports April employment figures on Friday, while Baker Hughes (BHI) reports weekly oil-rig data. Those reports come as the broader stock market remains under pressure, with a possible correction on the horizon, led by ailing techs such as Apple (AAPL). Weaker Job…

Treasury 10-year yields traded close to the lowest in two weeks after dueling U.S. economic data showed service companies expanded in April at the fastest pace in four months while jobs growth slowed.The benchmark 10-year note slipped two basis points to 1.78% on Wednesday.The Institute for Supply Management’s nonmanufacturing index rose to 55.7 from 54.5 in March, beating economist forecasts. Also, data from the ADP Research Institute showed U.S. companies added fewer jobs than expected last month, before the Labor Department releases official figures May 6.“The employment data was on the weak side, ISM nonmanufacturing was stronger -- the economic data this morning was on balance a little disappointing because of the jobs number," said Guy LeBas, chief fixed-income strategist at Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia. "I find it hard for a material bounce higher in yields."U.S. debt rallied by the most in two months Tuesday when data from China to Europe pointed to a slowing global economy that would need continued central bank support. Two regional Federal Reserve bank presidents said that an interest-rate increase should be on the table next month, at odds with market expectations.Futures show traders assign a 12% probability to a Fed rate increase next month and a 53% chance of an increase this year.

Private sector employers added 156,000 jobs in April, down from 200,000 in March, ADP said on Wednesday. That's the smallest gain since April 2013.Employers may be tapping the brakes on hiring amid slow economic growth, which hit a 2-year low. In the first quarter, the combination of solid payroll gains and weak growth translated to a drop in output per hour of work, a negative for earnings and wage hikes.Productivity fell at a 1.0% annual rate in the first quarter, as output rose 0.4% and hours worked grew 1.5%, the Labor Department said. It was the fourth drop in six quarters.The overall decline in productivity came despite a 1.9% rise in the manufacturing sector, which saw output grow 0.7% and hours worked fall 1.1%.Economists expected a 196,000 rise in private payrolls. The Labor Department employment report out on Friday is expected to a 207,000 gain in nonfarm payrolls.The productivity decline in the first quarter was slightly less than expected. Fourth-quarter productivity was revised to a 1.7% decline from the 2.2% drop first reported.Unit labor costs rose at a 4.1% annual rate after Q4's 2.7% gain. That's the biggest gain since Q4 2014.

Stocks were modestly lower at midday Wednesday following mixed economic data. The Nasdaq sank 0.8%, the S&P 500 was down 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.5%. Volume was running below Tuesday's levels on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE in the stock market today.Private employers added 156,000 jobs in April, according to payroll processor ADP. It was the lowest total in three years and far less than expected. But the Institute for Supply Management's index of U.S. service sector activity rose 1.2 points in April to 55.7, beating analysts' expectations. Readings above 50 indicate expansion.Cray (CRAY) dived 22%, destroying a flat base that it had been working on for the past two months, following its earnings report after the close Tuesday. The maker of high-performance computers lost 13 cents a share during the period, but that was much better than expected. Sales rose 33% to $105.6 million, also topping views.Investors appeared to react to uncertainty surround the company's Q2 revenue outlook.Meanwhile, Under Amour (UA) dropped 6% after the maker of athletic apparel announced the departure of two key executives late Tuesday. The stock fell more than 8% below a 45.53 cup-with-handle buy point, triggering a sell signal.How does Under Armour rank among its peers? Find out at IBD Stock Checkup.Most IBD 50 stocks were lower, but Paycom Software (PAYC) managed to buck the trend, rising 3% after posting strong quarterly earnings. The provider of cloud-based human resources management software is climbing the right side of a deep base.

Add a jump in open interest to signs that gold’s rally may persist after the best start to a year in a decade.Open interest, a tally of outstanding contracts in Comex futures, rose 3.1% to 565,774 on Tuesday, the highest since January 2011. The same day, investors boosted holdings in exchange traded funds backed by the metal for a sixth straight session to the highest since December 2013. The increases come after hedge funds boosted net-long positions in bullion futures and options more than fivefold since early February.Gold futures climbed 21% this year in the best start since 2006, helped by speculation that the U.S. Federal Reserve will be slow to tighten monetary policy amid global risks to growth and as lending rates in the euro area and Japan fell below zero. Low borrowing costs are a boon to gold and other precious metals because they don’t offer yields or dividends."There’s a lot more interest in gold, and we’re seeing a lot of people looking to enter gold," said Bob Haberkorn, a senior market strategist at RJO Futures in Chicago, in a phone interview. "We’re seeing a lot of new buying coming in. Overall, the sentiment toward gold is extremely bullish."Gold for immediate delivery swung between gains and losses before slipping 0.2% to $1,283.54 an ounce at 10:59 a.m. Wednesday in New York, according to Bloomberg generic pricing. Gold futures for June delivery fell 0.6% on the Comex.In the U.S., where the Fed is closely monitoring the job market before deciding whether to raise rates, companies in April added fewer workers to payrolls than economists projected, according to figures Wednesday from the ADP Research Institute in Roseland, N.J. U.S. worker productivity decreased for a second straight quarter, government data show.Traders see little chance of higher rates soon, even as two Fed officials said this week that an interest-rate increase should be on the table next month. Odds that the central bank will make a move at its meeting in June were at 12% on Wednesday, down from 24% at the start of last month, Fed fund futures data compiled by Bloomberg show.

Here's your Investing Action plan for Wednesday: What you need to know as an investor for the coming day. Tesla Motors (TSLA), Fitbit (FIT), Priceline (PCLN), Whole Foods Market (WFM) and several shale energy companies report earnings on Wednesday. Investors should also pay attention to U.S. oil inventory and production data as well as economic reports on productivity, service sector activity…

Private-sector employers continued to hire at a steady rate this month, adding 200,000 jobs after a slightly downward revised 209,300 in February, the ADP National Employment Report.Services firms accounted for 190,900 new hires, the vast bulk of new employment. Manufacturing added 2,600 jobs after losing 8,600 jobs in February. Boeing (BA) said Wednesday it would cut 4,550 jobs.Small firms led the way, adding 85,700 jobs, while large enterprises' net hiring slowed to 38,800. But year-over-year, large firms are adding jobs at the fastest pace since May 2012, while small business hiring is the weakest since mid-2014.Also, franchise employment rose by 22,000 in March and 4.1% vs. a year earlier, largely on restaurant franchise gains.  The National Labor Relations Board and several minimum wage hike efforts are singling out the franchise model used by McDonald's (MCD), Yum Brands (YUM) and many other fast-food chains.The Labor Department will release its March employment report on Friday. Economists expect to see a rise in nonfarm payrolls, including government jobs, of 210,000. They also expect a rise in hourly earnings and the average workweek, after weekly pay fell a stunning 0.5% last month.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Paychex’s (PAYX) quarterly revenue came in slightly ahead of Wall Street estimates, while its earnings were in line with views. But shares for the provider of payroll assistance dropped more than 2% in the early going Wednesday.Paychex said that its third-quarter revenue rose 7% to $752.6 million as it provided more payroll services, added new customers and saw its revenue per check climb. Analysts had predicted revenue at $751.2 million.The company, which primarily serves small and medium-sized companies with minimum-premium health insurance and cloud-based accounting, said that its adjusted earnings were 50 cents a share.Paychex forecast its total service revenue for the fiscal year ending May 31 to grow 7% to 8%. The midpoint would be slightly below analyst consensus for roughly 7.6% revenue growth for the year.Human resources corporate services providers such as Paychex, Cintas (CTAS), Convergys (CVG), WageWorks (WAGE) and ExlService Holdings (EXLS) have expanded recently, in part by assisting companies at complying with ObamaCare regulations in the health insurance market.During the quarter, Paychex began integrating Advance Partners, a provider of financial, operational and strategic services that it purchased on Dec. 22 for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition added 1% to third-quarter revenue, Paychex said."We are pleased with execution during our selling season, in particular in the midmarket space," Chief Executive Martin Mucci said in a written statement.Paychex stock has been in a first-stage consolidation for nearly three months with a 54.88 buy point. It closed down 2.2% to 53.28 in the stock market today.Smaller rival ExlService dipped 0.1% Wednesday. Cintas gained 0.1%, Convergys lost 0.7%, and WageWorks dropped 2.3%. Automatic Data Processing (ADP) fell 0.3%.

Hello Barbie says, "Privacy breach" to plaintiffs in a lawsuit that’s testing the boundaries of security in the Internet of Things age.Mattel (MAT), the maker of the interactive doll, is among those being sued on grounds that the doll picks up and records the voices of the children who play with the doll, voices that it uploads and stores without parental consent.The unusual case was filed in December in Los Angeles County Superior Court. Other defendants include San Francisco-based ToyTalk, which partnered with Mattel to produce the doll; and Los Angeles-based Samet Privacy, which does business as the kidSAFE Seal Program that lists, reviews and certifies interactive and online products as compliant with the federal Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act, or COPPA.“The problem is parents and children don’t really know that ToyTalk is going to use their child’s conversation for data mining and other purposes not fully disclosed,” said Steve Teppler of the Abbott Law Group in Jacksonville, Fla. “They say they’ll protect the child of the purchasing parent’s identity, but what about friends’ children?”Abbott Law Group represents the plaintiffs in the case: Ashley Archer-Hayes of Vista, Calif., who bought the doll, and her minor child; and Charity Johnson of Chula Vista, Calif., and her minor child “on behalf of all others similarly situated,” states the suit. The children of Johnson and Archer-Hayes are friends, and they played with Hello Barbie at a Barbie-themed birthday party late last year, the suit says.The suit is one of many dealing with the untapped online frontier that is the Internet of Things, referring to products used in everyday life that are increasingly connected with the Internet and that store information online. These products range from cars to home security systems.On its website, kidSAFE describes Hello Barbie as “the first fashion doll that can have a two-way conversation with girls. The doll features speech recognition and progressive learning features that enable girls to engage with Barbie like never before. Hello Barbie features more than 8,000 lines of dialogue, inspires imagination and storytelling, plays more than 20 interactive games, and tells jokes.”Although Hello Barbie must be registered to activate, and the registration process includes information relating to privacy, plaintiffs argue that Hello Barbie will pick up voices of a child’s friends, and those voices will be uploaded and stored without parental knowledge, let alone consent.Interactive toys like Hello Barbie are expected to proliferate. How can parents stay informed about the privacy policies of each toy?“That’s the problem,” Teppler said. “What are your choices? You could make the doll only perform with the registered user, but that’s not the way the toy is designed. To comply with COPPA, you’d have to have a waiver for the user of the child’s voice. We don’t know what ToyTalk’s affiliates do with this information.”Teppler raised the possibility that information stored on ToyTalk computers could become discoverable in litigation, for example, if kids start talking about their parents’ activities.“It’s an interesting evidentiary issue,” said Teppler. “The terms of service say the purchasing parents can access the recordings for two years, but can they get them erased? You could deactivate your account, but they would still have the recordings.”Mattel would not make someone available for an interview, but spokesman Alex Clark said in an email, “While we do not comment on pending litigation, I can tell you Mattel is committed to ensuring every product we make meets or exceeds all applicable laws and regulations. In addition, we are confident in the robust data security technology used in our Hello Barbie product.”For its part, kidSAFE has rated Hello Barbie as “COPPA certified.”Ben Warlick, an attorney with Morris, Manning and Martin in Atlanta, says that plaintiffs have an uphill battle to recovery because Mattel and other defendants don’t control how a child uses the toy.“Plaintiffs pointed out suggestions for what Mattel could have done, including notifying parents that the toy should not be used outside the presence of other nonregistered children,” Warlick said. “But I do not think it’s a realistic argument to tell a child not to play with a toy around other kids; that’s hard to do.”Warlick, who co-chairs his firm’s Internet of Things practice group, says that the Hello Barbie case is likely just one of the first of many that will test the bounds of privacy protection in the Internet of Things age.“We started the new practice group because we’re finding that universal notions of privacy and security don’t necessarily translate to the Internet of Things,” he said.Warlick says that an argument can be made that interactive devices should have higher security and encryption features, “but many little battery-powered devices like weather or pet monitors may not have the processing power to run encryption or robust security measures.”Similar suits have been filed against ADP home security systems and Vizio smart TV sets.“It’s a real issue for product developers in this area,” Warlick said, “about what is the right level of security and encryption for these devices.”

Treasuries fell, led by 30-year bonds, as traders looked to U.S. employment data for the next clue to the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate path.Longer-dated U.S. debt retraced gains a day after Fed Chair Janet Yellen sent yields tumbling when she said in a speech that caution in raising rates was “especially warranted.” A report from the ADP Research Institute showed the U.S. added more jobs than forecast in March ahead of Labor Department data due April 1. The difference between yields on two- and 30-year Treasuries, known as the yield curve, climbed to the highest since Feb. 18.The ADP report "may have caused some traders to back away from bets that payrolls will disappoint on Friday," said Jim O’Sullivan, chief U.S. economist at High Frequency Economics Ltd in Valhalla, New York. "It adds to the evidence that the trend in employment growth remains strong, despite the global economic and financial developments that Fed officials continue to worry about."Investors are assessing the outlook for the $13.3 trillion Treasuries market after Yellen said global economic risks may slow the pace of policy tightening, even amid signs of U.S. economic strength. The Labor Department report will show the U.S. added 205,000 jobs this month, while the pace of wage gains held steady at a 2.2% annual rate, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists. A report this week showed core U.S. inflation remains below the central bank’s 2% target.The yield on the 30-year bond, which is more sensitive to longer-term expectations for inflation and economic growth, rose five basis points, or 0.05 percentage point, to 2.65% as of 5 p.m. ET, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader data.The 2.5% security due in February 2046 fell $10.94 per $1,000 face amount, to 96-27/32.The gap between yields on two- and 30-year Treasuries steepened for a second day, rising to 1.89 percentage points.“With the Fed now more reluctant to hike than previous perception suggested, the notion that inflation could bounce back and steepen up the curve makes sense,” said Ian Lyngen a government-bond strategist at CRT Capital Group LLC in Stamford, Connecticut.Companies added 200,000 workers in March, according to figures released Wednesday from Roseland, New Jersey-based ADP. The median forecast in a Bloomberg survey called for a 195,000 March advance.The U.S. sold $28 billion of seven-year securities Wednesday at a yield of 1.606%, the last of three note auctions this week totaling $88 billion.

And as expected - stocks did very little yesterday...in yesterday's note - I suggested that we would remain in the 2055/2065 range with no reason at all to do much else....in fact yesterday's range was 2057/2063 - and there were no fireworks, no end of month or end of qtr surprises at all as investors were just happy to see the end of the qtr come (and go)! In the end the Dow end the qtr with a 1.5% gain and the S&P had a 0.8% gain.Now you could credit yesterday's lack of activity to both exhaustion and reluctance by anyone to do anything ahead of today's NFP report and the host of other macro data points that will bombard us today......... Remember today is April 1st - otherwise known as April Fool's Day around the world....now while its origin is unknown - it is a day defined by tricks, tomfoolery and hoaxes - all designed to make someone look like an April Fool..... So the question today is:Will today's NFP report just be an April Fool's joke? Mkt expectations are calling for an increase of 205k jobs created in March - now remember last month the call was for +195k and the gov't came out and told us that we really created 242k jobs! (Now THAT is a joke.....).....on Wednesday - the ADP reported a slightly higher number of jobs created + 200k (vs. the expected 195k), and they raised the prior month from 205k to 214k......this now suggests that we will get a stronger NFP report.... and to that I say - "April Fools!!!"Other eco data due out today includes:
The Unemployment rate - exp of 4.9%,
Avg Hourly Earnings of +0.2%,
Avg Hours Worked - exp of 34.5
Labor Participation Rate exp of 62.9%
Market US Manf PMI of 51.5
ISM Manf of 51
Construction Spending of +0.1%

Ward's Domestic Vehicle Sales of 13.8 mil and Total Vehicle Sales of 17.5 milSo as you can see - it will be a day of data points...and the mkt appears to be taking a breather. US futures are down 9 pts in early pre-mkt trading.....Now remember - it is a NEW qtr...the slate has been wiped clean and the odometer has been reset to zero.....The dollar continues to come under pressure, oil appears to be de-coupling from the broader mkt - the recent rally in oil driven more by the dollar action vs. any real change in fundamentals.....Gold - which has seen a dramatic 16% gain over the past 3 months is now coming under a bit of pressure as investors decipher the tea leaves over the future of US and global economics. If the data begins strengthen then logic tells us that Gold should weaken (think other more dynamic opportunities) but if the global economies continue to stall or weaken then watch Gold spike higher yet again (think the safe haven play)....Earnings are now clearly in the bulls eye as investors prepare themselves for the onslaught of coming earnings over the next 3 weeks.The WSJ runs with a headline article this morning detailing the state of the IPO (Initial Public Offering) mkt."Lackluster IPO Market Flashes Warning - Pace for initial public offerings is slowest first qtr since 2009, and analysts warn that second period may not bring much relief"In this article the writer tries to connect the dots between the lack of new product and investor appetite for risk...... I am not sure that is the connection...investor appetite will be fed by interesting and dynamic product as well as realistic valuations for these untested products.....it is the purest form of mkt dynamics that rewards proper risk taking......Investment by PE firms, Venture Capital Firm and large asset management firms have push valuations to extremes and maybe investors are finally waking up the idea that these extreme valuations reward nobody but the investment banks and the insiders looking to unload these 'over valued' shares.Yesterday we learned that many of the big asset managers (Fidelity, Blackrock, TRowe Price etc....) - the same ones that have invested in private start ups (PRE-IPO) have pushed valuations to 'extreme' levels and are now taking - 'hair cuts' ( I think it was described as an AX) to valuation estimates for these privately held (difficult to value) companies. I would argue that it was THESE asset managers themselves that are responsible for the crazy valuations creating ' Unicorns' that they now are the focus of investor angst.[A Unicorn is usually a startup company that does NOT have any established performance metrics but have a supposed stock mkt valuation of more than $1 billion dollars]So now that all of these asset managers are having a 'V-8' moment and becoming more realistic - we are beginning to see a change in psychology.....Should these companies really have such ridiculous valuations? Apparently not! And these very markdowns have sucked the life out of the momentum - making it harder for investment banks to 'sell this story' at the ridiculous valuations that they have tried to convince us all of....So now you get untested, overvalued private companies that think they are going to cash out at 'X' and are now told that "maybe that is not the case"......they may have to settle for something more realistic like 'Y'....and they don't want that - so they don't come to the mkt....It's like the guy that says my house is worth $1 mil while everything around him is trading at $400k......HELLO??? Does this remind anyone of the late 90's DOT.COM bubble?????Global mkts begin the new qtr all in the RED - (no one should be surprised at all).

As noted - US futures a pointing lower - now down 9 pts at 2044 - in pre-mkt trading as we prepare for the US jobs report. If we don't find support on the future right here at 2040 - then a move into the low 2030's would be expected.Global mkts also started the new qtr in the RED - In Asia - all mkts ended the day lower.....In Japan the March Manufacturing PMI dropped to 49.1 while the important Tankan Survey also missed estimates coming in at 4 vs. the exp of 6 - and this only causes more angst over the Japanese economy. Next door in China - we did see China Manf PMI rise (surprise) to a 9 month high of 50.2 vs. the est of 49.4. All of this just noise as all eyes are focused on the US - after all the drama of the past couple of weeks. Japan - 3.5%, Hong Kong -1.34%, China +0.12% and ASX -1.64%.In Europe - PMI"s were than the flash estimates, but the weakness in Japan ended up stealing the show....Volumes remain subdued as European investors count the minutes until the US jobs report. FTSE - 1.2%, CAC 40 - 2.09%, DAX -2%, EUROSTOXX -2.06%, SPAIN -1% and ITALY -1.85%

Today we get Cleveland's own Loretta Mester - who will be speaking at 1 pm....she tends to be more hawkish than dovish - but let's see what she has to say today. Remember - it is April Fool's Day -so beware of anything that sounds 'too good to be true'.Take Good Care

Gold slipped, wiping out this month’s gain, as signs of a strengthening U.S. labor market and a rally in equities curbed demand for haven assets.Companies took on 200,000 workers in March, beating a median forecast of 195,000 in a Bloomberg survey, and adding to evidence of a firming labor market, according to figures Wednesday from the Roseland, N.J.-based ADP Research Institute. Stocks around the world advanced and oil gained for the first time in five days."It really looks like gold has topped out," Michael Smith, the president of T&K Futures & Options Inc. in Port St. Lucie, Fla., said by telephone. "Any good economic news is going to be bad for gold."Gold futures for June delivery declined 0.7% to settle at $1,228.60 an ounce at 1:45 p.m. on the Comex in New York. On Tuesday, prices gained 1.3%, the biggest advance since March 17, after Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen reasserted a gradual approach to raising interest rates. Prices are down 0.5% this month.Spot prices, which traded at $1,227.22 Tuesday will drop to $1,130 by September as the rally in the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index prompts investors to reevaluate their pessimism on the U.S. economy and back away from gold, Jeffrey Christian, the New York-based managing partner at CPM, said in an interview."Yesterday, the Fed did it again in helping gold higher as it pushed back rate rise expectations," said Matthew Turner, a precious metals analyst at Macquarie Group Ltd. in London. "Today, it looks as if the buying had been a bit overdone, since even if the U.S. is stumbling towards a rate rise, it will get there eventually."

The U.S. stock market followed European markets higher and extended its gains as the Federal Reserve effect continued into Wednesday.The Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq composite each rose 0.5%, while the S&P 500 added 0.4%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq closed above its 200-day moving average for the first time in nearly three months. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq fell from Tuesday's levels, according to preliminary figures.Winners topped losers by about a 5-to-3 margin on the the NYSE, and by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq.Select oil-and-gas-related industry groups led the upside in today's stock market action, even though crude oil reversed an early 4% gain. It ended up just 0.1% to $38.32 a barrel. Consumer electronics retailers and railroad operators also outperformed. Homebuilders, data storage and gold miners lagged.On Tuesday, dovish comments from Fed Chair Janet Yellen were cheered on Wall Street as indexes rose sharply.Apple (AAPL) and Visa (V) led the Dow, each with an almost 2% gain. Apple is now 2% away from retaking its 200-day moving average. It's been below the line since early November. Cowen upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform and raised its price target to 135 from 125. Shares had advanced more than 2% Tuesday amid news the FBI had dropped its iPhone-hacking order against Apple.On the IBD 50, Universal Display (OLED) knocked out an almost 4% gain to climb just past a 54.78 buy point of a cup with handle. Volume was 92% higher than normal, a bullish sign.Lululemon Athletica (LULU) gapped up and soared 11% to a nine-month high in fast turnover. Shares cleared a 65.09 buy point of a new handle. Earlier this month, the stock cleared a 63.60 handle but volume was light. The yoga wear maker reported Q4 results that topped views, though it offered Q1 and full-year EPS guidance below forecasts.Sonic (SONC) gapped up and rose more than 6% to a one-year high, clearing a 33.04 handle entry in hefty trade. The drive-in burger chain late Tuesday reported solid earnings.In economic news, private employers added 200,000 jobs in March, according to the ADP National Employment Report, just below forecasts for 203,000 and a downwardly revised 205,000 in February.Economic data out Thursday include weekly jobless claims and the Chicago PMI for March. The Fed's Charles Evans and William Dudley are scheduled to speak.Image provided by Shutterstock.

With one trading session left in the first quarter of 2016, stocks on Wednesday gave growth investors a little more confidence to wade deeper into the market. The major indexes padded Tuesday's gains with a broad -- albeit mild -- advance. Volume declined. The gains by the Nasdaq composite, S&P 500 and even the S&P 100 -- which tracks the…

The stock market opened higher Wednesday as oil prices rebounded and most global markets moved higher.The Nasdaq rose 1%, the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.9% and the S&P 500 gained 0.8%.The stock market today warmed its hands on some afterglow from Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen's comments on Tuesday. Yellen's cautious tone pushed back expectations for any further interest rate hikes until September, sending U.S. stocks sharply higher Tuesday and triggering broad rallies in global currency and stock markets.Wall Street also liked the look of the ADP National Employment Report. It showed that private employers added 200,000 workers in March, down from a downwardly revised 205,000 new hires in February and just below expectations for 203,000 new jobs. Service-sector employers accounted for 191,000 of the positions.Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Charles Evans is scheduled to speak at 1 p.m. ET.Oil futures bobbed 2% higher, with West Texas Intermediate just below $39 a barrel and down a bit more than 1% for the week. Oil prices may see some effect from weekly inventories data, due out from the Energy Information Administration at 10:30 a.m. ET. Gold was flat at $1,237 an ounce. The dollar eased vs. the euro and the yen. Bonds also inched lower, putting the 10-year-yield up 1 basis point to 1.82%.Overseas markets asserted a positive influence. The leading indexes in Hong Kong and Shanghai ended Wednesday's session with gains of between 2% and 3%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dropped 1.3%,  pressured by the yen's gaining strength following Tuesday's comments from Yellen.In Europe, benchmark indexes in Frankfurt, Paris and London all showed gains approaching 2% near midday.Dow stocks were generally positive, with Apple (AAPL) and McDonald's (MCD) leading the way. Boeing (BA) picked up 0.7% after announcing it would cut 4,500 workers from its commercial aircraft division by June, after already cutting 1,200 workers from the unit this year.S&P 500 component PayPal (PYPL) edged 0.3% higher. PayPal has been wrestling to retake a 40.03 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Lululemon Athletica (LULU) soared 10% after reporting fourth-quarter revenue and earnings well ahead of its previously increased guidance. First-quarter and full-year EPS guidance was below analyst consensus.  The stock has traded below a 63.60 buy point since tripping a sell rule with a 9% dive below that pivot.Inside the IBD 50, Facebook (FB) reversed lower, falling 0.2%. It's near the top of a new base with a  117.69 buy point.Also in the IBD 50, Store Capital (STOR) dropped nearly 2% after pricing a follow-on offering of 33.3 million shares of common stock at 25.25. The shares are owned by STORE Holding, a stockholder affiliated with Oaktree Capital Management. Store Capital is not offering any shares. Store Capital shares ended Tuesday's session extended after a rebound from 10-week support early in March.Image provided by Shutterstock.

So yesterday Janet came out swinging - admitting that the world is on the edge or a recession saying:"Given the risks to the outlook, I consider it appropriate for the committee to proceed cautiously in adjusting policy.....the key is that the global economic and financial backdrop looms more threateningly now than before.........and even though officials expect the US economy to weather any further rough patches, the dangers can't be ignored"Let me be clear - she did NOT give any details on timing whatsoever and now the feeling is that if we get any rate rise at all - it will just ONE and it may not be in June....So we can forget all the chatter about 'multiple increases'.... and should the economy take a turn for the worse - she assured the invitees that the FED could still take steps to resuscitate the economy - think 'forward guidance' (which is just another word for Jawboning - which is what she did yesterday as she 'guided' expectations), the other trick up her sleeve would be the launch of an ECB style bazooka..... but either way - she put the idea of any increase to bed and she essentially told the 5 non-compliant FED mouthpieces to 'assume the position' and prepare to get spanked for insinuating last week that rates are due to rise in April -.......And the mkt roared! Investors and traders immediately hit the BUY button on their computers sending the S&P up 17 pts or 0.8% and the Dow up 97 pts or 0.6%.....Remember - last week - CNBC.com ran with a headline article about how "Fed Chair Yellen has a mini revolt on her hands" as 5 FED presidents took to the airwaves to suggest that the FED was falling behind the curve and that the mkt (and investors) should expect rates to rise in April. Now it appears that Janet was not happy about that development - And whether or not there is a bit of dissension in the ranks - as the French proverb goes: "Il faut laver son linge sale en famille" ......or "Never wash your dirty laundry in public".... and that is what they were doing.......washing their 'dirty laundry' for all to see in the name of 'transparency'. And what does that transparency show - it shows a complete mess within the ranks as no one really knows what to do....so staying the course appears to be the best answer for now.....Oh boy.....this story gets more interesting as the hours tick by.....I am beginning to re-think this whole transparency issue - Is it in fact the best thing for the mkts? Does it create more angst and instability for investors and traders? Would Paul Volker ever run the FED like this? (A: NO) Does the FED secretly want more instability to keep everyone guessing? As far as I am concerned - they can do what they want 'behind closed doors' but once they open those doors and the FED chair speaks then that should be it. Period the end. Whatever happened to loyalty? This business of then letting everyone in the FED run hog wild over any network that will have them is getting a bit exhausting. Because in the end - what does it really accomplish besides mass confusion and mkt instability? It is not helpful for investors nor businesses that are trying to plan for the future - it also does not help the individual as he/she plans for the future. The constant sense of angst concerning (global) monetary policy is unnecessary - and quite honestly has created a global monster...Just look around the world and tell me what you see....I think the worst part of all this is what are we really talking about? 25 bps?

Moving rates from an absurdly low level to another absurdly low level? I mean we are talking about going from 0.05% to 0.75%....not from 4% to 5%. And still this tiny move is creating all of this drama.....For those of you too young to remember 1982 - let me remind you....rates were 21% , the Dow was trading at 792 - and then on Tuesday Aug 17th - Chair Volker cut rates by 10% or a full 2%age points when he decided to take the bull by the horns and do something dramatic.....He took rates down to 19% - and the world celebrated, the mkt surged by 4.5% on that day......volumes exploded and the greatest bull mkt of our lifetime was born....... THAT WAS DRAMATIC! (But that was a different time......Ronald Reagan was president and America was on the verge of an incredible resurgence...)Once again - let's point out how legislators have done zero to assist the FED by being creative and pro-active with fiscal policy....But that's another story - one that we see unfolding right in front of us via the Presidential election......People are disgusted and rightly so.....Does anyone in DC understand that?Overnight - stocks rallied - (duh), credit mkts rallied, commodities (think oil) rallied and the dollar continued to slide lower - extending its worst month in 5 yrs. The VIX also moved lower - sliding 9% taking it to its lowest level of the year.....what does this mean? It means that there is a fair amount of complacency in the mkt - no real sense of fear...of course not - Janet has once again tucked it tightly in bed - kissing it on the head, saying 'Mommy loves you... now go to sleep'..... and this is right in front of what is expected to be a weak earnings season.... so the plot thickens.Stocks in Asia and Europe shot higher on the news....with the exception of Japan that got hit with a huge drop in Industrial Production - sending the Nikkei down 1.5%. Hong Kong +2.15%, China + 2.77% and the ASX +0.1%.European mkts following in lock step with Asia and the US....FTSE +1.7%, CAC 40 + 1.9%, DAX + 1.7%, EUROSTOXX +1.6%, SPAIN +1.5% and ITALY + 1.45%US Futures are up another 11 pts in pre-mkt trading......taking the futures index up to 2060.....which will send the cash index up to 2067 if this holds.....I suspect that 2075 should be another level of resistance - but anything is possible now.... Eco data today includes Mort Apps which fell by 1%, and the ADP employment report which is due to show an increase of something approaching +195k jobs.....We will be entertained by one FED speaker today.....Chicago's own Charlie Evans.....(an admitted DOVE). He will be on CNBC Squawk box at 8:30 just after the ADP release, he will also be speaking at the Forecasters Club of NY at 1 pm.Remember that this is end of month and qtr...so a rally would do so many people so much good - especially ahead of April 15th....(Tax day)..... Either way -Take Good Care

The stock market shook off a weak start to score big gains Tuesday, after dovish remarks by Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen.The Nasdaq composite surged 1.7%, while the S&P 500 rose 0.9%, and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.6%. Small caps also fared well, with the Russell 2000 up 2.7%. Volume was sharply higher across the board vs. Monday, according to preliminary figures.Winners topped losers by a nearly 4-to-1 margin on the NYSE and by more than 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq. Gold miners, software makers and chip stocks were among the top gainers in the stock market today. Consumer electronics and oil stocks lagged. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures fell more than 2% to $38.43 a barrel, extending their slide for a fifth straight session.After the close, Sonic (SONC) was trading 3% higher on a fiscal Q2 earnings and sales beat. The burger chain also boosted its full-year earnings and same-store sales outlook. Shares had edged slightly lower during the regular session and were just shy of a 33.04 cup-with-handle buy point.Dave & Buster's (PLAY) was down slightly in extended trading after reporting Q4 results that topped views. The stock rose 2% during the regular session and is building the right side of a base.Apple (AAPL) led the Dow with a 2.4% advance, its biggest one-day gain in nearly a month. The stock, up 16% from its Jan. 28 low, is still nearly 20% off its high. The FBI on Monday withdrew its order for Apple to hack into the iPhone used by Syed Farook, one of the two perpetrators of the December mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif. Apple had been fighting the order since mid-February.Microsoft (MSFT) was the second-biggest gainer on the blue chip index, climbing 2.2% as the stock nears a 55.19 buy point of a double-bottom base. The software giant is reportedly among companies interested in bidding for troubled Internet firm Yahoo (YHOO), shares of which rose 3.1% Tuesday.The IBD 50 outperformed, with 46 advancers and four decliners. Telecom play Broadsoft (BSFT) led with a 6% jump, which broke out past a 39.20 buy point. TAL Education (XRS), Universal Display (OLED) and Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI) all rose more than 3%.On the economic front, consumer confidence came in better than expected for March, while the S&P/Case-Shiller 20-City Composite Index for January showed a 5.7% jump in home prices.Economic data due out Wednesday include the ADP employment report for March and the weekly mortgage applications and petroleum status reports.

Thanks Janet. Stocks wiped out small early-morning losses Tuesday, soon after the most powerful banker in the world reiterated a "go slow" approach toward raising short-term interest rates. The major indexes then kept rumbling higher, right into the finish. Volume jumped sharply on both main exchanges. The gains in heavier volume reflected anxious buying (and quite likely some short covering)…

Stocks chopped as neither the bulls nor the bears made a stand, volume was the lowest so far for 2016, and many global mkts had remained closed for what is known as the Easter Monday Holiday......leaving very little for traders or investors to chomp on......and so the S&P did nothing really other than bounce around moving both north and south of the unchanged line some 20 times - and at the final bell was up 1 pt to close at 2037.The lack of action is more reflective of the uncertainty over the near term direction the 1Q earnings season and the uncertainty over FED policy.....Recall that last week - we saw a revolt within the central bank......on the 16th - Janet assured the world that rates were fine right where they were for now (all the while leaving June as the next launch date).....concern over global macro issues and mkt turmoil had given rise to continued caution in terms of US monetary policy...the mkts loved it and rallied hard exploding thru what should have been more significant resistance at the 200 dma....but on the back of the renewed ECB commitment to stimulus and Janet's commitment to 'lower for longer' - investors/traders went on a buying binge - some to 'get more long' while others scrambled to cover 'short positions' (or those bearish bets) on the future direction of stocks.That took us up and thru resistance only to fail at the 2050 level when the revolt began....5 different members of the FED came out and challenged her publicly....defying the data, ignoring the protocol.....each one suggesting that not only should rates rise - they should do so in April....smack in the middle of what is expected to be a weak earnings season.... the mkts stumbled, unable to advance as confusion set in..... but they did not collapse either - or not yet anyway.....Were these bozo's just testing the water? Were they trying to gauge investor sentiment? Was this all a ploy to divert the conversation away from the broader geo-political issues - ISIS, Brussels, Oil, a weakening Europe, Obama's visit to Cuba and his Tango in Argentina and even the comedic stupidity of the Presidential election as two of the GOP contenders running for the highest office in the country succumb to middle school antics?OK...so today - all mkts are back online and the focus is returning to what should be the drivers of mkt action. Investors and traders returned to their desks after the long weekend and now are focusing on the end of the month action, coming macro data and what Janet will say today when she speaks at the Economic Club of NY at 12:20 pm (est)....Overnight - San Fran's Fed President Williams is the latest to opine on monetary policy this morning.... You see - he is in Singapore - and gave 'prepared remarks' to an audience at the National University there about US monetary policy - because that is important.........and in it he appeared to join in with his fellow bankers while never really committing to any hard and fast date - as he said -"Others' economic fate do now spell our own.....My view is essentially, let's just stay on track. Let's not get sidelined by the noise and distraction commentary can sometimes cause. We're not quite where I'd like us to be, but recent developments have been encouraging and add to my confidence that we're on course to reach our (inflation) goal. Overall the US economy keeps chugging ahead."And so there is another vote for a rate increase - at some point - leaving him squarely 'on the fence' but suggesting that the next move should be UP and not DOWN- as he tried to assuage investor/trader angst.Now eco data this week includes a fair amount of information.....today we get lots of Case Shiller Home Price data......(nothing to get excited about), tomorrow brings us the ADP employment report and expectations are for +195k jobs.....Thursday includes ISM Milwaukee and the Chicago Purchasing Managers report.....on Friday - we get the monthly Non Farm Payroll report - and this time the gov't is promising us an increase of 210k jobs, (How many of those are minimum wage?), they expect unemployment to remain at 4.9% and are looking for average hourly wages to increase by 0.2%. Look for ISM Manf, Construction Spending, Labor Force Participation rates, ISM Prices Paid and ISM New orders. All of this macro data will set the stage for more trader speculation on the next FED move. What do FED Fund Futures say about an April increase?US futures are down 4 pts at 2024.....right now....there is no reason for the mkts to really rally hard at the moment.....but remember it is end of month and end of qtr..so the next couple of days could see increased volumes as portfolio managers 'clean up' ahead of the marking period. I continue to believe that we remain range bound within the 2020/2050 trading bands.The next move will come from the FED and if Janet surprises us and tells us that so much has changed in the last two weeks - and SHE puts April squarely on the table.... then watch for the mkt to test lower.....breaching the 2020 support to test the 1996 support level.I don't expect that she is going to divine the tea leaves for anybody today. It will be more of the same - where she plays the Dove and then releases the boys to contradict her to gauge investor and mkt sentiment. After that - then the mkts will settle in for month/qtr end and then prepare for the coming earnings season....which kicks off the week of April 4th.In Asia - stocks traded with a downside bias on some soft economic data. In Japan - the Unemployment Rate and Retail Sales both missed. Japan -0.18%, Hong Kong +0.1%, China -1.28%, ASX -1.57%,In Europe - stocks are edging higher ahead of Yellen’s speech. The Europeans are not convinced that rates are due to rise in April.....Michael Hewson - Chief Mkt analyst at CMC markets sums it up last week's chatter this way:"What was all the more puzzling was that last week's chatter was completely at odds with the recent dovish narrative of the most recent FOMC meeting"So - sit back and enjoy the show.....remember the mkt is now flat on the year and that is a WIN for many asset managers as we close out the qtr.....I suspect the mkt will hold tight thru Thursday....but then Friday is April 1st and the beginning of a new qtr.....Take Good Care

Private employers added a net 213,800 jobs to their payrolls in February, up from 193,400 in January, ADP reported. The services sector accounted for virtually all of the gains, while manufacturing employment fell.Economists expected private payrolls to rise 185,000 last month.The services sector added 208,500 jobs, up 20% from January's downwardly revised 174,400 jobs added, ADP said. Broken down further, professional and business services added 59,000 jobs, up 55% from January. Trade/transportation/utilities added 20,000, down 30% from January.The 8,000 jobs added in the financial activities sector was the least since August. Bank of America (BAC) is reportedly planning investment banking cuts, according to various recent reports, after JPMorgan Chase (JPM) warned of a "very tough" quarter for investment banking.Manufacturing, battered by a strong dollar, weak global economic growth and an enervated energy sector, lost 8,900 jobs last month, the second-largest drop in five years. Halliburton (HAL) is among the companies who have announced fresh layoffs in recent days. Manufacturing employment rose 0.1% vs. a year earlier, the smallest gain since late 2010.But the overall goods sector increased jobs modestly, led by a gain in construction, which added 27,000 payrolls.Large businesses and small businesses added 76,000 jobs each, while medium-sized businesses added 62,000 jobs.ADP's report comes ahead of the Labor Department's employment report on Friday. Economists expect 190,000 non-farm payrolls were added in February. They see the unemployment rate holding at 4.9%.

Let's just get this off the table NOW -And let the games begin .......We weren't 5 mins into the debate before FOX News lost complete control of the GOP debate, the issues and the candidates....As so many expected - the school yard fight between Rubio, Trump and Cruz continued to play out on the small screen...John Kasich - Ohio Governor - remained on the sidelines - taking the high road, choosing not to get drawn into the fray and showing the country that he is the most presidential of any of the GOP candidates....and who could blame him?In a continuation of Rubio's assessment about the size of Donald's HANDS - Trump made sure to let the world know that the size of his hands has nothing to do with the size of anything else and as expected today's NY POST runs with the headline:"Prickly Don Rips Below the Belt Jab - SIZE MATTERS"And now - US politics has fallen to a new low - and the GOP is frantic....while Hillary is all 'nestled in her bed with visions of sugar plums in her head!Stocks edged higher yesterday.....as they continue to build on the rally, a rally begun by the turnaround in oil/energy and financials....Healthcare and Tech continue to lag....The latest rally which begun 3 weeks ago has the S&P up 10% from the February 12th lows...and is now within just a couple of percentage points of going positive for the year, in what some will describe as yet another incredible Fed (and global central bank) pump!We have managed to break thru initial resistance at 1940 - and are now testing the weekly middle Bollinger Band line at 1996 - which is essentially the same level as the 100 dma at 1999. Now yesterday we closed at 1993 - right on the highs of the day, a bit over extended and hitting our heads on what is sure to be significant resistance. .....and today - the gov't will report on Non Farm Payrolls (NFP) - the expectation is for +190k jobs to have been created.....but many are now expecting an upside surprise after Wednesday's ADP surprise. Included in this report will be the Unemployment rate which is expected to remain at 4.9%, the labor participation rate which is expected to inch up to 62.8% and Avg hourly earnings - which are expected to show a 0.2% gain.While the mkt has managed to stage a very impressive countercyclical (bear mkt) rally, on what appears to be improving macro data - we do need to be concerned about what is happening to earnings estimates for the 1st qtr. Bloomberg tells us that forecasts have fallen 9.6% or DOUBLE the average rate. And why should this concern you? Well......if they prove to be correct then that will make 5 qtrs of negative growth......and 5 qtrs of negative growth typically produces a real bear mkt and not one of those swift 6 week affairs like we saw in Jan/Feb but one that is longer and more painful.Income amongst the S&P companies is now expected to decline by 8% this qtr while projections for profit gains have turned to declines for tech and consumer non-durables - bringing the number of industries with no growth to 7 out of 10. Street analysts are now projecting a 1.9% decline in profits for the 1st qtr and that is down from initial expectations of +3.7% growth rate in January....If these forecasts prove true then someone has a lot 'splainin' to do'....And talk about 'splainin - Across the pond in Europe - the talk turns to Eurozone Deflation.....and the last thing that they need is a building recession.....our friends at Credit Suisse made a bold call last week......" if the euro zone were to relapse back into recession it is not clear it would endure.”Essentially - they are suggesting the days may be numbered for the European experiment..... The zone's 19 member states only managed to grow by 0.3% in the 4th qtr of 2015, despite all of the bond purchases initiated by the European Central Bank (ECB) and the benefit of weaker oil prices... and that is AFTER the Eurozone includes drug money and prostitution in their GDP figures...Now many of you are saying "Come ON! Really! - Kenny, you must be mistaken...how could that be?" Well - back in late 2014 - someone suggested that in order to bolster GDP - The EZ could benefit from including 'illegal activities' in their calculation......(incredible right?) and since then the calculation was changed to "include Class A Drug Trade and the provision of prostitution services" and these new components have added about 0.2% to EZ (Eurozone) GDP.( It is surprising that the Democrats have not adopted this same plan to help improve US GDP! - but it is still early in the game....)So now - as we know - the Europeans sit and wait until next week's ECB announcement - as they are expected to launch another round of QE while they force interest rates further into NEGATIVE territory. Now all this talk has helped precious metals....GOLD - trading at $1274/oz is now up 20% off of the December 2015 lows....having broken thru all 3 resistance levels as investors flocked to the safety of this precious metal when talk of NEGATIVE rates turned to reality....Next week will be important all around.... because if the ECB pushes negative interest rates even lower, gold will find even more support and will surely spike higher. If they disappoint and do less than expected then gold would consolidate these recent gains...based on the action - the smart money is betting that they won't be disappointed....Overnight - global mkts appear to be ending the week on a positive note...rallying broadly into the closing bells... There were no material economic reports released and the only news event overnight were comments made by BOJ Governor Kuroda - comments that downplayed the chances for any additional easing at the next Bank of Japan (BOJ) meeting next week. in Asia - Japan +0.32%, Hong Kong +1.1%, China +0.5% and ASX + 0.18%. In Europe mkts are also higher as they await our NFP report at 8:30 am. FTSE + 0.86%, CAC 40 + 0.89%, DAX + 0.91%, EUROSTOXX + 0.76%, SPAIN +0.37% and ITALY -0.47%.US futures are UP 3 pts as they pucker up and get ready to kiss S&P 2000. Psychologically this will be an important event...but if the NFP report is stronger than expected then the talk returns to a rate hike on the table this month (almost impossible) and we could see some profit taking....If the NFP number is surprisingly weak (Unlikely) then talk of lower for longer will be the headline and then look for a real test of resistance. I continue to believe we will remain in the 1940/2000 trading range until after the FED meeting....Take Good Care

Stocks opened to thin losses Wednesday, but the Nasdaq flicked in and out of positive territory.The Dow industrials and S&P 500 eased about 0.1% each, with the Nasdaq moving between fractional gains and losses.Things might have been worse in the stock market today, but a strong February employment report from ADP helped shore up some confidence before the start of trade. Still, the market may be hanging back ahead of the Fed's March Beige Book report, due at 2 p.m. ET. It is the last before the Federal Open Market Committee's March 14-15 meeting, and it could have some impact on afternoon trade.Oil prices stuck to their early losses, with West Texas Intermediate down almost 2% and Brent crude trading 1% lower. The Energy Information Administration reports its weekly inventory data at 10:30 a.m. ET. The weekly inventories estimate from the American Petroleum Institute indicated Tuesday that inventories rose 9.9 million barrels last week, vs. consensus views for a 2.5 million barrel increase.Dow stocks opened generally lower. Apple (AAPL), Pfizer (PFE) and Merck (MRK) crept higher, all with gains of less than 0.3%. DuPont (DD) and Nike (NKE) led the downside, with losses of 0.9% and 2%, respectively.On the S&P 500, Monsanto (MON) tumbled 5% after management guided its Q2 and full-year earnings below consensus expectations. Dollar Tree (DLTR) shed 3% after its fourth-quarter earnings fell more than expected and a 117% revenue gain stopped short of analyst forecasts.Small caps were performing comparatively well as the S&P 600 generated some big moves. CheckPoint Systems (CKP) skipped up 27% on a takeover offer. Darling Ingredients (DAR) spiked 26% after reporting Q4 results Tuesday. American Vanguard (AVD) rocketed 16% higher after its Q4 report late Tuesday.On the Nasdaq 100, Seagate Technology (STX) climbed almost 3%. The hard disk drive manufacturer is almost 30% off a Jan. 28 low but still deep in a 15-month consolidation. Peer Western Digital (WDC) rose 2%.Most IBD 50 stocks lost ground in early trade. Ross Stores (ROST) posted the strongest gain, up nearly 3% following its Q4 results late Tuesday.  The gain put shares more than 3% above 55.74 buy point.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Will it be Hillary? Or will it be The Donald? Perhaps the market doesn't really care. A day after strong results for both presidential candidates during Super Tuesday's primaries, stocks acted as they should during a confirmed market uptrend: Stumbling start. Strong finish. The Nasdaq composite chipped away at a Wednesday morning loss that never topped 0.5% and closed up 0.3%…

It was a SUPER TUESDAY in America.....March came in like a LION as global investors grabbed for anything that wasn't nailed down and......Some would have you believe it was a MAGA (Make America Great Again) rally.....I say - 'not so fast cowboy.....it ain't over until the fat lady sings......'Voters went to the polls to try and cull the Presidential field......Democrats pulling for Hill as she looks to be the anointed leader of that party (although Sanders has not conceded, but should) .....while the GOP is still struggling trying to find their next leader......The Donald would have you believe it is him as he continues to cause earthquakes every time he opens his mouth and now that it looks like he could really snatch it - the calls from the GOP establishment get louder and louder to STOP him.......as the party spins out of control.............. Kasich and Carson barely registered on the Richter scale while Teddy and Marco cause tremors across the nation .....tremors yes, but a real quake - not so much.......but they are not giving up so easy - vowing to take this fight to the convention in what would is known as a 'contested convention'.....the Democrats would LOVE this to happen.....as it just confirms that the GOP is a mess......[A contested convention (or brokered convention) is a situation where no one single candidate has secured the required number of delegates to be the clear front runner - so the process then goes to 'political horse trading' at the summer convention......At the convention - if there still is no clear candidate then all of the delegates are released from their prior pledges and the slate is wiped clean. And the 'brokering' or 'horse trading' begins anew....after a couple of winks, some promises and a handshake - the party chairman calls for a new vote of the delegates. It is then hoped that this will result in a clear winner as a majority of delegates rally around one candidate....The interesting thing here is that a brokered convention does not necessarily reflect the will of the people and could end up being more divisive rather than inclusive - and then we will be saying congratulations to President Rodham- Clinton (again)]And as far as the mkts go - it was a Super Tuesday for stocks as well....Stocks around the world rallied hard.... In the US - all of the indices broke up and thru resistance....and in a vote of confidence - OIL also made history as investors in that asset class took WTI (West Texas Intermediate) up and thru its resistance as well to end the day at $34.44/barrel.....The excitement started early.....Global mkts were on fire after NY FED's Dudley made very dovish comments overnight (Monday evening in NY, Tuesday morning in Asia) in China - concerning US interest rate policy and the PBoC (Peoples Bank of China) announced more stimulus - after a very disappointing manufacturing PMI report - Couple that with expectations of more ECB action as Europeans continue to struggle with what their future looks like......and we got a massive global rally.......Germany’s DAX shot up 2.3%, France’s CAC-40 added 1.2%, and the broader Eurostoxx Index added 1.7%.....Here at home - stocks came out of the gate strong and finished even stronger......The Dow closed up 2.1%, The S&P tacked on 2.4%, Nasdaq rallied 2%, the Russell 2000 +2% ......and so the story continues.....Central banks are at it again.....jawboning to pump up prices— They have spent a great deal of effort in changing the narrative for oil, for stocks, and for the economy - trying to drive up prices for stocks as we enter the final month of the 1st qtr.Now March came in 'like a lion - but will it go out like a lamb' as the saying goes?Overnight the excitement continues.....Japan rallies 4% as news that the Japanese gov't pension fund - (GPIF) - the largest fund in the world with some $1.2 trillion dollars may put some $47 bil to work in the Japanese mkt after the recent beating it took......Other mkts in the region jumped on board for the ride.....Hong Kong rallies 3%, China +4.1% and Australia + 2%. Now Moody's tried to throw cold water on the party by cutting the Chinese country's credit rating outlook to NEGATIVE from stable...but that was not successful at all.... Investors thumbed their nose at Moody's reminding them that they are always late to the party....and that their track record of protecting investors is suspect - think Great Financial Crisis of 2007-2016.....In Europe - mkts there are in rally mode - but not nearly as excited as the rest of the world at the moment...They seem to be in digesting mode after all of the excitement.....as they continue to speculate on the next move by Uncle Mario and the ECB...FTSE -0.34%, CAC 40 + 0.16%, DAX + 0.4%, EUROSTOXX +0.45%, SPAIN +0.8% and ITALY +0.83%This morning - US futures are taking a breather...currently down 4 pts....which is completely understandable...and I would not be surprised to see us back off and test support at the 50 dma....which is now 1940.....We don' t have too, but it would not be a surprise at all, before the next attempt to pierce S&P 2000. Oil is also backing off a bit and has now once again broken thru support - as it is down 0.68 cts...at $33.72/barrel....in what I think is a test to shake out the weakest links before a move higher once again.San Fran Fed's Williams is due to speak today at 10 am est.Eco data today includes ADP employemnt - exp of +190k.....Mortgage Apps came in at minus 4.8% and that makes sense after the pending home sales number on Monday......Fed's Beige Book due at 2 pm.Now with the official results still being counted - it does look like Hillary and Donald took the majority of the delegates last night so the momentum builds. The mkt will now start to pay more attention to the battle as analysts/strategists position themselves for what both a Rodham-Clinton Presidency and Trump Presidency would look like....Will Janet and the FED will fade to black as the investors ponder the political landscape? After yesterday - talk of the pace and timing of rate hikes once again grew louder....but March for all intents and purposes is off the table - June is the next opportunity for any rate hike and then December if at all...so maybe we get 50 bps in 2016, but for sure we will not get 100 bps and maybe that is part of the reason to celebrate......Take Good Care

Productivity at U.S. businesses fell at an annualized rate of 3% in Q4, the Labor Department said, the biggest drop since Q1 2014, as hiring jumped despite stalling output.Economists had forecast a productivity decline of 1.8%, and the fourth quarter's number came in below the most bearish estimate of -2.6%.The third-quarter number was revised downward by 0.1 point to a 2.1% gain. Output rose just 0.1% gain, while hours worked increased 3.3%.United labor costs rose 4.5% during the Oct. 1-to-Dec. 31 period.U.S. productivity rose a meager 0.6% in 2015, the fifth straight year of sub-1% growth. That's been an unfortunate pattern since the Great Recession, as the productivity rate during the economic recovery has been anything but impressive. Weak productivity has contributed to a lack of wage growth and a non-robust economic performance.While the U.S. economy is still adding jobs, it primarily has come via the service sector, which typically has smaller productivity gains. ADP reported the U.S. added roughly 205,000 private-sector payrolls in January, and 192,000 of that total was in the services sector.U.S. manufacturers have been hurt by a strong dollar, weak global demand and a battered energy sector. Caterpillar (CAT) and Dow Chemical (DOW), with the latter currently in the midst of a merger with DuPont (DD), are among the companies who have been trimming staff.Manufacturing productivity fell at a 0.5% pace in Q4, but that followed a 5% gain in Q3.

Job growth slowed much more than expected in January as the economy added just 151,000 jobs, but the report was seemingly strong in all the ways that might keep the Federal Reserve itching to raise interest rates again.Average hourly wages rose 0.5%, the second-biggest monthly gain going all the way back to 2008. Meanwhile, the jobless rate fell to 4.9%, the lowest since February 2008, and the labor force participation rate rose for a third straight month, to 62.7%.A tighter labor market begets higher wage growth and puts upward pressure on inflation. This is what Fed policymakers expect to happen, it's why they raised rates in December, and it's why investors are apparently beginning to fear they could do so again as soon as March -- despite the sharp decline in job gains.That may be one reason why stocks sold off sharply Friday, with the S&P 500 down 1.85% at the closing bell, while the dollar rose against other currencies. The Nasdaq tumbled 3.25%, as grim forecasts from LinkedIn (LNKD) and Tableau (DATA) triggered widespread concern about business spending on software generally.But a closer look at the details of the jobs report suggests more reason to be worried about the economy weakening than to fear another Fed hike. Not only were overall job gains lackluster and lower for a third straight month, but a large portion of those gains are more than a bit puzzling and probably not something to count on going forward.Manufacturers added a surprising 29,000 jobs -- tied for the best gain since early 2012. Yet that reading stands in stark contrast to the Institute for Supply Management manufacturing survey earlier in the week showing factories shedding jobs at the fastest pace since 2009. While not as dismal, ADP reported that factory payrolls were unchanged in January.Meanwhile, the trade deficit widened in December as exports fell for a third straight month, rising 6.9% vs. a year earlier, the Commerce Department said Friday. U.S. manufacturers are struggling as a higher dollar makes it even harder to compete in a sluggish global economy.Then there's the retail sector, which added 57,700 jobs, or 38% of the total gain. The best month of retail hiring in more than three years came even as Wal-Mart (WMT) said it would lay off 10,000 workers and close 154 U.S. stores (though the closings came after the payroll survey week) and as Macy's (M) closed 40 stores and announced 2,500 layoffs.Most of the retail job gains appear to be a statistical quirk related to seasonal adjustment."Department stores, an industry having a difficult time by any measure, increased payrolls by 13,200 -- primarily because they didn't hire as many in the fall to lay off a lot in January," said Steve Blitz, chief economist at ITG Investment Research.Electronics and appliance retailers like Best Buy (BBY) added 8,600 jobs on a seasonally adjusted basis, the best gain in nine years. That doesn't seem to square with reality, as the sector faces brutal competition from Amazon (AMZN). Nor does it square with the picture Best Buy painted when it reported disappointing holiday sales amid weak demand and price cuts for the Apple (AAPL) iPhone 6S and iPad.Seasonally unadjusted data show that electronics retailers added 9,200 fewer workers in November and December compared to a year earlier, then trimmed payrolls by 6,000 fewer in January 2016 vs. January 2015.On the other hand, IHS Global Insight chief economist Nariman Behravesh notes that temp hiring swung from a 25,100 gain in December to a 25,200 drop in January. That's not likely to be repeated either.ITG Investment's Blitz concludes: "Given all this noise and that it is way too soon for current market turmoil to impact real economic activity . . . (we'll have to) wait for February data to begin to get a sense of whether trending demand for labor is shifting."There also is reason — actually 14 of them — to wonder if the 0.5% jump in hourly wages last month really represents a shift in the trend. That's because 14 states raised their minimum wages on January 1, directly affecting 2.8 million workers, according to the liberal Economic Policy Institute. California's $1 hike to $10 an hour was the most consequential.The think tank estimated that the minimum wage hike would lead employers to raise wages for another 1.9 million workers earning close to the new minimum to avoid paying more senior workers the same as less senior ones at the cost of morale.It remains to be seen if the higher minimum wages depress job growth to any extent. Low-wage hiring does appear to have slowed last year in the six cites which implemented big minimum wage hikes to $10 an hour or more last year.Even the strong household survey, which showed that the number of people with jobs surged by 615,000 last month (or 409,000 excluding a population adjustment), probably isn't giving a reliable signal. That's not to say the jobless rate is higher than 4.9%, but only that it can't be counted on to give a reliable estimate of employment gains in any given month. For example, in the third quarter of 2015, the payroll survey showed an increase of 192,000 jobs a month, while the household survey showed a gain of 73,000.A slower pace of hiring was expected after gains averaged 279,000 in the fourth quarter but economic growth slowed to just 0.7%. Economists had expected a gain of about 188,000 jobs in January.The workweek rose 0.1 hour to 34.6 hours, meaning that the increase in work was better than the headline 151,000 job gain. Still, the payroll report offered one more not-so-great sign for the strength of hiring going forward: Outside of manufacturing, 57.6% of industries added jobs last month, down from 65.3% the prior two months.Image provided by Shutterstock.

It also guided 2016 beyond Wall Street expectations. Still, Manhattan Associates stock…

Federal Reserve officials are increasingly uneasy about financial markets since they raised interest rates in December. Meanwhile, U.S. hiring remained solid to start 2016. The service sector continued to expand, but at its slowest pace in nearly two years.Financial conditions have tightened since the Federal Reserve hiked rates for the first time in nearly a decade in December, New York President Bill Dudley told MNI in an interview. That could affect the Fed's decision-making. Further weakening in the global economy and additional dollar appreciation could have "significant consequences" for the economy. The Fed signaled more concern about global markets and less optimism for the U.S. economy at the end of last week's policy meeting.Dudley's comments initially helped lift markets, but stocks soon retreated in morning trade, with the 10-year Treasury yield near a 1-year lowOne reason why the dollar might rise? Other central banks continuing to ease. Bank of Japan Gov. Haruhiko Kuroda said the BoJ has room to ease further after surprising markets late last month by pushing interest rates to -0.1%. Kuroda said there is "no limit" to monetary easing, saying policymakers can "devise new tools."The Institute for Supply Management's nonmanufacturing index fell 2.3 points in January to 53.5. That's the lowest since February 2014, though still above the neutral 50 level. The export orders index signaled the sharpest decline since March 2009, during the last recession. Import orders slid to their weakest since July 2012. The jobs index signaled slower hiring.On Monday, ISM's manufacturing index signaled contraction for a fourth straight month, with the jobs gauge the lowest since May 2009.Markit's services index, similar to the ISM nonmanufacturing gauge, fell 1.1 points to 53.2, the weakest in 27 months.The U.S. economy added more jobs than expected last month, adding 205,400 to private-sector payrolls, the ADP National Employment Report said.Economists had forecast 190,000 jobs added in January, less dramatic than the upwardly revised 266,900 jobs added in December's report.The services sector was the big driver with 192,000 jobs added. The U.S. service sector has remained in growth mode despite grim numbers from U.S. manufacturers, who have been hurt by a strong dollar, weak economic growth overseas and a battered energy sector.Manufacturing jobs fell fractionally vs. December. They dipped 0.1% vs. a year earlier, the worst since September 2010.  Industrial companies such as General Electric (GE) and Caterpillar (CAT) have issued Q4 earnings reports attesting to trouble overseas. Caterpillar and Dow Chemical (DOW) have announced new plans to cut jobs in recent weeks.The Labor Department will release U.S. nonfarm payroll data on Friday.Mortgage applications fell 2.6% during the week of Jan. 29, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Refinancings inched out a 0.3% gain while the purchase index fell 7%. The average 30-year fixed loan for mortgages ($417,000 or less) fell five basis points to 3.97%, its first sub-4% level since October.Image provided by Shutterstock.

The big question for the economy is whether the service sector can keep on trucking, even amid manufacturers' struggles and financial market jitters.The news on Wednesday provided some cause for concern as the Institute for Supply Management's nonmanufacturing index unexpectedly fell 2.3 points in January to a 23-month low of 53.5. Though still above 50, signaling expansion, it was the measure's third straight decline. That follows ISM's manufacturing index out Monday that showed factory activity contracting for a fourth straight month.A 53.5 reading for this closely watched indicator of the service sector's health is historically consistent with GDP growth of 1.8%, the institute said.Of particular concern, the employment index dropped to a 12-month low of 52.1 from 56.3. Yet ADP's monthly employment report out Wednesday showed that private service-sector firms added 192,000 jobs in January, just below the 199,000 average reported by the Labor Department for 2015.Still, that's a step down from the 230,000 private service sector job gains that ADP reported in December, as total private payrolls grew 266,900 vs. a 205,400 gain last month. Manufacturing jobs edged down slightly compared to both December and a year earlier.The Labor Department will release its January employment report on Friday.Meanwhile, another Federal Reserve official signaled unease about events since the central bank raised interest rates in December. Further weakening in the global economy and additional dollar appreciation could have “significant consequences” for the economy, New York Fed President William Dudley told MNI.Online employment postings advertised only 13,500 more jobs in January than in the prior month, the Conference Board said Wednesday. While calling it "a disappointing start for 2016" and highlighting a large drop in postings for sales-related positions, the research group noted that demand remains high, with nearly 5.5 million advertised vacancies.Wal-Mart (WMT) announced 10,000 job cuts in January, part of its plan to close 154 stores in the U.S. Macy's (M) said it would lay off 4,500 while closing as many as 40 stores.Sprint (S) detailed 2,500 job cuts last week, including 2,000 customer-care positions, many of them at call centers. Yahoo (YHOO) announced late Tuesday that it would cut 15% of staff.Staffing firm Robert Half International (RHI) said in an earnings call this week that it ramped up full-time staff in the second half of 2015 and "wouldn't add significantly to headcount during this quarter."The ISM services report's prices paid index fell from 51.0 down to 46.4, the lowest since July 2009. One of the survey respondents noted that "falling prices are pushing margins down as many are forced to drop prices to meet the competition."The ISM survey also highlighted the service sector's exposure to the weak global economy as the export orders gauge sank to a nearly seven-year low of 45.5 from 53.5 the prior month.
