Have employers cut work hours to avoid ObamaCare penalties? There's no clearer test than the one put forth by the White House Council of Economic Advisers.The Affordable Care Act employer mandate applies to workers who clock at least 30 hours per week. So if companies were seeking to minimize liability, we'd likely see a drop in the number of workers with hours just above that threshold relative to the number with hours just below it.The White House test, as amended in early 2014: "Compute the ratio of persons working 31-34 hours per week to persons working 25-29 hours per week."30-Hour Dividing LineThe results, seen in the accompanying chart, are striking. After leveling off for a couple of years as the economy recovered from recession, the ratio began a sharp and sudden dive in 2013. In June of this year, there were 191,000 fewer workers with usual work schedules of 31 to 34 hours in their main jobs than at the end of 2012, a drop of 8%. Meanwhile, an additional 406,000 people usually worked 25 to 29 hours, up 12%. These figures average 12 months of data because the U.S. Census' Current Population Survey (CPS) data are volatile from month to month.The divergent shifts on either side of the 30-hour divide coincide almost perfectly with the initial measurement period for ObamaCare employer penalties that began in 2013. Potential liability is determined a year before the penalties are actually imposed, so employers began responding in a pretty big way in early 2013.While the data show that the shift away from a 31- to 34-hour workweek became obvious in the final quarter of 2013, the data are consistent with employers adjusting work hours months earlier. That's not only because it takes some time for employers to implement such changes but also because census interviewers ask people to give their most frequent schedule over the past four or five months.The timing also matches the surge in anecdotal reports of employers cutting work hours, which IBD collected in a database that grew to 450 employers.The timing also matches up well with the relapse in the average workweek in low-wage industries. That's evident in the other chart based on Bureau of Labor Statistics data from the monthly establishment survey.As noted above, the White House economists tweaked their test of ObamaCare's impact. Initially, they had counted the 5 million or so people reported by the census to be working exactly 30 hours a week as full-time under ObamaCare. Once IBD brought it to their attention that the census rounds up, counting 30 minutes or more as a full hour, the White House acknowledged that including those workers "may be misleading."New Studies Claim No ObamaCare Jobs ImpactThat rounding problem is all the reason needed to dismiss one of three new studies casting doubt on ObamaCare's impact on work hours. The authors of an Urban Institute study treat all 5 million 30-hour workers as full time, rendering their analysis unreliable.Indeed, there were numerous reports of employers cutting workers to 29.5 or even 29.75 hours. Economists have noted that workers with their hours closest to 30 are most likely to have their schedules trimmed. Not only is it less disruptive to worker morale to lose a half hour of work, as opposed to 3 or 4 hours, but the penalty is greatest per hour of work for those working exactly 30 hours.For companies that provide coverage to most workers over 30 hours, that penalty equals $3,120 per uncovered full-timer in 2015. Remember that the penalty is paid after taxes. Converted to the equivalent in tax-deductible wages, the fine is equal to about $5,120 in wages for a company facing the average combined federal and state tax rate of 39.1%.Now it's fair to say that as employment has picked up and the jobless rate has come down, companies have likely become somewhat less concerned about ObamaCare penalties and more concerned about finding and hanging onto good workers. But as the penalty grows from year to year (along with the growth of the average national health insurance premium), so too may its bite, particularly as the economic cycle begins to turn.The Secret Of TimingTiming, in other words, matters a lot, and timing may be the biggest problem with the other two studies. One study from Aparna Mathur and Michael Strain of the American Enterprise Institute and Sita Slavov of George Mason University compares work hours before ObamaCare's passage (from January 2008 to February 2010) to work hours after (from March 2010 to July 2014).Thus, the "after" includes nearly three full years before the earliest measurement period for ObamaCare penalties was set to begin, during which time the Supreme Court was set to decide whether the individual mandate was kosher and President Obama had to face re-election.Asked whether it would have made more sense to focus on the period starting in 2013, Strain responded: "I don't agree that it would have made more sense, but I do agree that this would be an interesting question to study."Strain and his colleagues did find a shift from above 30 hours to below, but the shift wasn't more pronounced in lower-wage service industries likely to feel the brunt of the mandate, so the authors concluded that the mandate didn't have an effect.One shortcoming of the methodology is that it looked at employment by industry, not occupation. Yet school districts, local governments and colleges account for the bulk of IBD's database of hour-cutters. The fact that bus drivers, cafeteria workers and paraprofessionals lost hours in a high-paying industry actually helps generate the study's conclusion that ObamaCare hasn't had an impact.Other data also appear to contradict their finding that service-sector workers aren't bearing the brunt of short shifts and lack of full-time jobs. Researchers from the Atlanta Federal Reserve noted earlier this year that the share of workers stuck in part-time jobs was nearly back to normal in production industries but the recovery had barely dented the share of people working part time for economic reasons in general service industries.Timing is also a main flaw of a third study from human resources service provider ADP, which compared work hours in the third quarter of 2013 to the fourth quarter of 2014. The study missed out on the substantial shift that was already well advanced when the Obama administration, at the start of July 2013, pushed back the mandate penalty until 2015. The White House subsequently delayed the penalty for companies with fewer than 100 full-time equivalent workers until 2016.Lastly, it's not clear how well the ADP study adjusts for seasonal factors, since retail and hospitality-sector workers tend to work longer hours in the fourth quarter. It's hard to conclude much from studying a quarter's worth of data, especially the fourth quarter.

Stock futures cut sharply lower ahead of Wednesday's open, as global markets reacted for a second day to currency policy decisions made in China.
Dow futures bobbed between losses of 100 and 126 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures hung 34.5 points in the red. S&P 500 futures were off 14.8 points.

The stock market today once again opens with eyes toward China, where the currency slipped nearly 2% for a second straight day as the central bank holds to its new policy of letting the yuan adjust according to market forces.

The two-day contraction raises questions over how much adjustment is in store and what the impact of the currency shift will be on China's domestic demand as imported goods suddenly become more expensive. The currency shift also clouds the view into a possible Federal Reserve rate hike in the U.S.

Global markets showed their dread of uncertainty, with Europe's leading indexes down hard near midday, led by 2.2% declines each for the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris. In China, Hong Kong's Hang Seng dropped 2.4%. The Shanghai Composite shed 1.1%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 fell 1.6%.

The fears spread to the U.S. premarket session, though losses were moderating on the approach to the opening bell. Still, Apple (AAPL) was down more than 1% after diving over 5% on Tuesday. Alcoa (AA) was down more than 1%, but Caterpillar (CAT), Exxon Mobil (XOM) and General Electric (GE) trimmed losses to less than 1% over the prior hour.
Against that backdrop, earnings reports continued to roll out.
Watch maker Fossil (FOSL) tanked 9% after reporting weak Q2 revenue and Q3 guidance. Internet retailer Wayfair (W) surged 11% after trampling analysts' Q2 earnings and revenue expectations.
China's Alibaba (BABA) swooned 6% ahead of the opening bell after earnings narrowly beat and a 28% revenue gain stopped short of analyst consensus views.

Gross merchandise volume — a measure of the goods sold through all of Alibaba's online channels — rose at its slowest rate in three years, up 34% to $105 billion. Management also launched a two-year, $4 billion share buyback program. Alibaba ended Tuesday 36% below a November high and 13% above its September IPO price.
CDK Global (CDK) punched up 9%, apparently on news reports that the company is exploring the possibility of a sale to private equity groups.

Bloomberg reported that the provider of software to auto dealerships and manufacturers, spun off last year from Automatic Data Processing (ADP), was working with Morgan Stanley. Neither CDK nor Morgan Stanley commented.

Sachem Head Capital Management and Elliott Management are among CDK's largest shareholders. The stock ended Tuesday in a test of support at its 200-day moving average, 16% below its June high and up more than 56% from its October IPO.

In economic news, New York Federal Reserve chief William Dudley was scheduled to speak at 8:30 a.m. ET. The Labor Department reports its Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey at 10 a.m. and the Energy Information Administration releases its weekly petroleum status report at 10:30.

The dollar dipped vs. the euro and the yen. The 10-year yield dropped 4 basis points to 2.10%. Commodities were generally higher. Oil bounced 1%, but not nearly enough to lift West Texas Intermediate back to $44 a barrel. Gold added 1% to $1,117 an ounce. Private hiring eased up in July, processor ADP said. Employers added 185,000 jobs, well below the expected 210,000 and the 2015 average of 200,000. Job gains were evenly distributed across small, mid-sized and large companies, and the service sector saw nearly all the hiring. But construction jobs did tick up by 15,000. That's the smallest gain in 15 months, but…

Major averages took it on the chin Thursday as media stocks and several leading growth stocks sold off. The Nasdaq pierced its 50-day moving average, falling 1.6%, while the S&P 500 closed just above its 200-day moving average, ending with a loss of 0.8%. The Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.7%.

Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq coming in higher than Wednesday's levels.Declining stocks outnumbered advancers on the Nasdaq by more than 2-to-1. The ratio was less than 2-to-1 on the NYSE.Oil and gas stocks outperformed while security software and biotech stocks lagged.In the stock market today, long-time leader Palo Alto Networks (PANW) gave up its 50-day moving average in heavy volume, falling 8%.Meanwhile, a trio of media names got slammed after disappointing earnings reports. Viacom (VIAB) crashed 14% after earnings missed expectations. Shares of 21st Century Fox (FOXA) slipped 6%, but ended well off session lows, on on sluggish fiscal Q4 results. Small-cap media name Gray Television (GTN) tumbled 8% after trimming losses. It fell close to its 200-day moving average despite a solid earnings beat.Fitbit (FIT) and Tesla (TSLA) were other earnings casualties.Earnings bright spots included FleetCor (FLT) and Sucampo Pharmaceuticals (SCMP).Sucampo has been volatile after a recent breakout over a 22.10 buy point. On Wednesday, the company reported its third straight quarter of triple-digit earnings growth.The earnings parade continues after the close today with reports due from the likes of Arista Networks (ANET), Fleetmatics (FLTX) and Monster Beverage (MNST).In IPO news, Planet Fitness (PLNT) priced last night at 16 and opened at 14.50. Shares closed at 16.02 after hitting an intraday low of 13.75.On Friday, all eyes will be on the monthly job report. Economists expect July nonfarm payrolls to rise 212,000, with the unemployment rate holding steady at 5.3%. On Wednesday, ADP said the private sector added 185,000 jobs in July, below expectations.

The Nasdaq enjoyed a much-needed accumulation day Wednesday, but action was quieter in the rest of the market. The Nasdaq added 0.7% and the S&P 500 picked up 0.3%. The Dow Jones industrial fell less than 0.1%, hurt by weakness in Walt Disney (DIS), which plunged 9% on disappointing earnings.

Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq coming in higher than Tuesday's levels in the stock market today.Winners and losers were evenly split on the NYSE. Nasdaq breadth was better as winners topped losers by less than 2-to-1.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, benchmark crude oil lost 59 cents, or 1.4%, to $45.15 a barrel — its lowest close since March.Big gainers in the Nasdaq 100 included Cognizant (CTSH), Priceline (PCLN), Netflix (NFLX) and Facebook (FB).IBD 50 name Paycom Software (PAYC) was a huge gainer thanks to strong earnings. Paycom gapped above its 50-day moving average, ending with a gain of 19%.Another IBD 50 stock, Heritage Insurance (HRTG), outperformed ahead of its earnings report after the close. Shares rose 2.5%. It's getting support at its 10-week moving average for the first time after a cup-with-handle breakout in late June over 22.74.Fitbit (FIT) continued its ascent ahead of earnings after the close. Shares rose another 4% in the regular session and were volatile after the earnings announcement. Fitbit beat Q2 expectations.In economic news, Wall Street shrugged of disappointing data from ADP that showed private employers adding 185,000 jobs in July, down from 229,000 in June, and below the consensus estimate of 210,000.The government will release its official jobs report for July on Friday. Nonfarm payrolls are seen rising 212,000 with the unemployment rate holding steady at 5.3%.

Stocks pared gains Wednesday afternoon as Disney (DIS) fell sharply and mixed economic data spurred uncertainty over interest rates. The Nasdaq was up 0.7%, the S&P 500 climbed 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%. All were off session highs. Volume in the stock market today was running well above Tuesday's levels on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq.

Media stocks were among the hardest hit. Disney dropped 9%, weighing on the Dow, after reporting late Tuesday that revenue rose 5% in the latest quarter to $13.1 billion, below Wall Street estimates. The stock sliced through its 50-day moving average and fell as much as 3% below a 113.40 buy point of a flat base. Volume was the highest in at least a year, suggesting heavy institutional selling.
Discovery Communications (DISCA) was down 9%, hitting its lowest levels since February, after the cable operator also reported weaker-than-expected Q2 revenue.

On the upside, Mexican restaurant chain Chuy's Holdings (CHUY) soared more than 24% to a 52-week high after reporting that Q2 profit jumped 52% to 32 cents a share, accelerating for the second straight quarter and easily beating analysts' forecasts. Sales rose 19% to $75.4 million, also above views.
Volume was heavy as the stock retook a 28.14 buy point of a flat base.

In the IBD 50, Paycom Software (PAYC) popped 17%, retaking its 50-day line, after the provider of cloud-based personnel management software posted strong Q2 results late Tuesday. The stock had recently triggered a sell signal by falling more than 8% below a 35.96 buy point.

In economic news, payroll processor ADP said private employers added 185,000 jobs in July, below Econoday's estimate of 210,000 jobs. Stocks rose initially on sentiment that weak data may keep the central bank from raising interest rates. However, the Institute for Supply Management's index of service sector activity came in much stronger than expected last month, jumping 4.3 points to 60.3. Readings above 50 indicate expansion.Stocks pared gains Wednesday afternoon as Disney (DIS) fell sharply and mixed economic data spurred uncertainty over interest rates. The Nasdaq was up 0.7%, the S&P 500 climbed 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%. All were off session highs. Volume in the stock market today was running well above Tuesday's levels on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq.Media stocks were among the hardest hit. Disney dropped 9%, weighing on the Dow, after reporting late Tuesday that revenue rose 5% in the latest quarter to $13.1 billion, below Wall Street estimates. The stock sliced through its 50-day moving average and fell as much as 3% below a 113.40 buy point of a flat base. Will tonight's FOX Presidential debate be more like "All in The Family" or "The West Wing"?

For the entertainment factor alone - millions of households (both at home and abroad) will be tuned in to the 9 p.m. ET Varsity Presidential Debate - featuring the likes of 'The Donald', Governor (FL) John Ellis Bush (JEB), Governor (WI) Scotty Walker, Governor (AK) Mike Huckabee (really?), Neurosurgeon Ben Carson, Senator (TX) Teddy Cruz (?), Senator (FL) Marco Rubio, Senator (KY) Rand Paul (?), The always outspoken, roll up your sleeves and get in your face NJ Governor Chris Christie, and the sleeping giant - Ohio Governor - John Kasich.

The other 7 candidates have been relegated to the JV team and will appear at 5 p.m. in what Carly Fiorina has dubbed - "The Happy Hour Debate"! How happy is Lindsay Graham? He actually lobbied for his position to be on the JV team......
So - if nothing else - it is sure to be a bit entertaining and will provide so much fodder for the late night talk shows and of course the perennial favorite - SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE.

No matter what happens tonight - the field has to start to consolidate if the GOP has any chance at all of delivering a message to American voters. Currently - with 17 candidates running - the GOP appears fractured and fragmented and the message is getting lost in the antics provided cost free (because he doesn't need any money - as he has told us over and over) by none other than The Donald. The big question - how many minutes into the debate before The Donald's head explodes?

Look - don't expect too much tonight - with only 2 hours and 10 candidates - there will not be a lot of substance to the debate - How could any one of them possibly really state their case for why they should be the POTUS (Pres. of the United States)? And just how will 3 moderators - Chris Wallace, Brett Baier and Megyn Kelly really be able to control the crowd without it looking like a sitcom? So sit back, get the popcorn and enjoy the show. Nothing that happens tonight will have any effect on the broader market or investor/trader mentality.

Stocks spiked sharply higher yesterday morning but then lost some ground as investors/traders digested another mixed batch of economic news (ADP) and earnings (Walt Disney (DIS) - the standout disappointment). This then caused 'renewed' speculation about WWTFDN (What will the Fed do NOW?) - causing so many to suggest that they won't do anything in September......So the indexes wallowed back and forth falling from their highs of the day - but not collapsing at all.

Given all the chatter from the Fed and their 'representatives' about raising interest rates, yesterday's ADP private payroll report - stunned them.....(So much for that improving labor market) - Job growth was a big disappointment at 185K vs. expectations of 215K, and last month - revised lower, So traders immediately took this as a sign that this weak jobs report might cause the Fed to hesitate.

Then we got the Disney earnings - and guess what - not so good.....they reported another big miss on their TV networks and amusement park revenues - the stock plunged 9% taking the DOW index with it. Talk of a slowing economy once again takes the spotlight (Yawn)....... Now - it may not be a good sign that the Disney theme parks underperformed - but I have to ask - Have YOU been to one lately?

For a family of 4 you have to fly to FL (or CA), - and at today's airfares that will run you $3000, pay $940 just for the 3-day pass (or upgrade for another $40 each to get what exactly?), or you could get the VIP guided tour for a mere $500/hour if you so choose, get a hotel room for $500/night or $1500 plus tax, buy breakfast, lunch and dinner at ridiculous prices - $15 eggs, $8 cokes and $10 frozen meat patties (I refuse to call them burgers) - and then be subjected to standing in long lines waiting to get on a 3 minute ride while the kids are screaming, crying, fighting, ....so after it's all said and done - this family has spent a minimum of $7k or $8k - but probably closer to $10k or $12k after you buy all the Disney 'stuff' for 3 days and have they really had a good time? (I mean be honest here).

How many times can you take a picture with Minnie Mouse , Cinderella or Jasmine? So it may not be a good sign for Disney but I am not sure that it means the economy is slowing or worsening - I think it means that people don't want that kind of vacation. I think the mindset is changing a bit.....I think families want a different experience - and with a stronger dollar - taking your family to Europe is more of a option............So I think the vacation dollars are just being spent more wisely. Again - maybe not so good for Disney - but it is good for families.

From a technical perspective - market breadth still looks a bit weak and lower oil prices aren't helping the action. the Dow continues to trade below long-term support and we are only days away from the feared 'Death Cross' - where the Dow's down-trending 50-day moving average crosses the up trending 200-dma - a technical sign of more difficult times ahead - but remember - do not overemphasize this....the Dow is only 30 names....the one to watch for is the S&P 500 and that is nowhere near as ominous....in fact - the broader market is holding up well and is closer to all time highs than not. Yesterday - it managed to trade back above short-term supports at 2094 to close higher at 2099. This morning - Futures are flat as the market awaits tomorrows NFP report. I suspect that the market will find support right in here at the 2085/2090 range.....- volumes to remain muted as we await tomorrow's report.

In Europe this morning - The BoE voted to hold rates steady - after they cut their near-term forecast for inflation - due to lower energy prices and a strengthening pound. This means they are keeping rates at 'record lows' for the time being....In Germany - manufacturing orders showed a strong increase at 2% vs. exp of 0.7%....Stocks had no real reaction - with markets currently mixed ... insignificant really. FTSE -0.11%, CAC 40 +0.11%, DAX +0.06%, Eurostoxx +0.09%, Spain -0.09% and Italy -0.13% - Greece catching a bit of a bounce after 3 days of slaughter - currently +0.03%
Take good care.
Kp

And as promised - the night was full of one liners, assaults on Obama and Hillary (not unexpected), praises, thoughtful and heartfelt responses - all of which added up to a…
Major averages edged lower Tuesday in a mostly quiet session.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq eased 0.2% each. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in very close to Monday's levels.
Declining stocks only had a slight edge over advancers on both exchanges in the stock market today. The Nasdaq's advance/decline line has been in a downtrend since late June.

Among the day's gainers, Regeneron (REGN) had a good day, up 5%, on better-than-expected Q2 earnings. The company reported a profit of $2.89 a share on sales of $999 million. Views were for $2.77 a share on revenue of $887.81 million. Regeneron also raised its growth forecast for its flagship drug Eylea, a popular treatment for age-related wet macular degeneration. The stock cleared a 544.10 buy point from a late-stage flat base last month.

Martin Marietta (MLM) reversed higher after early weakness as shares gained nearly 6%. The producer of stone, sand and other aggregates delivered earnings of $1.22 a share, down 10% from a year ago, on sales of $921.4 million. Views were for $1.61 a share on revenue of $924.16 million.

Meanwhile, institutional investors continued to sell shares of Apple (AAPL). The stock lost another 3% in huge volume after giving up its 200-day moving average Monday over concerns about slowing iPhone sales in China.
Apple suppliers were also hit hard, including Skyworks (SWKS), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) and Qorvo (QRVO). Losses for all three ranged from 3% to 4%.
On Wednesday before the open, watch for earnings from Priceline Group (PCLN) and Sucampo Pharmaceuticals (SCMP). Fitbit (FIT) and Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) report after the close.

Economic data due Wednesday include the ADP jobs report, which measures the change in U.S. nonfarm private sector employment. The consensus estimate calls for job growth of 210,000. The data come ahead of Friday's government jobs report.Major averages edged lower Tuesday in a mostly quiet session.The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq eased 0.2% each. Losses for all three ranged from 3% to 4%.On Wednesday before the open, watch for earnings from Priceline Group (PCLN) and Sucampo Pharmaceuticals (SCMP). Fitbit (FIT) and Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) report after the close.Economic data due Wednesday include the ADP jobs report, which measures the change in U.S. nonfarm private sector employment. The consensus estimate calls for job growth of 210,000. The data come ahead of Friday's government jobs report.
Private hiring down

Private payrolls increased by 185,000 in July, processor ADP said. That badly missed expectations for 210,000 and suggests the gov't payroll report due Fri. may also be a disappointment. Services made up almost all the gains; construction added 15,000 jobs and manufacturing 2,000.
Service sector activity soars

ISM's nonmanufacturing PMI surged 4.3 points to 60.3 in July — a 10-year high. New orders were at a sizzling 63.8, up 5.5 points from June. Employment rose to 59.6, also the highest since '05. Respondents were upbeat, ranging from 1 who expects 15% annual growth to another who described growth as manageable.
Trade balance widens

The trade gap was $43.8 bil in June, close to the $43 bil expected. May's $41.9 bil deficit was whittled to $40.9 in a revision. Imports rose 1.2%, largely on petroleum, while exports ticked down 0.1%.

 Markit's service sector PMI rose nearly a point to 55.7 in July, reflecting the fastest rise in new work in 3 months. Hiring was "robust," the group said, but business confidence fell to a low not seen since '12.

 Small-business borrowing surged to a record high in June, according to the Thomson Reuters/PayNet Small Business Lending Index. It touched 143.3, up from 131 in May and the highest in the index's 10-year history. PayNet says the index foreshadows gains in GDP and capital spending by 2-5 months.
Powell: liftoff not yet set

Federal Reserve Gov. Jerome Powell, a policy voter, told CNBC he is not committed to hiking rates in Sept. While the labor market continues to be strong, he said, there's "more slack in the economy than the 5.3% (unemployment rate) would suggest" and inflation is far from the central bank's target.

 Mortgage applications leapt 4.7% in the July 31 week, the Mortgage Bankers Assn. said. Its purchase index rose 3% and was up 23% vs. a year ago while refinancing applications were up 6% as rates dropped 4 bps.
Eurozone retail sales soften
Sales dropped 0.6% in June, defying forecasts of a 0.1% gain, and the yearly increase eased to 1.2% from 2.6%. Nonfood items declined only 0.2%.
Eurozone composite PMI ticks down
Markit's final read for July eased to 53.9 from 54.2, thanks largely to softening activity in Italy and France. Germany remained strong. New business, hiring and outstanding orders rose.

 Canada's trade balance shrank to 0.48 bil CAD in June, down from 3.37 bil CAD in May. Imports dipped 0.6%, but remained 4.4% higher than year-ago levels while exports surged 6.3%. Exports were 1% lower for the year.

 China's composite PMI eased in July, according to the Caixin-Markit index. It fell to 50.2 from 50.6, the weakest in more than a year. But service sector new orders accelerated and employment picked up.
 Japan's service sector expanded at the fastest rate since May '13, according to the Nikkei-Markit PMI. The index was 51.2 in July, down a touch from 51.8 in June.
COMING UP THURSDAY
 Jobless claims for the Aug. 1 week, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: 273,000).
FRIDAY
 Employment situation for July, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: 212,000 jobs, 5.3% jobless rate).

 Jobless claims for the Aug. 1 week, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: 273,000).
FRIDAY
 Employment situation for July, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: 212,000 jobs, 5.3% jobless rate). Employment situation for July, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: 212,000 jobs, 5.3% jobless rate).
Small business hiring edges up
The Paychex-IHS Small Business Jobs Index rose to 100.64 in July from 100.63. That's down .46% from a year earlier. Washington was the strongest state, and Dallas was the strongest metro area.
Factory orders increase

Orders rose 1.8% in June, a bit stronger than the 1.7% expected, and up from a downwardly revised 1.1% decline in June. Orders are 5.9% lower vs. a year ago. Shipments increased 0.5%. The inventory-shipment ratio was 1.35, unchanged during the month.

 Americans turned sharply less confident in July, according to Gallup's economic confidence index, which sank to -12 from -8. That's the lowest since Aug. '14. Only 39% said the economy was getting better; 56% said it was getting worse.
Home prices jump

Prices rose 1.7% in June, CoreLogic said, for a 6.5% yearly jump. There were new price peaks for 15 states and D.C. in June. Sales excluding distressed properties rose 6.4% vs. a year ago. The group expects a 4.5% yearly gain from June '15 to '16.
 Same-store sales accelerated in the Aug. 1 week, Redbook said. Its measure hit a 1.7% annual rate, up from 1.0%.
OECD: global inflation still low

Inflation was below target in most developed nations, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said. It averaged an annual rate of 0.6% in June, well below the 2% desired by most central banks.
Eurozone producer prices sink
Prices fell 0.1% in June, the first monthly decline since Jan., and the yearly decline worsened to -2.2% from -2%. That's a setback for the central bank's goal of about 2% inflation.

 U.K. home prices picked up in July, as Nationwide's index rose 0.4%, up from a 0.2% decline in June. The yearly increase was 3.5%, up from 3.3% in the prior month. Demand is strong and supply light, Nationwide said.
COMING UP WEDNESDAY
 ADP Employment report for July, 8:15 a.m. ET (forecast: 210,000 private jobs).
 Int'l trade for June, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: -$43.0 bil).
 ISM nonmanufacturing for July, 10 a.m. ET (forecast: 56.2).

It's noise….Do not get dragged in by the weakness in Apple — Apple is not the US economy — yes it's a big name and yes it plays a starring role in the economy (but is not the economy), yes, it is one of the main attractions in the indexes, and yes there is this a mania about it, and yes — its recent move off the highs makes for a great headline — but let's not get all 'Chinese' about it.

The recent sell off in Apple is the recent sell off in Apple — no matter how many analysts try to tie it into every tick in the mkt. Recall that during the Oct 2012/April 2013— the mkt rallied 11% yet while Apple dropped 45%...Where was the 'hysteria' then? How come these same analysts weren't jumping up and down about the damage a selloff in Apple would create? In fact — for the savvy investor — a buyer of Apple then would have yielded a 120% return as of last night……Not so shabby….

FLASHBACK — recall the Dutch Tulip Bulb Craze in 1593 — Tulips from Turkey were introduced to the Dutch — The novelty of this new flower created demand among the people, a virus known as 'Mosaic' caused a change in the color patterns and the petals appeared to be on fire — demand grew and prices started to rise…Everyone became a speculator in Tulip bulbs — people were giving up their land and putting their life savings into tulip bulbs — thinking the party would never end, that only the sky was the limit…..they created a bit of a 'bubble'……While some of the 'smart money' took profits and money off the table it caused prices to begin to fall buyers backed away, sellers got nervous — selling beget more selling which put more pressure on prices, buyers stepped back, sellers panicked and then you had the 'capitulation' — panic and pandemonium ensued, the gov't attempted to stop the bleed — unsuccessfully — and no one emerged from this mania unscathed…..

Ok— work with me here…....Ipods first introduced by Apple to the world created demand, then newer products that changed the look and feel of the Apple products creating new and more demand — much like the 'Mosaic virus' changed the appearance of the Tulip — mania sets in — investors margin 'the house' — everyone is telling you a story about how they bought Apple (thus how smart they were) they can't get enough — the stock had an amazing run — there are parties in the street……how could this party ever end? There will never be another down day on Wall St! I mean it's APPLE! Are you following me here? Does the 'housing crisis' ring a bell with anyone? All I am saying is — don't get dragged down the road about Armageddon just because investors are re-pricing the risk in Apple as they wonder what the next 'new product' will be….what's happening in Apple is reflective of a mkt at work — Remember — there are always two sides to a trade — both a buyer and seller and it appears that the buyers are in control at the moment as the sellers become 'anxious'. Econ 101 — Supply and Demand.

So back to the present — the mkt ended the day just a bit lower — commodity prices did manage to stabilize, giving some early support to the mkt — and then we got Dennis Lockhart — Atlanta Fed President — to take to the podium and said that
"The economy is in a state of readiness for beginning normalization" and that a rate rise was "imminent" and that there "was a high bar right now for not acting"

— Yields spike, the dollar surges and stocks took it on the chin…..Can I ask — when will this stop? The Fed should just stop teasing the mkts and just strap in and make 'the move' — a 25 bps move in rates will do nothing to the economy as rates will still be artificially low — bond investors will adjust and the sense that the first move will presage further moves in rates is ACTUALLY correct — does anyone think that rates will never move again? I mean HELLO? The Fed has to start somewhere, rates need to normalize, global investors need to wake up and smell the coffee. Does anyone think that this 'party' will never end? (Think housing crisis, tulip bulbs, China and Apple…..) As the Nike says— "Just Do It"!

Overnight in Asia stocks continue to be mixed….Positive macro data out of China failed to help lift that boat — The Caixin/Markit PMI rose to 53.8 — the highest level in a year and the 12th straight month of expansion…. That is in contrast to Monday's disastrous PMI reading so it only adds to investor confusion. Most mkts just treading water as they await more US macro eco data today and Friday. Japan +0.46%, Hong Kong +0.44%, China -1.65% and ASX -0.42%.

European mkts are all higher in early morning trading — investors there seemingly unfazed by the Dennis Lockhart comments and now expect that the US will be the first major economy to raise rates. Fear over continued Greek economic crisis seemingly subsided — though Greece and their banks continue to suffer. Eurozone composite PMI beat expectations at 53.9 indicating that the 'recovery' is alive and well. FTSE + 0.18%, CAC 40 + 0.76%, DAX + 0.96% EUROSTOXX +0.75%, SPAIN 0.53%, ITALY +0.69% and GREECE -3.76%.

US futures are +6.5 pts in early trade suggesting that investors/traders are expecting today's macro data to offer up NO surprises. ADP employment data is due out at 8:30 - 215k jobs is expected and as usual this report is just the warm up act for Friday's NFP report —the street expects +225k jobs to be created.
Today will also bring us Non Manf ISM — exp of 57. Earnings include TWX, PCLN, RL, WEN, Kate Spade and the HFT Firm (disguised as a mkt maker/liquidity provider) — Virtu Financial.

On a side note did you see the story yesterday about AQR's head of trading on paid leave amid a probe? Here is the link. And just to make the point — these are some of the guys that are leading the discussion about what the future of the US capital mkts should be — no wonder real asset managers continue to look for ways to eliminate the noise and trade amongst themselves in an attempt to shield themselves from the potential abuse in the 'dark pools'. Anyone listening?
Take good care.
Kp

Incomes rise, spending dips Personal incomes were up 0.4% in June, a tick below the 0.5% notched in May but better than the 0.3% expected. A 0.2% gain in consumer spending was right in line with expectations for a pullback from a hefty 0.9% gain in May. The Fed's favored inflation meter accelerated to a 1.3% yearly gain from 1.2%.…

As the sun makes it way around the world - it sheds light on so many concerns... In Asia - stocks tumbled on disappointing Chinese manufacturing data - The Caixin China PMI (Purchasing Manufacturing index) for July was a disappointing 47.8 - lower than the expectation of 48.2 and below the 'official' government figure of 50 released over the weekend.....(recall…

U.S. stocks held on to modest gains, but were off session highs in late afternoon trading after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras urged Greeks to reject a bailout deal. A referendum Sunday could decide the country's future in the eurozone.

An early 1% gain for the Nasdaq faded to 0.3%. The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5% and the S&P 500 rose 0.4%. Volume on both exchanges was tracking slightly lower than Tuesday's levels in the stock market today.

In M&A news, a big deal in the insurance space made headlines Wednesday whenAce (ACE) announced plans to buy Chubb (CB) in a $28 billion deal. Ace was mostly unchanged after surging 9% early. Chubb soared 27%.
Among growth stocks, Acadia Healthcare (ACHC) padded gains after a recent breakout over a 74.19 buy point. Shares rose more than 1% in above-average volume. It's now 7% past the buy point.
Elsewhere, Leaderboard name Acuity Brands (AYI) jumped nearly 4% after reporting strong earnings before the open.
Ten out of 15 Leaderboard names were outperforming the broad market Wednesday.
IBD 50 name Heritage Insurance (HRTG) added to gains after a recent cup-with-handle breakout over 22.74. Shares jumped 4.5%.
Criteo (CRTO), Santander Consumer USA (SC) and Epam Systems (EPAM) were the top percentage gainers in the IBD 50.

In economic news, manufacturing strengthened in June, according to the latest ISM reading. Meanwhile, payroll processor ADP noted private employers added 237,0000 jobs in June. This comes ahead of Thursday's jobs report, which will be released one day early due to the Fourth of July holiday. Economists expect nonfarm payrolls to rise by 230,000, with the unemployment rate ticking lower to 5.4%.

Manufacturing strengthensISM's closely watched factory PMI was stronger than expected in June, at 53.5. That was up 0.7 point from May and the strongest since Jan. Employment surged to 55.5, up nearly 4 points, and new orders were a robust 56.0. But export orders dipped below the neutral 50 line as the dollar continues to weigh.Private payrolls jumpPrivate employers added 237,000 jobs in June, processor ADP said, up sharply from its 203,000 reading in May and also beating estimates. ADP has a mixed record of predicting the government's employment report that follows: Labor said employers added 280,000 jobs in May. Markit's manufacturing PMI dipped to 53.6 in June from 54.0 in May, the lowest since Oct. '13. The dollar continued to weigh as new export orders dropped for the third straight month, the longest such stretch since '12. Construction spending rose 0.8% in May, stronger than the 0.5% expected, though down from a 2.1% monthly gain in April.Planned job cuts surgeEmployers announced 44,842 cuts in June, said Challenger, Gray and Christmas, up 9.3% vs. May and capping the highest midyear total in 5 years. The 287,762 cuts in '15 are up 17% from '14. But many of the cuts were due to weakness in the oil patch, which is likely in the rearview mirror. Mortgage applications fell 4.7% in the Mortgage Bankers Assn.'s June 26 index. Purchases were down 4% and refinancings sank 5% as the average interest rate rose 5 bps. A jobs index from Gallup rose in June to the highest since '12. The Payroll to Population survey touched 45.5, up a full point, the strongest monthly gain in a year.Did Greece blink?PM Alexis Tsipras sent a letter to international creditors agreeing to accept most of the demands in the last offer they had drafted. But his counterproposal differed enough that creditors — and markets — remained skeptical. All eyes are on the ECB, which must decide whether to keep extending emergency liquidity to Greek banks, which are closed all week, following a skipped payment to the IMF Tues. The June eurozone factory PMI was unchanged at 52.5 in June, 0.3 point above May, Markit said. France's PMI was upped to 50.7 in the final read from 50.5, while Germany's reading was unchanged at 51.9, nearly a point above May.Japan spending, confidence roar backThe Q2 Tankan survey found big companies plan to up capex by 9.3% in fiscal '16, the strongest pace in a decade. The sentiment index swelled to 15 from 12, which had been the consensus forecast. That was the first increase in nearly a year. Markit's manufacturing PMI for Japan sank to just above the neutral 50 line in June. At 50.1, it was down nearly a point vs. May. New orders contracted, but new export orders picked up.
Treasuries fell for a second day Wednesday after Greece's prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, offered to accept certain terms needed for a financial bailout, adding to optimism a deal may be forged.

Greece is preparing for a July 5 referendum on whether to accept austerity measures proposed by creditors after it missed a repayment to the International Monetary Fund on Tuesday. U.S. 10-year notes also fell after reports showed manufacturing expanded and employers added more jobs than forecast in June, reinforcing the Federal Reserve's case to raise interest rates this year as investors await a widely watched labor-market gauge to be released Thursday.

"There have been numerous headlines vacillating between Armageddon and solutions," said Gary Pollack, who manages $12 billion as head of fixed-income trading at Deutsche Bank AG's Private Wealth Management unit in New York. "What's driving the price action is some optimism about Greece. There's a slight upward bias to yields from here."

The benchmark Treasury 10-year yield rose seven basis points, or 0.07 percentage point, to 2.42% at 4:59 p.m. ET, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader data. The 2.125% note due in May 2025 fell 19/32, or $5.94 per $1,000 face amount, to 97-3/8. The yield touched 2.44%, the highest level since June 26.
The Bloomberg U.S. Treasury Bond Index declined 2% in the last quarter, its first loss since the last three months of 2013. It fell 1% in June, the worst monthly performance since February.
"Lost in the Greek headlines is the reality that the U.S. economy is doing quite well in the second quarter," said Dan Greenhaus, chief global strategist in New York at BTIG.

Manufacturing grew in June at the fastest pace in five months as the Institute for Supply Management's factory index rose to 53.5 from 52.8 in May, the Tempe, Ariz.-based group's report showed. Readings above 50 indicate expansion. The figure was in line with the Bloomberg survey median forecast of 53.2.
U.S. firms added 237,000 jobs last month, according to a private report from payroll services firm ADP, compared with a forecast for 218,000 among economists surveyed by Bloomberg.
A report by the Labor Department Thursday will show employers added more than 200,000 jobs for the 15th time in 16 months in June, according to the Bloomberg survey median estimate.

"The employment report could show continued strength in the labor market," Pollack said. The Fed wants to raise rates and September looks most likely, he said.Treasuries fell for a second day Wednesday after Greece's prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, offered to accept certain terms needed for a financial bailout, adding to optimism a deal may be forged.Greece is preparing for a July 5 referendum on whether to accept austerity measures proposed by creditors after it missed a repayment to the International Monetary Fund on Tuesday. U.S. 10-year notes also fell after reports showed manufacturing expanded and employers added more jobs than forecast in June, reinforcing the Federal Reserve's case to raise interest rates this year as investors await a widely watched labor-market gauge to be released Thursday."There have been numerous headlines vacillating between Armageddon and solutions," said Gary Pollack, who manages $12 billion as head of fixed-income trading at Deutsche Bank AG's Private Wealth Management unit in New York. "What's driving the price action is some optimism about Greece. There's a slight upward bias to yields from here."The benchmark Treasury 10-year yield rose seven basis points, or 0.07 percentage point, to 2.42% at 4:59 p.m. ET, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader data. The 2.125% note due in May 2025 fell 19/32, or $5.94 per $1,000 face amount, to 97-3/8. The yield touched 2.44%, the highest level since June 26.The Bloomberg U.S. Treasury Bond Index declined 2% in the last quarter, its first loss since the last three months of 2013. It fell 1% in June, the worst monthly performance since February."Lost in the Greek headlines is the reality that the U.S. economy is doing quite well in the second quarter," said Dan Greenhaus, chief global strategist in New York at BTIG.Manufacturing grew in June at the fastest pace in five months as the Institute for Supply Management's factory index rose to 53.5 from 52.8 in May, the Tempe, Ariz.-based group's report showed. Readings above 50 indicate expansion. The figure was in line with the Bloomberg survey median forecast of 53.2.U.S. firms added 237,000 jobs last month, according to a private report from payroll services firm ADP, compared with a forecast for 218,000 among economists surveyed by Bloomberg.A report by the Labor Department Thursday will show employers added more than 200,000 jobs for the 15th time in 16 months in June, according to the Bloomberg survey median estimate."The employment report could show continued strength in the labor market," Pollack said. The Fed wants to raise rates and September looks most likely, he said.

Stock futures climbed hard ahead of Wednesday's open, as news from the eurozone and Greece continued to dominate the holiday-shortened trading week.Dow futures soared 162.5 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures leapt 40 points. S&P 500 futures powered up 16.1 points.Global markets turned optimistic on news that a letter from Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras acceded to the austerity measures demanded by eurozone creditors, but with several critical changes.Tsipras asked for an extension of the prior bailout arrangement, which expired at midnight following the default on Greece's debt payment owed to the International Monetary Fund. The letter also requested an additional $32.3 billion in bailout funds.European leaders gave a mixed review to Tsipras' offer, which was received as central bankers were preparing to restrict access by Greek banks to emergency loans, according to the Financial Times.The reaction among European markets was not mixed, with the CAC-40 in Paris up 2.6% and Frankfurt's DAX ahead 2.5% just after midday.The U.S. stock market today received a slug of early economic news, beginning with the Challenger Job Cut report. Consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas said employers announced almost 45,000 job cuts in June — 43% above the year-ago level. That pushed the midyear total for layoffs to its highest since 2010. The retail sector posted the most job cuts in June, the report said, primarily due to the closing of Target (TGT) stores in Canada.The ADP National Employment report showed U.S. nonfarm private employer added 237,000 jobs in June. That was a healthy step up from 201,000 new hires in May and well above consensus forecasts for additions of 220,000. Of the June gains, 225,000 were service sector jobs.At 10 a.m. ET, the Institute for Supply Management releases its June Manufacturing Index, and the Commerce Department delivers May construction spending data. Automakers will be releasing June auto sales tallies throughout the day.In stocks, insurance mergers made news for a second day this week, with New Jersey-based Chubb (CB) soaring 32% ahead of the open on news that Switzerland-based Ace (ACE) will acquire the company in a $28.3 billion cash-stock deal. Ace shares rose 7%.On the IBD 50 list, leaders were generally flat to higher. Israel's CyberArk Software (CYBR), Ambarella (AMBA) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) ran at the head of the group, up 2% each in premarket trade.In China, the Shanghai Composite continued its recent volatile streak, backing down 5.2% after regulators did not alter the standing policy on IPO approvals. The Hong Kong Exchange was closed Wednesday. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 edged 0.5% lower.The dollar rose vs. both the euro and the yen. Oil dropped more than 1%. Gold eased a fraction. Wheat dropped 2%.
Home price gains decelerate

Home prices in the S&P/Case-Shiller index rose 4.9% in April, down from 5% in March and below consensus estimates of 5.4%. For the month, the 20-city index rose 0.3%, much less than the 0.8% expected and the 1% notched in March.
 Same-store sales picked up in the June 27 week, Redbook said, with a 1.7% gain vs. a year ago, compared with 1.6% in the prior week. But Redbook expects a monthly decline of 1.5% for June.
Consumer confidence surges

The Conference Board's measure jumped nearly 6 points to 101.4 in June, putting it within sight of the recovery high notched in Jan. The present situation index rose to 111.6 from 107.1 and the expectations index jumped to 94.6 from 86.2. Those saying jobs are plentiful increased and those saying they're hard to get declined.
Chicago PMI jumps

A closely watched purchasing manager's index for the Midwest surged 3.2 points in June, but remained in contraction at 49.4. Analysts had expected a read of 50.6, which would signal expansion. ISM's Chicago measure has been volatile this year, and June was its fourth month below 50.
Greece's day of reckoning arrives

Even as Athens confirmed it would not pay the IMF $1.73 bil due today, reports suggested the gov't was considering a last-minute appeal to creditors. European Commission leader Jean-Claude Juncker offered Greece a slightly better offer Mon. night, which would require that the gov't support a yes vote in the weekend referendum.
Eurozone inflation eases

The harmonized consumer price index rose 0.2% for the year in June, lower than the 0.3% notched in May. It was the first step backward since Jan. and had been expected by analysts. Separately, the unemployment rate for the eurozone was unchanged at 11.1% in May, down 0.5 point from May '14. Germany had the lowest jobless rate, at 4.7%, and Greece the highest, at 25.6%.
 German retail sales rose 0.5% in May, better than the flat reading expected but unable to match the 1.3% monthly gain from April. For the year, sales were down 0.4%.
 French consumer spending on durable goods was unchanged in May, down from an upwardly revised 0.4% monthly gain in April. It stood 4.6% higher for the year.
 Unconventional monetary policy may be the norm for "quite a while" as global central banks struggle to boost growth after the financial crisis, said the chief of the Reserve Bank of Australia.
COMING UP WEDNESDAY
 ADP employment report for June, 8:15 a.m. ET (forecast: 220,000).
 ISM manufacturing index for June, 10 a.m. ET (forecast: 53.2).

Fast Track Or No, The Long Global Trade Boom Is Over.

It was the first step backward since Jan. and had been expected by analysts. Separately, the unemployment rate for the eurozone was unchanged at 11.1% in May, down 0.5 point from May '14. Germany had the lowest jobless rate, at 4.7%, and Greece the highest, at 25.6%. German retail sales rose 0.5% in May, better than the flat reading expected but unable to match the 1.3% monthly gain from April. For the year, sales were down 0.4%. French consumer spending on durable goods was unchanged in May, down from an upwardly revised 0.4% monthly gain in April. It stood 4.6% higher for the year. Unconventional monetary policy may be the norm for "quite a while" as global central banks struggle to boost growth after the financial crisis, said the chief of the Reserve Bank of Australia.

DealerTrack Technologies (TRAK) stock surged nearly 60% Monday after it signed a definitive agreement for Cox Automotive to buy the software maker, which links auto dealers with banks and other lenders and credit agencies, for $4 billion. Atlanta-based Cox Automotive, a privately held company that provides vehicle remarketing services and digital marketing software for consumers, dealers and the overall auto…
Job gains pick up

Private employers added 201,000 jobs in May, ADP said. That was in line with analyst expectations. Small businesses accounted for 122,000 of those jobs, with midsize firms adding 65,000 and large companies hiring 13,000. Manufacturing jobs were down 5,000.
Trade deficit narrows

The trade gap dropped 19.2% to $40.9 bil in April, lower than the $44 bil expected and the steepest plunge in more than 6 years. March's figure was revised downwardly to $50.6 bil. Imports declined 3.3% and exports rose 1.0%. That will help boost Q2 GDP.
Service sector eases slightly

ISM's nonmanufacturing index fell 2.1 points to 55.7 in May, a steeper decline than expected. That's still a strong read; new orders also fell but remained robust at 57.9. New export orders swung handily into expansion territory at 55.0. Respondents were mostly upbeat, ISM said.

 Mortgage applications fell 7.6% in the May 29 week, the Mortgage Bankers Assn. said. Purchases were down 3%, though up 14% vs. a year ago, while refinancings slid 12% even as average rates ticked down 5 bps.

 Gallup's job creation index rose to a fresh high in May. The 32 reading was 1 point higher than in May and the most since tracking began in '08. Some 43% of respondents said their employer was hiring, the same as in April, but fewer said their staffs were being cut.
Eurozone activity eases

Markit's composite PMI for May dipped to 53.6 from 53.9, though it was better than the initial flash estimate. Job creation was at a 4-year high in May, Markit said. Germany's final May service gauge was 53.0, down from 54.0 in April and a 5-month low. But the service sector in France was at a 3-month high of 52.8, up 1.4 point from April.
 U.K. home prices rose 4.6% vs. a year ago in May, Nationwide said. That was 1 tick below expectations and down from a 5.2% yearly gain in April. Home price appreciation ran hot in '14.
Eurozone joblessness down

It declined 1 tick to 11.1% in April, a 3-year low, while the prior read was also revised down 1 tick to 11.2%. Youth unemployment dropped to 22.3% from 22.6%. Greece had a 25.4% jobless rate; Spain was at 22.7%.

 Eurozone retail sales were up 0.7% in April, a tick more than expected following a slightly upwardly revised 0.6% decline in March. Sales stood 2.2% higher for the year, but that was mostly driven by food, drink and tobacco.
 China's service sector activity popped in May, according to the HSBC/Markit PMI. New orders rose at the fastest rate in 3 years, the group said. The index hit 53.5, up from 52.9.
 The Japanese service sector expanded in May, according to Markit's final PMI, with new business rising at the quickest pace since Nov. The PMI hit 51.5, up 2 ticks from April.
COMING UP THURSDAY
 Jobless claims for the May 30 week, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: 276,000).
 Productivity and costs for Q1, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: productivity -2.9%, unit labor costs 6.0%).

Stocks pulled together some nice gains early Wednesday, as investors ignored weak housing data ahead of this afternoon's release of Fed minutes.
The Dow Jones industrial and the Nasdaq climbed 0.6% each. The S&P 500 grabbed a 0.5% gain.
Volume was quietly mixed, up 3% on the Nasdaq and 11% lower on the NYSE, relative to trade at the same time Tuesday.

The stock market today got off to a reasonably healthy start, despite Commerce Department data showing October housing starts slumped to a seven-month low. The market will be tuned to the 2 p.m. ET release of minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's Oct. 28 meeting, seeking any signs of timing on an interest rate increase.
Dow stocks were mostly positive. Apple (AAPL) pounded out a 3% gain to top the group after being added to Goldman Sachs' conviction buy list.
Norfolk Southern (NSC) led the S&P 500, up nearly 6% after Canadian Pacific Railway (CP) offered to buy the rail peer in a cash stock deal valued at more than $28 billion.

ConAgra (CAG) rallied more than 5%. The Omaha, Neb.-based packaged food giant announced it would strip out its frozen potato business, separating it under the Lamb Weston name at the beginning of next year.
U.K.-based oil driller Ensco (ESV) was close behind with a gain of nearly 5%. Energy stocks made a strong showing in early action, as oil prices rose modestly.
An array of retail stocks posted mixed early moves following their quarterly reports. The Energy Information Administration reports its weekly inventories data at 10:30 a.m.
China-based Vipshop (VIPS) spiked 10%. Jack in the Box (JACK) climbed 3%. Staples (SPLS) slipped 2%. Target (TGT) gave up its premarket gain and slumped 3% after reporting third-quarter results.

Among leaders, healthcare staffing agency AMN Healthcare (AHS) rumbled up 6% at the start of trade. The San Diego-based operation said late Tuesday it agreed to buy privately held B.E. Smith for $160 million in cash. AMN said the deal would be immediately accretive to its adjusted EPS. The stock has been scrawling out an erratic pattern and attempting to regain support its 10-week moving average.

Citrix Systems (CTXS) shed 8% in early action. The developer of enterprise software solutions announced late Tuesday it would lay off 1,000 workers and spin off its GoTo unit as a separate business. The company said the moves would result in pretax charges of up to $85 million and create savings of $200 million per year. The loss sent shares below their 10-week moving average in heavy trade and 5% below a 76.38 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Stocks pulled together some nice gains early Wednesday, as investors ignored weak housing data ahead of this afternoon's release of Fed minutes.The Dow Jones industrial and the Nasdaq climbed 0.6% each. Six grinding years into a mediocre expansion, confidence among small-business owners is lagging behind other economic indicators. The National Federation of Independent Business sentiment index rose 1.7 points in April to 96.9, still below historical norms.
"We've clawed our way up to just below average. That's how we've gone through this recovery," said NFIB's chief economist, Bill Dunkelberg.

With the jobless rate at 5.4%, the Federal Reserve prepping for its first interest-rate hike, and household balance sheets repaired, shouldn't small-business owners be feeling, well, at least average?

Noting NFIB's April survey, ITG chief economist Steve Blitz wrote, "Reminds of when I worked in a neighborhood store as a kid .. . the owner told me that the stock answer to how's business is always to complain that it could be better."
Small Firms' 'New Normal'

But small business has had good reason to be gloomier. And that melancholy may have contributed to the sluggish recovery, creating what might be called a "vicious business cycle" effect. If small firms are finally starting to feel more confident, as some signs show, it could prompt the tepid expansion to heat up a bit.
In a "new normal" slow-growth economy, smaller firms are more exposed to local or sector slumps. Large businesses are far more likely to have national exports and overseas operations.

Meanwhile, according to Dunkelberg, the Obama administration exacerbated small firms' worries and burdens. He ticked off a list of issues keeping small-business owners up at night: EPA regulations, tax reform, health care and "record numbers of new and changed regulations."

It might be tempting to dismiss such comments as standard rhetoric from a pro-business lobby, but small-business owners far removed from Washington and Wall Street echo the notion that government has done little to help and may have even gotten in the way for small businesses.

Lou Ramondetta, founder and president of Surplus Service, a Fremont, Calif.-based supplier of industrial recycling services, spent much of his earlier career at large firms including General Electric (GE). But now, he said, "I think big business is getting a bigger share" of the economic pie.

Without large budgets or administrative staffs to handle regulatory red tape, owners like Ramondetta, who has 13 employees, wind up in what can feel like a long slog that takes away from the real job: the company's mission.
That unease has real-world consequences.

"Yes, it is a political statement. But to the extent that people are feeling upset rather than good it does impact their instinct to be aggressive," said Joel Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors. "That means hire two people rather than three."
Slow To Hire
Hiring is where there's been the most evidence of malaise among small businesses, often lauded as America's job creators.

Employment at large firms rose by an average of about 7,000 a month following the three downturns before the Great Recession, while small-firm job growth averaged 82,000, according to recent Goldman Sachs research using Census Bureau data.

But in 2010-12, after the Great Recession, big businesses added an average of 42,000 per month, while employment at small firms shrank by 700. Goldman also noted that wage growth at large firms outpaced that at small firms by 6 percentage points from 1996 through 2009. But in the past five years, that gap has swelled by an additional 14 percentage points.
Naroff adds that smaller firms often hire "non-traditional" workers: those just entering or re-entering the workforce, who have less experience, or who want to work only part-time.
"Small businesses by necessity have to be more flexible in their hiring and as a result, maybe they're more democratic," he said.
More recent evidence suggests that small businesses are stepping up hiring. In each of the past 16 months, they've added more jobs than large businesses, according to the ADP Employment Survey.

Companies with less than 50 employees have added 1.67 million jobs since the end of 2013. Employers with 500 or more workers have boosted payrolls by just 552,600 in that span, and only 95,000 so far this year.
Ramondetta says he's been "desperately" trying to hire workers but hasn't found the right people yet. And those who are normally considered "hard to hire," he says, would be more than welcome.
"I don't have a problem hiring someone, say, out of prison who needs a second chance," he said. "I care about what are you going to do for me now."
When industry groups and the media say that the economy is lousy for small business, it "absolutely" has a chilling effect on activity, he said.
But he rejects the idea that this should sink a business owner's plans.

"The economy is what the economy is," he said. "You have to find a way to grow. That's what small business does well."Six grinding years into a mediocre expansion, confidence among small-business owners is lagging behind other economic indicators. The National Federation of Independent Business sentiment index rose 1.7 points in April to 96.9, still below historical norms."We've clawed our way up to just below average. That's how we've gone through this recovery," said NFIB's chief economist, Bill Dunkelberg.With the jobless rate at 5.4%, the Federal Reserve prepping for its first interest-rate hike, and household balance sheets repaired, shouldn't small-business owners be feeling, well, at least average?Noting NFIB's April survey, ITG chief economist Steve Blitz wrote, "Reminds of when I worked in a neighborhood store as a kid .. . the owner told me that the stock answer to how's business is always to complain that it could be better."Small Firms' 'New Normal'But small business has had good reason to be gloomier. Private payroll growth declined for the fifth straight month to the weakest increase since January 2014, according to ADP's estimate, the latest evidence that the U.S. economy is sluggish beyond the winter storms. Private jobs rose by 169,000, way off the 205,000 that analysts were expecting. Manufacturing jobs fell by 10,000 — the worst drop in five years — following…

Paychex (PAYX) reported third-quarter earnings in line with Wall Street estimates on Wednesday. The provider of human-resource services and processing services said Q3 earnings rose 4.5% to 46 cents per share, in line with estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue climbed 8% to $704.3 million, above views for $701.2 million. Shares fell 1.2% to 50.70 in premarket trading…

Sellers had the upper hand again in early afternoon trading Wednesday as major averages continued to struggle at a key support level. The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average all fell 0.5% and are below their 50-day moving averages. Nasdaq volume was tracking 9% higher than Tuesday. NYSE turnover fell 1%.
The market was rattled by earlier comments from Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen, who cited potential dangers in U.S. stock valuations.

In economic news, private employers added 169,000 jobs in April, according to payroll processor ADP. The new reading was well below the consensus estimate of 205,000 and comes ahead of Friday's jobs report.
Treasuries were under pressure again, sending the yield on the 10-year Treasury note higher by 6 basis points to 2.25%.
In the stock market today, Tesla (TSLA) eased 0.4% ahead of its earnings report after the close. The stock has been in rally mode lately, up 27% since hitting a low of 181.40 in late March.

Meanwhile, Papa John's (PZZA) tried to clear a 66.05 flat-base buy point early, but gave back gains. After soaring 8%, shares were up 4%. Late Tuesday, earnings of 55 cents a share topped views by 2 cents.
On the downside, former leader Alexion (ALXN) plunged 10.5% on news it's buying Synageva (GEVA) for 230 a share, or $8.4 billion. Synageva closed Tuesday at 95.87.

Stocks were lower near midday Wednesday following disappointing jobs data and a warning by Federal Reserve head Janet Yellen that equity valuations were "quite high."

The Nasdaq, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were each down 0.3%. All three indexes are now below their 50-day moving averages. Volume was running 15% higher on the Nasdaq but was fractionally lower on the NYSE compared with Tuesday.

Yellen, speaking at a conference in Washington, said, "Equity market valuations at this point generally are quite high," adding that "there are potential dangers there." However, she said she doesn't see any bubbles forming.
Meanwhile, private U.S. employers added 169,000 jobs in April, the fewest since January 2014, according to payroll processor ADP. The government's key nonfarm payrolls report for April is due Friday.

In the stock market today, Apple (AAPL) weighed on the Nasdaq, sliding 1% in heavy volume. Early in the session, the iPhone maker fell nearly 8% below a 133.70 flat-base buy point. A key IBD sell says to sell a stock if it falls 8% below the purchase price.

Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) dropped 8% after the biotech company said it would buy Synageva BioPharma (GEVA) for $8.4 billion in cash and stock. The acquisition values Synageva at $230 a share, more than double Synageva's closing price Tuesday. Synageva was up 115% at midday.

Selling in the major averages picked up the pace with a little over one hour remaining in Wednesday's session. The stock market was rattled by earlier comments from Fed Chair Janet Yellen who cited potential dangers in U.S. stock valuations.
The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average moved in lockstep, down 0.9% each. Nasdaq volume was tracking about 7% higher than Tuesday. NYSE volume was tracking close to Tuesday's level.

In economic news, private employers added 169,000 jobs in April, according to payroll processor ADP. The new reading was well below the consensus estimate of 205,000 and comes ahead of Friday's jobs report.
Treasuries were under pressure again, sending the yield on the 10-year Treasury note higher by 5 basis points to 2.24%.

In the stock market today, biotechs rebounded after recent weakness. Regeneron (REGN) edged higher ahead of its earnings report Thursday before the open. Regeneron is closing in on a 486.10 cup-with-handle buy point, but it's a late-stage base.
Recent new issue HealthEquity (HQY) jumped 4% to 26.92. Late Tuesday, the company priced a 3.85 million share offering at 25.90. HealthEquity is back above a cup-with-handle buy point of 26.60.
Tesla (TSLA) eased just over 1% ahead of its earnings report after the close. The stock has been in rally mode lately, up 27% since hitting a low of 181.40 in late March.

On the downside, Apple (AAPL) was poised for its sixth decline in seven sessions. Shares fell another 1.6%. A recent breakout over 133.70 hasn't worked out. LinkedIn (LNKD), meanwhile, lost another 0.8%. Shares cratered 21% last week after reporting earnings and issuing weak guidance.

Growth names set to report after the close include Epam Systems (EPAM), Fleetmatics (FLTX), Paycom (PAYC), Lannett (LCI) and MercadoLibre (MELI).Selling in the major averages picked up the pace with a little over one hour remaining in Wednesday's session. The stock market was rattled by earlier comments from Fed Chair Janet Yellen who cited potential dangers in U.S. stock valuations.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average moved in lockstep, down 0.9% each. Nasdaq volume was tracking about 7% higher than Tuesday. NYSE volume was tracking close to Tuesday's level.In economic news, private employers added 169,000 jobs in April, according to payroll processor ADP. The new reading was well below the consensus estimate of 205,000 and comes ahead of Friday's jobs report.Treasuries were under pressure again, sending the yield on the 10-year Treasury note higher by 5 basis points to 2.24%.In the stock market today, biotechs rebounded after recent weakness. Stock futures pointed to a strong open Tuesday amid strength in most overseas markets. Nasdaq 100 futures rallied 17 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures climbed 6 points. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 64 points.
Stocks reversed higher Monday to solid gains, but volume was lower.
Equity markets overseas were mostly higher, with European bourses leading the charge. France's CAC-40 bolted 2.3% and Germany's DAX rallied 1.9%. Meanwhile, London's FTSE 100 gained 1.7%.
In Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed about 1.2% and Japan's Nikkei gained 1.2%. But the Shanghai composite was fractionally lower.
After gaining 2.5% Monday on rising tensions from Friday's terrorist attacks in Paris, crude oil pulled back. December crude lost 60 cents to $41.14 a barrel.
On the economic front, consumer prices rose 0.2% in October. That was the the first gain in three months and matched views.
Data on industrial production and the NAHB housing market index will be out at 9:15 a.m. ET and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Fed Governors Jerome Powell and Daniel Tarullo will be speaking later today.

In stocks, Home Depot (HD) rallied 3% in premarket trading in the stock market today after beating views. The home improvement retailer posted Q3 earnings of $1.35 a share on sales of $21.8 billion. Views were for EPS of $1.32 on revenue of $21.76 billion. It also pegged full-year earnings at $5.36 a share or a nickel above views.
Rival Lowe's (LOW) was also up 3% in premarket trading. It reports quarterly results Wednesday.

Wal-Mart (WMT) rose 2% in the premarket despite posting mixed quarterly results. The world's biggest retailer reported fiscal Q3 earnings of $1.03 a share. But excluding a gain from leases, earnings were 99 cents a share. Sales came in at $117.4 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected EPS of 98 cents on revenue of $117.79 billion.

Fitbit (FIT) gained more than 2% in premarket activity after being upgraded to buy from neutral at Bank Of America/Merrill Lynch. Shares of the maker of fitness trackers bounced back Monday after hitting a record low Friday.

Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) plunged 15% in premarket trade following disappointing earnings for Q3 and a weak outlook. The retailer posted adjusted earnings of 45 cents a share on revenue of $1.64 billion. Views were for EPS of 47 cents on sales of $1.64 billion. The retailer guided Q4 earnings at $1.10 to $1.25 a share vs. views for $1.43. On Monday, shares fell to their lowest levels since January 2012.

Stocks ended lower Wednesday, although buyers came in during the last 15 minutes and lifted major averages off session lows. Still, it was another unsettling session. Distribution days, or higher-volume declines, for the Nasdaq and S&P; 500 have been a formidable head wind for a while now. But the market had another problem to deal with Wednesday after Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen cited potential dangers in U.S. stock valuations.

At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.5%, while the Nasdaq and S&P; 500 gave up 0.4% each. Preliminary data showed Nasdaq volume coming in about 6% higher than Tuesday. NYSE trading rose 3%.

In economic news, private employers added 169,000 jobs in April, according to payroll processor ADP. The new reading was well below the consensus estimate of 205,000 and comes ahead of Friday's jobs report.

Bonds were pressured again, sending the yield on the 10-year Treasury note higher by 4 basis points to 2.23%. Crude oil settled at $60.93 a barrel, up 53 cents, or 0.9%. The U.S. government reported the first weekly decline in crude inventories since January.

In the stock market today, biotechs rebounded, although technical damage was done to the group last week that will likely take some time to repair. Regeneron (REGN) is one of the exceptions in the group. It rose 1% ahead of its earnings report Thursday before the open. Regeneron is working on a cup-with-handle base with a 486.10 buy point, but it's a late-stage base.

Meanwhile, recent new issue HealthEquity (HQY) jumped 3% to 26.70. Late Tuesday, the company priced a 3.85 million share offering at 25.90. HealthEquity is back above a cup-with-handle buy point of 26.60.
Paycom Software (PAYC) picked up 5.5% ahead of earnings after the close. Quarterly profit is expected to surge 167% from the year-ago quarter to 8 cents a share.

Other growth companies set to report after the close included Epam Systems (EPAM), Fleetmatics (FLTX), Lannett (LCI) and MercadoLibre (MELI).Stocks ended lower Wednesday, although buyers came in during the last 15 minutes and lifted major averages off session lows. Private payroll gains plunge Private employers added just 169,000 jobs in April, payroll processor ADP said, dimming hopes for the government's report due Fri. Economists had expected a gain of 205,000 and are predicting 220,000 on Fri. Small business accounted for most of the gain, 94,000 jobs, in ADP's sample. Manufacturing lost 1,000 jobs. Productivity eases Nonfarm productivity declined 1.9%…
Trade deficit balloons

The trade gap widened to $51.4 bil in March, up 43% vs. Feb. It was the widest since Oct. '08. Exports rose 0.9% and imports surged 7.7%, partially on clearing the backlog at West Coast ports following a work stoppage. The figures may nudge Q1 GDP down in later revisions.
Services keep growing

ISM's nonmanufacturing PMI rose 1.3 point to 57.8 in April, beating forecasts for no change. Business activity jumped 4.1 points to a strong 61.6. New orders also ticked up, to 59.2, good news for future activity, and employment eked out a gain of 0.1 point to touch 56.7.
Small-business hiring stable
The Paychex-IHS Small Business Jobs Index rose 0.04% in April, indicating "sustained job growth", the group said. But the index declined vs. a year ago, when it stood at all-time highs.

 Economic confidence stumbled in April, according to Gallup's index. It slipped to -9 from -2 in March, with most of the decline happening later in the month as stocks seesawed and the price of gas rose.

 The service sector PMI from Markit ticked down to 57.4 in April from 59.2 in March, but is still the second highest read since Sept. and higher than the Q1 average. Better new orders and business activity supported the strongest increase in jobs since June, Markit said.

 Freddie Mac will send taxpayers $746 mil for profit received in Q1, its smallest payout since '09. While Freddie has repaid the federal gov't $92.6 bil, more than the $71.3 bil it received during the financial crisis, some analysts believe the dwindling profit may point to a need for another bailout in the future.
Eurozone staves off deflation

The producer price index ticked up 0.2% in March, while a 0.5% monthly gain in Feb. was revised up a tick to 0.6%. Annual PPI inflation rose to -2.3% from -2.8% as the gains in Feb. and March followed four straight monthly declines.

 Greece and its creditors ramped up talks as the Wed. deadline for it to repay the IMF drew closer with no resolution. Greek PM Alexis Tsipras spoke on the phone with German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and other Greek officials worked with creditor representatives , but there was no breakthrough on key sticking points.

 The European Commission upped its GDP forecast for the eurozone to 1.5% in '15 vs. 1.3% seen in Feb. The economies in Spain and Ireland are seen growing the fastest, while a forecast for Greek growth was cut to 0.5% from 2.5%.
Australia central bank cuts again

The Reserve Bank trimmed its key interest rate another 25 bps, as expected, to a record low of 2%. The central bank said it was aiming to "reinforce recent encouraging trends in household demand," and inflation at an annual 2.3% is still below target of 2%-3%.
COMING UP WEDNESDAY
 ADP Private Employment report for April, 8:15 a.m. ET (forecast: 205,000).
 Productivity and costs for Q1, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: productivity -1.9%, unit labor costs 4.6%).
RELATED:

Factories Sluggish But Orders Signal Stronger Outlook.
