Frankfurt's DAX lagged with a 0.1% gain.A few notable names are scheduled to report quarterly results after the session's close, including Apogee Enterprises (APOG), Herman Miller (MLHR) and Oracle (ORCL).
Stock futures were tightly mixed ahead of Wednesday's opening bell following a weak November jobs report.
Dow futures hung 4.6 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were down a fraction, and S&P 500 futures traded a fraction higher.
The stock market today wades into the week's increasingly heavy calendar of economic news, ramping up to Friday's November payroll report.

Private-sector U.S. employers added 208,000 workers in November, according to the ADP National Employment Report. That was a sharp drop from October's upwardly revised 233,000 new hires and well below consensus forecasts for 225,000 additions.
Third-quarter productivity increased 2.3%, according to revised Labor Department numbers, better than initial estimates of 2%. Economist had projected a revision to a 2.4% increase.
Labor cost revisions were more positive, showing a 1% decline vs. initial views of a 0.3% increase. Consensus estimates forecast the revised number at a weaker 0.1% decline.

Stock action was relatively quiet, although some retail and apparel issues showed mixed premarket moves, with GIII Apparel Group (GIII) up 5% and Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) down 4% after reporting third-quarter results.

Discount retailer TJX (TJX) amped up 3% before the start of regular trade. The owner of the T.J. Maxx and Marshalls chains ended Tuesday just below Friday's high, but 6% above a 61.34 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Leading stocks were quiet before the open, with 49 of the IBD 50 list stocks staying within 1% gains or losses. The exception was Singapore-based chipmaker Avago Technologies (AVGO), down a bit more than 1% in premarket trade. The company is scheduled to report quarterly results after today's close.

In China, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index slumped 1%. The Shanghai Composite added 0.6%, boosted by an official nonmanufacturing purchasing managers index reading of 53.9 for November, one click higher than October's 53.8 performance. Tokyo's Nikkei added 0.3%.
Europe's markets were narrowly mixed ahead of data releases in the U.S. and ahead of the European Central Bank's monthly meeting tomorrow.
The dollar muscled up to a 27-month high vs. the euro and to a seven-year peak against the yen.
U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude bobbed back above $67 a barrel, while natural gas continued lower.
Gold prices gained a fraction, climbing back above $1,200 an ounce.

The Institute of Supply Management's November service index is due out at 10 a.m. ET. The Energy Information Administration reports its weekly crude inventory data at 10:30 a.m., and the Federal Reserve releases its December beige book report at 2 p.m.Stock futures were tightly mixed ahead of Wednesday's opening bell following a weak November jobs report.Dow futures hung 4.6 points below fair market value. Leading HR software-makers Automatic Data Processing and Ceridian are stepping up efforts to offer more services via the cloud to better compete with rivals already there, such as Oracle, Workday and recent IPO Paycom Software. The combination of competition and customer demand for easy access over the Internet to a full line of human resource functions that include talent management…

CEOs see weak growth in '15 The Business Roundtable's CEO Economic Outlook Index declined to 85.1 in Q4, down from 86.4 in Q3 and 95.4 in Q2, reflecting lower expectations for capital spending. Although the 129 CEOs surveyed expect to pick up hiring, they expect the U.S. economy to grow 2.4% next year, which matches their 2014 expectation. The CEOs…

Employers hired robustly again in Oct., according to payroll processor ADP. Gains of 230,000 made Oct. the second-best month of 2014. While smaller firms have traditionally been the engine of job creation, midsize firms got in on the act this month. Small and midsize firms made up 98% of the total in October vs. a post-recession average of 68%. Midsize…

Aluminum climbed for the first time in three days as labor-market gains added to signs of a strengthening U.S. economy, bolstering demand prospects for the metal used in construction, autos and cans. The four-week moving average of Americans filing claims for unemployment benefits dropped to the lowest in more than 14 years, a government report showed Thursday. Wednesday, ADP Research…

Treasuries fell as Republicans swept to control of the Senate and ahead of a U.S. report this week that economists said will show labor-market gains that will keep the Federal Reserve headed toward raising interest rates.

Ten-year yields approached the highest in almost a month as ADP Research Institute reported companies in the U.S. added 230,000 workers in October.Republican Mitch McConnell, in line to become U.S. Senate majority leader in January, said, "There will be no government shutdowns and no default on the national debt."The Fed ended bond purchases under quantitative-easing stimulus last month."People are looking at the positives again," said Alex McKnight, an investment manager with GAM in New York, which oversees $120 billion. "We're coming out of the tail end of QE and seeing less of the headwinds that others are facing."The benchmark U.S. 10-year note yield rose one basis point, or 0.01 percent, to 2.34% at 3:43 p.m. in New York, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader data. It reached 2.37%, after touching 2.38% on Nov. 3, the highest since Oct. 8. The price of the 2.375% debt due August 2024 fell 2/32, or 63 cents per $1,000 face amount, to 100 9/32.The volume of Treasuries traded through ICAP, the largest interdealer broker of U.S. government debt, was $207 billion as of 2 p.m. in New York, compared with a full-day average for this year of $333 billion.Republicans captured control of the U.S. Senate in voting yesterday, positioning McConnell, the chamber's Republican leader, to set the legislative agenda for the final two years of Barack Obama's presidency. Republicans added seats in the House, which they have controlled for four years.The inability of Republicans and Obama to compromise on debt and spending programs led to a 16-day government shutdown in October 2013 and a downgrade of the nation's debt to AA+ by Standard & Poor's in August 2011.Stocks rose today, with the Standard & Poor's 500 Index gaining as much as 0.6%. The immediate impact on bonds may be less pronounced, said Richard Kelly, a senior strategist at Toronto-Dominion Bank in London."Perhaps the biggest question for markets will be how this influences the debt ceiling and funding questions," Kelly said. "But that has a long fuse that doesn't start burning until March next year and will run into the summer before it is critical."Treasuries pared losses as the Institute for Supply Management's nonmanufacturing index fell to 57.1 in October from the prior month's 58.6.

Private payrolls gain brisklyPrivate employers added 230,000 jobs in Oct., payroll processor ADP said, and Sept. figures were revised up to 225,000 from 213,000. Oct. numbers followed expectations and may signal corresponding strong growth in official government data reported Friday. Service sector still strong ISM's nonmanufacturing PMI hit 57.1 in Oct., down 1.5 points for the month. The business activity…

Stocks headed lower yesterday as the markets remain unsettled over coming earnings, FED policy, last night's Chinese PMI report (wasn't good!) , declines in commodities and continued concern over global growth......yesterday's losses took the major indexes into negative territory for the week.......although - in the end - they did manage to close off of their lows for the day.

(The Bloomberg Commodity Index (BCOM on your BB terminal) is a basket of prices for natural resources like copper, oil, gold, soybeans, sugar, wheat, cattle, zinc, hogs, coffee, nickel,.... fell 1.6% yesterday. This gauge is now down 16% ytd looking like it is heading for the lows of 2002! This move continues to spook the FED as the big bad boogeyman known as DEFLATION lurks just below the surface - pushing up the dollar which in turn puts pressure on commodity prices (inverse relationship) - it's a vicious circle - now toss in the China syndrome and investors are not willing to ignore what now appears to stronger negative headwinds)

Are we heading to test the August lows of 1865 on the S&P, 15,381 on the Dow and 4300 on the Nasdaq? Well - maybe and no one should be surprised if we do - why? Way too much uncertainty surrounding the coming earnings season...with all this talk of a weaker China - we can see how analysts are slashing estimates as they try and perfect their calls ahead of the qrtly confessional. Once we really begin to see the impact of what a 'slowing China' is really having on company bottom lines and what that means for forward guidance - investors will err to the side of caution - and rightly so.....Now what can we expect? We can expect the usual song and dance....analysts cut estimates (to the bone) ahead of the reports and then somehow - miraculously - 75%-80% of companies BEAT those lowered estimates and then it's all good!

Now if the market successfully tests and holds the August lows, then I think the market will try and rally as we make our way thru earnings.....But investors/traders should be prepared for some disappointments in earnings as well as very cautious commentary about future guidance...... Now if we test and fail at the August lows, then it means we would establish a lower low on the monthly charts further confirming a 'bearish condition" setting us up for more volatility ahead.

Now last night while were sleeping - China reports that PMI fell to 47 - a 6 yr low.. while a gov't probe of CITIC Securities revealed evidence of 'insider trading' sending this stock to 18 month lows and major markets into a tailspin....or Risk Off mode. Japan -1.98%, Hong Kong -2.26%, China -2.19% and ASX -2%... Comments by President Xi Jinping have done little to help and in fact many think his comments (while vacationing in the states) have hurt any attempt to stabilize. Wang Zheng - CIO at JingXi Investment Company had this to say -

"The market is reacting to the bad economic data, which seem to show no improvement.... Xi's comment indicates that the government's rescue measures will be phased out and the state won't buy as much as it did before to ramp up the market."
(Xi's comments were that the Chinese stock market has 'reached a phase of self-recovery and self-adjustment as he compared China's economy to a giant ship sailing in stormy seas')

On top of that - speculation continues around FED Chair Yellen.......and in a speech she is about to give in Amherst, Ma on "Inflation Dynamics and Monetary Policy" It is here that she will get to do 'clear the air' (laugh track inserted here).

Will she in fact confirm that the FED is on track to raise rates as the 3 stooges told us on Monday and Tuesday? Or will she confirm what so many investors already believe to be true - that rates are not going anywhere until next year? The question is: Was Janet among the 13 of 17 officials that think rates should rise this year or not? If she clarifies her position about the economy and rates - will this serve to stabilize markets or create more chaos? Look - she is all about transparency - no? So if that is the case - she does NOT want to say "SURPRISE!!!". She has to lay out a course of action and then stick to it - maybe she needs a good PR firm to help negotiate the message? And no matter what - the market is now second guessing everything they do....because it has been disappointed over and over again...and then she sends out the troops to deliver different messages as she tries to calm the markets......As Bryan Carter - Former US Treasury Economist and now lead PM at Acadian Asset said -
"They are creating the conditions that are causing the external environment to be weak, and then they say they can't hike because of those same conditions that they have created."

European markets are bucking the trend - as they move higher....seemingly ignoring the Chinese PMI data and the growing VW scandal (which still remains a company-specific problem - not an industry problem) yet this issue has taken 41% out of the value of VW since the news broke.....FTSE + 1.5%, CAC 40 +0.94%, DAX + 0.83%, EUROSTOXX + 1%, SPAIN +0.77% and ITALY +1.4%.

US futures are up 8 handles at 1940 as trader types are following in Europe's footsteps - ignoring the negative news out of Asia.........Now yesterday - we traded right down to support at 1925ish......and bounced.....as the day wore on - we found plenty of bargain hunting going on as they rallied them off the lows towards the end of day....I suspect the market wants to once again try and rally around the 1950 level on the S&P.....but any move much above that will surely be met with resistance as the trader types move in and out taking advantage of the volatility.
Expect volumes to be light today as many participants are away for the Jewish holidays...
Take good care.
Kp

Trade gap widensThe deficit unexpectedly widened to $43.0 billion in Sept., from a modestly downwardly revised $40 billion in Aug. Exports declined 1.5% as the global economy slowed, while imports were unchanged. The gap in goods ex petroleum widened to $47.2 billion from $45.5 billion.
Yearly home price gains seen

CoreLogic's Home Price Index rose 5.6% in Sept. vs a year ago, and the group expects price gains of 5.0% in the 12 months ending Sept. 2015. Sept's yearly increase was the 31st month of yearly gains. All states saw year-over-year increases, with double-digit rises in Michigan and Montana; 28 states and the District of Columbia are at or within 10% of their previous peaks.

 Factory orders dipped 0.6% in Sept., less than the 0.7% expected. It was the second straight monthly decline. Shipments rose 0.1% in Sept., but unfilled orders rose 0.3% to the highest level since government record keeping began in 1992.
 Same-store sales declined 1.6% in the Nov. 1 week, ICSC-Goldman said, taking the yearly change down to 1.8% from 2.8% the week before. The group blamed weather, this time unseasonable warmth.
Eurozone recovery seen delayed

The bloc won't see even modest growth for at least another year, the European Commission said as it trimmed its forecast. It now sees GDP growth of 0.8% in 2014 and 1.1% in 2015, and doesn't expect 1.7% growth until 2016, a year later than in previous forecasts, due largely to a drag from France and Italy. The commission also halved its forecast for the German economy, projecting 1.1% growth in 2015 rather than the 2% previously seen.

 German Chancellor Angela Merkel acknowledged that the eurozone situation is "extremely fragile," but repeated that Germany would not borrow money for investments. Germany has been urged to step up investment spending by the European Central Bank, the International Monetary Fund and other eurozone countries, but has resisted.

 Eurozone producer prices rose 0.2% in Sept., a tick higher than expected, but offset by a downward revision to Aug. figures, now at -0.2%. For the year, the PPI is down 1.4%, the same as in Aug. The declines are largely due to energy costs.

 Japan's manufacturing PMI rose to 52.4 in Oct., Markit/JMMA said. It was the highest since March, before a national sales tax increase went into effect, and "signaled a sold overall improvement in operating conditions," Markit said.
COMING UP WEDNESDAY
 ADP Employment Report for Oct., 8:15 a.m. ET (forecast: 230,000).
 ISM Non-Manufacturing Survey for Oct., 10 a.m. ET (forecast: 58.0)
RELATED:

Ken Nickerson has a tough decision to make.

His employer, the University of Nebraska, is offering attractive retirement packages to eligible faculty. The 71-year-old biology professor passed on a similar offer in 2010 and wonders if he'll be lucky enough to receive another in two to five years, when he hopes to retire.
Nickerson understands why the university is asking older folks to step aside.
"There's a level of energy a 35-40-year-old will bring to writing grant proposals and manuscripts and just thinking about the world that someone who's 70 will not," he said.

Another key factor is that more experienced professors likely draw higher salaries than younger ones would. While the university doesn't have a specific budget target, a 2010 buyout saved $8.1 million as older faculty stepped down.

Something similar may be playing out across the country as thousands of older folks retire every day. The baby boom generation — those born from 1946 to 1964 — comprises 79 million Americans, according to Pew Research figures, and is dwarfed only by the millennials, 83 million strong and just starting their careers at the low rung of the pay ladder — if jobs are available.

The unusually large generational transition was intensified due to the 2008-09 recession and sluggish recovery. Many boomers delayed retirements as they lost jobs or had hours cut at the end of their careers. Many also saw the value of their retirement portfolios tank during the financial crisis.

There's some evidence that the generational shift is picking up, but its long delay may have had an impact even broader than previously realized, by depressing wage gains even as the job recovery shifted into high gear.
If that's true, it may have big implications for monetary policy.
Federal Reserve officials are worried about wage growth, which has plodded along at about 2% annually ever since the recession, barely above consumer inflation.

The Employment Cost Index, one of the most comprehensive measures of wages and benefits, rose 0.7% for a second straight quarter in Q3, the Labor Department said Friday. But those two strong quarters followed a 0.3% rise in Q1, which was among the lowest readings in three decades.

Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen and other monetary policymakers say that tepid wage gains have held back faster growth in areas like housing. More important, the Fed believes wages are the best barometer for gauging the labor market's health. As long as they stagnate, the Fed is reluctant to raise interest rates, believing there's still labor market slack, or an over-supply of workers, giving employers little reason to sweeten salaries.

Some analysts think official data may not capture the whole picture. The persistence of wage stagnation even as the jobless rate sinks below 6% and monthly job creation tops 200,000 suggests other trends may be at work.
Using data from payroll processor ADP, Moody's Analytics calculated in a recent report that 400,000 more job leavers and 500,000 more new entrants existed in Q3 than in the third quarter of 2013.
"Since new entrants are paid less than those at the ends of their careers (a large share of the leavers), measured wage growth has been depressed," the report concluded.

It's hard to know for sure, because official data don't capture this trend. The Labor Department tracks changes in wages and quantifies the number and percent of people working in each age category, but doesn't combine those two sets of data.
Generation X is entering its prime earning years, but there are only about 65 million gen Xers, far less than aging boomers and younger millennials.
The boomer scenario is logical to many job market professionals, who say it squares with what they see in their work.

"The data is more complicated because I think this generation of boomers is thinking about late career in a different way than previous generations," said John Challenger, CEO of Challenger, Gray and Christmas.
Boomers may continue working, but in lower-paying jobs that they love rather than depend on, he says, or they may cut hours back to work part time or as consultants and contractors.

Retirement may be skewing another key Fed metric — the labor force participation rate, which skidded to a 36-year low of 62.7% in September. Philadelphia Fed research suggests a full 8/10 point of that rate's decline since 2012 is due to retirements, and not a sign of increased labor slack.
"This implies that the decline in the unemployment rate since 2012 is not due to more discouraged workers dropping out of the labor force," concluded the author, Shigeru Fujita.

Some analysts don't believe the retirement thesis. Gad Levanon, chief economist for the Conference Board, points out that the share of people over 55 who are working continues to grow, according to September Labor Department statistics. He also thinks the labor market is getting so tight that employers will soon have to pony up to keep experienced older workers from retiring.

Challenger agrees that the economy is nearing full employment, and expects shortages and "a war for talent" to pressure wages upward. He figures more flexible attitudes toward work post-retirement may help address some of that shortage.

In 2010, when the University of Nebraska last offered buyouts, 77 of 200 eligible faculty took the offer, Nickerson says. For now, he wants to keep working, at least until his grad students finish their research in 2016.
"I'm not going to bail out when I have three grad students I'm working with now," he said. "There are projects I want to see finished, some I've been working on for years."
Even as it offers buyouts, the university is moving toward its future workforce; 54 open tenure-track positions are listed on its website.
John Challenger thinks it may be time for some older folks to call it a day.

"In many ways the baby boom has been artificially holding up the advancement of younger people because there's been more people clogging those jobs than in other periods," he said.Ken Nickerson has a tough decision to make.His employer, the University of Nebraska, is offering attractive retirement packages to eligible faculty. More than a million new business establishments formed in the U.S. last year, according to federal government data, and history suggests that roughly half will likely go under within five years. If you make your money serving small businesses, this can't be a very heartening figure. On the other hand, if you flip the equation upside down, you realize that…

U.S. stocks followed European stocks lower Wednesday.Sentiment weakened in Europe amid increasing signs of economic weakness in the eurozone. Manufacturing data showed contraction in Germany, France, Austria and Greece, according to Markit Economics. Meanwhile, Italy lowered its GDP forecast ahead of Thursday's ECB meeting.The Dow Jones industrial average lost 1.3%, weighed down by Boeing (BA) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ). The Nasdaq fell 1.5% and the S&P 500 gave up 1.2%. The Russell 2000 fell another 1% and is now 10% off its recent high of 1213. Another distribution day was taking shape as NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking higher than Tuesday's levels.Nasdaq 100 titans Facebook (FB), Illumina (ILMN) and Baidu (BIDU) lost more than 3%.On the home front, private employers added 213,000 jobs in September, according to the latest data from ADP. Separately, the ISM manufacturing index dropped to 56.6 in September from 59 in August. The drop was a little worse than expected.In the stock market today, Acuity Brands (AYI) was one of the few bright spots. Shares surged 11% after the company reported strong earnings, fueled by strength in its light-emitting-diode (LED) products.Mining and utility stocks also did well, but growth stocks came under heavy selling pressure.Half the stocks in the IBD 50 lost 2% or more with Polaris (PII), FleetCor (FLT) and Akorn (AKRX) all crashing below their 50-day moving averages.Two leaders in IBD's Transportation-Equipment Manufacturing group also gave up their 50-day lines. Greenbrier (GBX) tanked 9% while Trinity Industries (TRN) lost 7%.

Stocks sold off hard Wednesday, sparked by concerns about economic weakness in Europe and mixed U.S. economic data.The Nasdaq plunged 1.6%, while the Dow industrials sank 1.4% and the S&P 500 lost 1.3%. Volume rose across the board in the stock market today, according to preliminary figures.Private employers added 213,000 jobs in September, according to the ADP National Employment report, more than the expected 200,000. But monthly manufacturing data disappointed, as the Institute for Supply Management's September index slipped to 56.6, below views for 58 and August's 59 reading.Some leading stocks got hit hard, including Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), which sank 8% in fast turnover. The chipmaker closed below its 50-day moving average for the first time since April. Sterne Agee reiterated its buy rating and a 60 price target, citing profit-taking, but a Digitimes article noted slowing sales of 4G smartphones in China for the session weakness.The Transportation-Equipment Manufacturing group, down 6%, was the biggest loser among IBD's 197 industry groups. Oil and railroad industry trade groups are asking for more time to retrofit oil transport railcars. Trinity Industries (TRN) tanked 8%, Greenbrier Cos. (GBX) 10%, Wabtec (WAB) 3% and American Railcar Industries (ARII) 6%, all in heavy trade.Airlines, solar stocks, and oil and gas plays also underperformed. Gold and silver miners, and utilities, were among the few gainers.Royal Gold (RGLD) climbed 1%, nearly reclaiming its 50-day moving average in higher-than-usual volume. The Denver-based miner, which snapped a five-quarter string of profit declines in Q2 with a 44% gain, is expected to report a 48% increase in Q3.Acuity Brands (AYI), one of the day's top gainers, gapped up and soared 11% in busy turnover. The lighting products maker reported fiscal Q4 results that topped views on both the top and bottom lines, thanks to strong light-emitting-diode sales.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.
Stock futures nosed lower early Wednesday as investors weighed earnings, consumer price data and overseas action, and ahead of this afternoon's Federal Reserve release.

Dow futures slipped 55.3 points below fair market value, off lows but lower over the prior hour. Nasdaq 100 futures were 4.7 points lower. S&P 500 futures were down 4.4 points. Small caps were under pressure, down 6 points.

Minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's July 29 meeting, due out at 2 p.m., will be a focal point for the stock market today. It is the last official release of data before the September meeting at which the Fed has broadly suggested it could vote to raise the federal funds target rate. The Fed has not altered the rate, currently 0.25%, since December 2008.

Consumer prices rose 0.1% in July, the Labor Department said, a sixth straight monthly advance, but down from a 0.3% increase in June and below expectations for a 0.2% increase. Core prices, minus food and energy, also rose 0.1%, below the 0.2% consensus and June's 0.2% rise. It was the index's second straight year-over-year advance after flat action for the first five months of the year.

U.S. stocks may feel some early pressure European markets, trading lower after Germany's parliament approved the renewed bailout agreement for Greece. The debate rocked markets for months before finally securing Greek support in July and passed muster among eurozone finance ministers Aug. 14.

The German vote frees funds for release to the debt-stressed country later today. Greece owes the European Central Bank a $3.5 billion debt payment on Thursday. The DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris carried losses of more than 1% near midday.

Some China-based stocks trading on U.S. markets took post-earnings report beatings early Wednesday. Canadian Solar (CSIQ) dived 10%, Tarena International (TEDU) folded 12% after reporting second-quarter results late Tuesday. Sina (SINA), which also reported after Tuesday's close, rose a fraction.
Retailers were again busy in premarket action. American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) jumped 3% after posting healthy Q2 results. Staples (SPLS) dropped 2%. Lowe's (LOW) stumbled 1%.

Target (TGT) leapt 4% after a 33% jump in earnings and a 3% revenue gain topped analysts' Q2 expectations. The company boosted its full-year earnings outlook — a significant move following Tuesday's downgrade from Wal-Mart (WMT) — and same-store-sales comfortably beat forecasts. Shares rose almost 2% Tuesday, continuing the stock's rebound from support at its 200-day moving average.

Meat processor Hormel Foods (HRL) popped 2% ahead of the open. The Austin, Minn., company's adjusted Q2 earnings narrowly topped consensus views. Revenue dipped 4%, in line with expectations, and management raised its full-year EPS guidance. The stock finished Tuesday just below a Monday high after clearing a shallow, months-long consolidation.
Homebuilders were trading mixed in premarket action after a strong session on Tuesday. Toll Bros. (TOL) was down nearly 2%, while Lennar (LEN) and D.R. Horton (DHI) dipped a fraction each.
Thinly traded MI Homes (MHO) spiked 10% in premarket trade. The Columbus, Ohio-based builder ended Tuesday almost 3% past a 25.71 buy point after a breakout from a flat base on Monday.

Overseas, Asian markets were all over the map on Wednesday, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 taking a 1.6% loss, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 1.3%, the Shanghai Composite up 1.2% and the Shenzhen Composite posting a 2.2% gain. The Shanghai and Shenzhen markets dived 3% in early trade.

The dollar slipped vs. the euro and the yen. Commodities were mixed, with West Texas Intermediate oil down a bit less than 1% and Europe's Brent crude effectively flat. Gold rose a half-percent to $1,121 an ounce. Manufacturing pulls back, stays strong ISM's Sept. manufacturing gauge declined to 56.6 from 59.0, below expectations for a more moderate retreat but still very strong. New orders and employment both dipped but remained strong, while production added 0.1 point. Separately, Markit's manufacturing PMI dipped 0.4 point to 57.5 in Sept., but its jobs gauge hit a 2-1/2 year high and…

Treasuries posted their worst month of the year amid speculation the Federal Reserve will signal an increase in interest rates next year as the economic recovery firms. Benchmark 10-year-note yields rose today before reports this week forecast to show American employers added more than 200,000 jobs in September. Withdrawals from a Pacific Investment Management exchange traded fund that was run…

Yellen: rate hikes have limitsMonetary policy such as interest-rate hikes is usually not the best tool for reining in financial instability, Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen said, though she acknowledged that instability may arise after extended periods of low rates push investors to reach for yield. Regulatory tools already in the Fed's purview, such as bank capital requirements, are the best approach, she said at an IMF conference.ADP: private payrolls surgePrivate-sector firms added 281,000 workers in June, payroll processor ADP estimated, the best gain since late 2012. The estimate crushed expectations for a rise of 213,000 and suggests that the Labor Dept.'s Thu. report may also top forecasts. Most gains were in the services sector, but manufacturing and goods producer hiring also accelerated. ADP is not always a great gauge of the official report, but other June data point to strong job gains.Factory orders sputterNew orders for manufactured goods fell 0.5% in May, worse than the 0.3% decline expected, with broad weakness across categories. But orders ex defense rose 0.2%, and a 0.7% gain in April was revised up. Also a plus: Core capital-goods orders, considered a proxy for business investment, rose 0.7%.Equipment leasing seen downThe Equipment Leasing & Finance Foundation revised its investment growth forecast to 2.6% in '14, from 4.2%, saying it expected "modest sector growth" following a weak start to the year. Credit supply and demand have been steady, it said. Employment ticked up in June in Gallup's Payroll to Population survey, which rose 0.5 point to 45. A separate Gallup job-creation survey was flat at 27, a 6-year high.Canada manufacturing ticks upThe RBC factory PMI rose to 53.5 in June, from 52.2. That's the highest since Dec. and the 15th straight month in expansion territory. The employment gauge rose 0.2 point to 52.6, its best since Nov., and output and new orders were brisk. EU producer prices softened 0.1% in May, for a 1% decline on the year. It was the fifth straight monthly decline. Consensus had been for a flat read.U.K. home prices at new highPrices returned to pre-bubble highs in June, Nationwide said. Its index posted a 1% increase on the month, more than the 0.5% expected, and is up 11.8% on the year. Prices in London are up nearly 26% on the year. The Bank of England is taking steps to rein in housing. Two of Europe's PIGS, the countries whose sovereign debt crises engulfed the continent, are funding short-term debt repayments early. Ireland is refunding debt maturing in '16, and Portugal is readying a new issuance of U.S. dollar-denominated 10-year bonds.Macau incomes swellThe administrative region belonging to China has surpassed Switzerland to become the world's 4th-largest per-capita GDP, aided by mainland gamblers, the Financial Times reported. It lags Luxembourg, Norway and Qatar.COMING UP THURSDAY Employment situation for June, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: payrolls up 211,000, jobless rate 6.3%). U.S. trade balance for May, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: -$45.1 bil). ISM nonmanufacturing index for June, 10 a.m. ET (forecast: 56.2).
Private payroll gains miss forecasts

Private employers added 204,000 jobs in Aug., processor ADP said, just shy of the 223,000 expected, while July was revised down 6,000 to 212,000. Still, it was the fifth straight monthly gain over 200,000 jobs. The composition of new jobs shifted, with goods-producing roles up 41,000, more than the 23,000 gain in July, while service-providing employment rose by 164,000, down from 190,000.
Service sector forges ahead

ISM's non-manufacturing gauge touched an 8-year high of 59.6 in Aug. from 58.7, with output and employment measures rising strongly. The new orders gauge declined 1.1 point from July's cycle high, but it still remains elevated at 63.8.
Trade deficit narrows

The trade gap shrank to $40.5 billion in July from a downwardly revised $40.8 billion in June, the Census Bureau reported. Expectations had been for a higher deficit of $42.3 billion. Exports rose 0.9%, while imports rose 0.7%.
Productivity rises

Productivity increased at a 2.3% rate in Q2, vs. the 2.5% originally reported and expectations of a 2.4% revision. Q1 was revised down to a 4.5% decline. Unit labor costs dipped 0.1%, rather than gaining 0.6% as originally reported. That followed an 11.6% Q1 gain.
Jobless claims rise slightly
Initial claims rose to 302,000 in the Aug. 30 week, up from 298,000. It was just above expectations for 300,000. The 4-week average declined 1,250 to 299,750.
 Planned layoffs declined 15% in Aug., said placement firm Challenger, Gray and Christmas. The Aug. count of 40,010 is 21% lower than year-ago levels and was concentrated in electronics.
 German manufacturers' orders surged 4.6% in July, well above expectations for a 1.6% rise and more than reversing the 2.7% decline in June. Orders are up 4.9% for the year.
COMING UP FRIDAY
Employment situation for Aug., 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: payrolls up 230,000, jobless rate at 6.1%).

Stock futures showed strong gains ahead of Wednesday's open, as global markets rallied on word of a Ukraine/Russia cease-fire.Dow futures were 66.4 points above fair market value and leaning higher. Nasdaq 100 futures were up a strong 13. 3 points and also on the uptick. S&P; 500 futures were ahead 6.7 points and, among small caps, Russell 2000 futures were up 6.2 points and climbing.The stock market today was rattled awake by stocks and futures bolting higher around the world after Ukraine President Petro Poroshenko claimed a "permanent cease-fire" had been agreed upon between he and Russian President Vladimir Putin. Russia has denied any agreement, however, saying it is not party to the conflict. Ukraine's presidential office updated its initial statement, declaring an agreement to a "permanent cease-fire regime" had been reached.In stocks, the moonshots by smaller pharmaceuticals played continued with Infinity Pharmaceuticals (INFI) rocketing 46% ahead of the open. The Cambridge, Mass.-based biotech announced it would partner with Abbvie (ABBV) to develop and commercialize the oral cancer treatment duvelisib. Abbvie shares rose a fraction.Among leaders, a broad swathe of China-based stocks moved higher, tracking Wednesday's gains among Asian markets.Autohome (ATHM) popped 3% in premarket action. The volatile stock reversed after a sharp dive Tuesday, and after backing out of a breakout attempt last week.Baidu (BIDU) rose 2% ahead of the bell. The search engine heavy surged 5% in strong trade Tuesday, clearing a buy point at 222.23.Vipshop Holdings (VIPS) also climbed 2%. The online clothing retailer retook its 50-day moving average Tuesday, one day after cutting that line in very heavy trade on Friday.Overseas, Russia's market leapt 4% on initial news of a possible cease-fire agreement, paring those gains back to below 3%. Asia's markets closed sharply higher. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index led with a 2.3% gain. Europe's major indexes were also up significantly, with both the CAC-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX showing 1.2% gains at midday.The euro rose against the dollar, buoyed by the Ukraine cease-fire talk. The dollar was flat against the yen after the start of the Bank of Japan's two-day policy meeting. Commodities edged higher, taking back some ground lost on Tuesday.The week's economic calendar begins picking up today, with July factory orders expected from the Commerce Department at 10 a.m. ET followed by the Fed's September Beige Book report at 2 p.m. The Challenger Job Cuts and ADP National Employment Reports are due out Thursday, wrapping up with August payrolls numbers from the Labor Department Friday.

U.S. gains in competitivenessThe U.S. moved up 2 notches to No. 3 in the World Economic Forum's global economic competitiveness ranking. The U.S. lags Switzerland and Singapore; Finland and Germany come just behind. America progressed because of improvements in financial markets and public institutions. Fed's beige book report upbeat on activity, hiring Economic growth remained mostly moderate across the country,…

ISM manufacturing index surges to 3-year high ISM's factory gauge rose to 59.0 in Aug., up 1.9 points and well above expectations. It was the 15th straight month in expansion mode and the highest level since March 2011, the Institute for Supply Management said. New orders soared to 66.7, up 3.3 points and a 10-year high. Employment shed a tick…

Signs of strength in economyPrivate employers added 179,000 jobs in May, ADP said, though that was less than forecasts for 210,000. It may preview the Labor Dept.'s employment report out Fri. But ISM's May service sector PMI jumped nicely, to 56.3, above views, with the new orders gauge hitting a 3-year high. The Fed's beige book noted modest to moderate economic activity in recent months, with labor markets improving, but wage pressures are subdued.Trade gap hits 13-month highApril's U.S. deficit widened further than expected, to $47.2 bil from an upwardly revised $44.2 bil in March. Exports declined $300 mil, or 0.2%, after increasing in March, while imports rose 1.2%, down from the 3.1% gain in March. It was the biggest deficit since March '12, and will detract from Q2 GDP figures. Crude oil imports declined by $100 mil.Productivity suffers worst decline in six yearsQ1 output per hour fell at a 3.2% annual rate, the worst decline since Q1 '08. That was worse than originally thought, partly reflecting GDP's downward revision to a 1% drop. Meanwhile, unit labor costs rose at a 5.7% pace, the fastest in more than a year. As with other winter weather effects, most analysts believe wrinkles like this one to be temporary.Mortgage applications downThe Mortgage Bankers Assn.'s applications index fell 3.1% in the week ended May 30. Demand for loans to buy a home slid 3.6%, their 4th straight drop. The refinance index sank 2.9%, even though average rates fell 5 basis points to 4.28%, a fresh 11-month low. With Treasury yields rising this week, mortgage rates should follow. Gallup's Job Creation Index rose 2 points in May, to a recovery high of 27. Separately, the Conference Board's Help Wanted Online survey slipped by 18,900 in May. The supply of workers to every vacancy slipped below 2 for the first time in 6 years.Canada trade swings to deficitImports surged to a record and exports fell in April, unexpectedly pushing the trade balance to a deficit $638 mil Canadian ($585 mil), following a March surplus of $766 mil. The Bank of Canada left monetary policy unchanged, as expected, reiterating that sluggish inflation remains a risk. Eurozone Q1 GDP growth was confirmed at 0.2%. Sluggish household consumption weighed on the economy, at 0.1% growth. Separately, Markit's composite PMI for May softened a bit in its final read, to 53.5 from 54. The services gauge rose 1 tick to 53.2.Japan to cut corporate taxPM Shinzo Abe agreed to cut the corporate tax rate in fiscal 2015, provided the gov't continues to bolster public finances. The 35% rate is 2nd in the rich world only to the U.S.', but Japan has the world's highest public debt levels. Separately, Markit's composite PMI leapt 2.9 points to 49.2 in May as effects of the sales tax hike waned, but it is still below the neutral 50 level. Russia will get World Bank money, the first investment since tensions broke out over Crimea. The $340 mil will enable a French grocery retailer to expand there and in other emerging markets.World manufacturing humsJPMorgan's Global Manufacturing PMI hit an 8-month high of 54.3 in May, led by the U.S. and U.K., which saw its highest rate of growth ever. Across the globe, new business volumes rose, while higher demand led to backlogs. The pace of job growth hit a 4-month high.COMING UP FRIDAY BLS May employment report, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: 213,000). Consumer creditfor April, 3 p.m. PT (forecast: $15 bil).
Analysts expect slight year-over-year gains from payroll-processing firmPaychex (PAYX), which reports fourth-quarter and full-year results Tuesday after the close.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Q4 earnings of 40 cents a share, a 5.3% rise from the same period last year, on revenue up 5.5% to $617.4 million. For the year, analysts project earnings up 6.9% to $1.71 per share, on revenue up 6.2% to $2.47 billion.
Paychex expects human resource services revenue to have grown in the low double digits for the year, with Q4 payroll revenue growth affected by one less processing day than last year.

Shares of the company had risen 0.7% to 41.49 by late Monday morning in the stock market. Paychex has an IBD Composite Rating of 37, meaning 63% of public companies have outperformed Paychex on key metrics, including sales and earnings growth. In May, the Rochester, N.Y.-based company declared a 35-cent per share quarterly dividend.
Automatic Data Processing (ADP) and Workday (WDAY) are competitors in the sector. In April, ADP spun off its automotive Dealer Services business.

Q2 GDP swells at 4% annual rate The economy grew at an annualized 4% in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said, while the dismal first quarter and all of 2013's second half were revised up. Some analysts had expected a rebound effect to take hold in Q2 after Q1's -2.1% pace — revised up from -2.9% — but overall…

The major averages ended mixed Wednesday, as stocks pared earlier losses following the Federal Open Market Committee's policy statement.The Nasdaq led with a 0.5% gain, while the S&P 500 closed fractionally higher. The Dow, dragged down by Coca-Cola (KO) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH), fell 0.2%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today, according to preliminary data. Nasdaq volume fell from Tuesday.Transportation logistics providers, steel producers and enterprise software makers were among the day's top gainers. The biggest decliners included truck parts makers, meat processors and utilities.Icon (ICLR) gapped up and soared 8%, clearing a 48.91 cup-with-handle buy point in huge volume. The clinical research services provider reported Q2 profit of 64 cents a share, up 48% and 6 cents above views. Revenue rose 13% to $376 million, in line with forecasts. The Irish company also lifted its full-year EPS outlook.Among IBD 50 stocks, Trinity Industries gained 2% in above-average trade to mark a new closing high. It surged as much as 6% intraday after reporting late Tuesday Q3 sales and profit that beat views.Stocks opened higher amid mixed economic data, then sharply pared gains ahead of the Fed announcement. Payroll processor ADP reported 218,000 new jobs added in July, well below June's 281,000 and economists' forecast for 235,000. But the Commerce Department said the economy grew 4% in Q2, above views for 3.1% GDP growth.As expected, the Fed said it will continue tapering its bond purchases and that short-term rates will stay low for "a considerable time" after its bond-buying program ends. But it didn't specify when it plans to start raising short-term interest rates.Economic data due out tomorrow morning include jobless claims for the week ended July 26 and the Chicago purchasing manager index for July.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter at @IBD_NGondo.
Stocks wobbled out of the starting gate in mixed action Wednesday, as quarterly reports powered much of the early action.
The Dow Jones industrial average pecked out a fractional gain. The Nasdaq slumped 0.5% and the S&P 500 took a 0.2% drop.
Volume was also mixed, 19% higher on the Nasdaq, 12% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Tuesday.
The stock market today got a rolling start as earnings reports from General Motors (GM) and Walt Disney (DIS) helped bolster early trade.
Early economic news was weak, as ADP reported a larger-than-expected decline in January hiring by U.S. employers.

Service sector news was more positive, with the Institute of Supply Management's January non-manufacturing index ticking up to 56.7. That was just above December's upwardly revised tally of 56.5. Consensus views also projected a reading of 56.5.
The service purchasing managers index from researcher Markit rose to 54.2 in January, up from 53.3 in December and 10 basis points above consensus views.

In stocks, Sony (SNE) spiked 12% after delivering preliminary Q3 earnings guidance of 63 cents per share, up 186% year over year and well above consensus views for 54 cents. It also projected revenue above consensus, citing positive foreign exchange rates. The gain punched shares to a 42-month high, clearing a correction begun in July 2013.
On the IBD 50 list, leaders hammered out both strong gains and losses.

Manhattan Associates (MANH) bolted 8% higher at the starting bell. The supply chain software developer reported, after Tuesday's close, Q4 sales and earnings above consensus expectations. Management also raised its full-year earnings and revenue guidance above projections. Raymond James upgraded the stock to strong buy from outperform. The move sent shares to a new high after a test of support at the 10-week moving average.

China-based Noah Holdings (NOAH) popped 4% in early action. The asset manager has shaped a sharp double-bottom base after failing to break out above a yearlong correction in December. Wednesday's gain put it back above 10-week support and below the 22.33 buy point.

At the list's low end, Gilead Sciences (GILD) dived 9%, despite reporting healthy fourth-quarter revenue and earnings. The drugmaker offered weak 2015 sales guidance, citing competitive cost pressures.
Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) unraveled 7%, diving below its 10-week moving average in heavy trade.

The fast-casual burrito chain reported above par earnings, and revenue just a sliver shy of estimates. But same-store sales and margins disappointed analysts, as did guidance for full-year same store sales growth.

The after-hours schedule holds a few names of interest to growth stock investors, with NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) and Under Armour (UA) all expected to report quarterly results.Stocks wobbled out of the starting gate in mixed action Wednesday, as quarterly reports powered much of the early action.The Dow Jones industrial average pecked out a fractional gain. Stock futures climbed hard ahead of Wednesday's open, as news from the eurozone and Greece continued to dominate the holiday-shortened trading week.Dow futures soared 162.5 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures leapt 40 points. S&P 500 futures powered up 16.1 points.Global markets turned optimistic on news that a letter from Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras acceded to the austerity measures demanded by eurozone creditors, but with several critical changes.Tsipras asked for an extension of the prior bailout arrangement, which expired at midnight following the default on Greece's debt payment owed to the International Monetary Fund. The letter also requested an additional $32.3 billion in bailout funds.European leaders gave a mixed review to Tsipras' offer, which was received as central bankers were preparing to restrict access by Greek banks to emergency loans, according to the Financial Times.The reaction among European markets was not mixed, with the CAC-40 in Paris up 2.6% and Frankfurt's DAX ahead 2.5% just after midday.The U.S. stock market today received a slug of early economic news, beginning with the Challenger Job Cut report. Consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas said employers announced almost 45,000 job cuts in June — 43% above the year-ago level. That pushed the midyear total for layoffs to its highest since 2010. The retail sector posted the most job cuts in June, the report said, primarily due to the closing of Target (TGT) stores in Canada.The ADP National Employment report showed U.S. nonfarm private employer added 237,000 jobs in June. That was a healthy step up from 201,000 new hires in May and well above consensus forecasts for additions of 220,000. Of the June gains, 225,000 were service sector jobs.At 10 a.m. ET, the Institute for Supply Management releases its June Manufacturing Index, and the Commerce Department delivers May construction spending data. Automakers will be releasing June auto sales tallies throughout the day.In stocks, insurance mergers made news for a second day this week, with New Jersey-based Chubb (CB) soaring 32% ahead of the open on news that Switzerland-based Ace (ACE) will acquire the company in a $28.3 billion cash-stock deal. Ace shares rose 7%.On the IBD 50 list, leaders were generally flat to higher. Israel's CyberArk Software (CYBR), Ambarella (AMBA) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) ran at the head of the group, up 2% each in premarket trade.In China, the Shanghai Composite continued its recent volatile streak, backing down 5.2% after regulators did not alter the standing policy on IPO approvals. The Hong Kong Exchange was closed Wednesday. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 edged 0.5% lower.The dollar rose vs. both the euro and the yen. Oil dropped more than 1%. Gold eased a fraction. Wheat dropped 2%.

Home prices cool off S&P/Case-Shiller's 20-city home price index rose 9.3% in May, well below the 10.8% rise in April and also below expectations. Only Tampa and Charlotte did not have decelerating prices. Prices have recovered 27.3% from the March 2012 lows but remain about 17% below 2006 highs. Consumer confidence hits new highs The Conference Board's index rose 4.5…

If your employer outsources payroll processing services, there's a good chance either Automatic Data Processing (ADP) or Paychex (PAYX) handles them. Roseland, N.J.-based Automatic Data Processing is the world's biggest provider of payroll, human resource, benefits and other outsourced business services. It serves some 620,000 customers in more than 126 countries. ADP says over 80% of Fortune 500 companies use…
Stocks were mixed and mostly unchanged in early afternoon trading Wednesday after a better-than-expected private payroll report from ADP failed to fuel much excitement.
The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average each rose 0.1%, while the S&P 500 rose a fraction. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking lower than Tuesday's levels — more so on the Nasdaq.

In economic news, private employers added 281,000 jobs in June, according to ADP, well above the consensus estimate of 213,000. The data came ahead of Thursday's jobs report. Nonfarm payrolls are seen rising 211,000 after growth of 217,000 in May. The unemployment rate is expected to remain unchanged at 6.3%.

In the stock market today, IBD 50 name Constellation Brands (STZ) made more progress after a recent cup-with-handle breakout over 84.58. Shares rose 3% after the wine and spirits firm reported solid earnings. Big growth in recent quarters has been fueled by its acquisition of Grupo Modelo's U.S. operations from Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD) last year.

Ambarella (AMBA) was another strong gainer in the IBD 50, with shares rising 5%. The stock has been a beneficiary of GoPro (GPRO)'s solid debut. Ambarella's chips are found in GoPro's Hero line of cameras.

The chip designer is in a new accumulation phase as it moves closer to an all-time high, but its current consolidation is weak because the stock has corrected a steep 41%. Sound bases generally shouldn't correct more than 25% or 30%. Sales growth has decelerated for three straight quarters, from 29% to 27% to 21%.
It has been a low-volume breakout so far for Gilead Sciences (GILD), but the stock extended gains Tuesday, rising 2%. It is near the high end of a buy range, 4% above an 83.80 buy point.

China-based 58.com (WUBA) outperformed, rising nearly 4% in strong trade. Treasuries dropped for a second day after a private report showed U.S. company hiring increased the most in June since November 2012, boosting bets the economy is growing enough for the Federal Reserve to consider raising interest rates. Ten-year-note yields rose to the highest in more than a week after ADP Research Institute's employment data topped the forecasts of all…
Severe winter weather could be a factor for payroll processor Paychex (PAYX) as the Rochester, N.Y.-based company issues its fiscal third-quarter earnings after markets close on Wednesday.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the company, which also provides human resources and benefits outsourcing services for small and midsize businesses, to show a 5% boost in earnings per share to 42 cents. Revenue is expected to grow about 6% to $629 million.

Severe snowstorms have been blamed for slowing the U.S. economy so far this year, which may cut into the growth of paychecks that Paychex cuts for small businesses, a big component of the company's customer base.
Small businesses saw recent drops in hiring and paycheck amounts, according to surveys taken by SurePayroll, a Paychex subsidiary.

Unfavorable interest rates and competition from Insperity (NSP) and Automatic Data Processing (ADP) also are considered hurdles for Paychex to overcome, according to analysts at Zacks Investment Research.
Paychex shares are down roughly 6.5% so far this year, but are up about half a percent on the stock market today .

On the positive side, companies have been hiring at a gradual but steady pace, with some signs that more people are re-entering the workforce to look for jobs.Severe winter weather could be a factor for payroll processor Paychex (PAYX) as the Rochester, N.Y.-based company issues its fiscal third-quarter earnings after markets close on Wednesday.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the company, which also provides human resources and benefits outsourcing services for small and midsize businesses, to show a 5% boost in earnings per share to 42 cents. The World Bank also lowered forecasts for Brazil, Russia and China, warning those countries that fin'l market turbulence may derail growth. The World Bank…
Stocks recovered from early losses by midday Wednesday to post mild gains as the market continued to trade in a tight fashion with volume running lower than Tuesday's pace.
The Nasdaq was up 0.3%; the S&P 500 rose 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average had its head slightly above water.

The stock market today opened lower on somewhat disappointing numbers from the ADP jobs report. But the market is looking ahead to the weekly unemployment claims report and the European Central Bank announcement on monetary policy on Thursday and the U.S. employment report Friday.

Chip stocks were again strong. Applied Materials (AMAT) was up 1% as it built on a 4% gain and breakout from a base on Tuesday. Cavium (CAVM) was up nearly 3% after breaking out of a base last week and then pulling back.
Medical-sector stock Grifols (GRSF) rose in heavy trade as it approached a 43.60 buy point from a base.
Machinery maker Rexnord (RXN) was up 5% in heavy volume. It was placed on Wedbush's best-ideas list with a price target raised from 31 to 33. It is trading near 27.

Canadian Pacific Railway (CP) was up 1% to a new all-time high. Major averages ended with solid gains in greater volume on Thursday, with all three indexes closing near session highs.

The Nasdaq jumped 1.1%, the S&P 500 added 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average picked up 0.6%. Nasdaq volume rose 21% from Wednesday, according to preliminary data, as institutional buyers made their presence felt. NYSE volume increased 10%.

Wall Street was in a good mood at the open after the European Central Bank took steps to stave off deflation in the eurozone. On top of reducing its main lending rate to 0.15%, the ECB also started charging commercial banks for keeping their money at the ECB with an interest rate of -0.1%. The euro hit a four-month low on the news but recouped early losses.

In the stock market today, Verint Systems (VRNT) gapped out of a first-stage base, rising 10% on strong Q1 earnings. The provider of data analytics software reported its fourth straight quarter of accelerating sales growth.
Elsewhere, fast-growing Eagle Materials (EXP) tried to clear a second-stage, cup-with-handle buy point of 89.32. Its stock closed just underneath the buy point, up nearly 1%.

Inside the IBD 50, tech outsourcer Epam Systems (EPAM) popped 3% as it works on the right side of a cup-shaped base that started in February. It recently corrected 37% off its high — on the steep side — but an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A- indicates heavy institutional buying in recent weeks.

On the economic front, the May employment report looms large on Friday. Economists expect non-farm payrolls to increase by 213,000. In April, the economy created 288,000 jobs. The unemployment rate is expected to tick higher to 6.4%. Earlier this week, the private payroll data from the ADP Employment Report came in below expectations.

After the close, watch for earnings from recent restaurant IPO Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES). Its stock has been consolidating gains since its April debut at 15 and currently sits 8% off its high. It has nearly doubled from the offering price. Retailers likely saw sales pick up in May as warmer weather sparked demand for spring and early summer merchandise. Stock futures nosed lower early Wednesday as investors weighed earnings, consumer price data and overseas action, and ahead of this afternoon's Federal Reserve release.

Dow futures slipped 55.3 points below fair market value, off lows but lower over the prior hour. Nasdaq 100 futures were 4.7 points lower. S&P 500 futures were down 4.4 points. Small caps were under pressure, down 6 points.

Minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's July 29 meeting, due out at 2 p.m., will be a focal point for the stock market today. It is the last official release of data before the September meeting at which the Fed has broadly suggested it could vote to raise the federal funds target rate. The Fed has not altered the rate, currently 0.25%, since December 2008.

Consumer prices rose 0.1% in July, the Labor Department said, a sixth straight monthly advance, but down from a 0.3% increase in June and below expectations for a 0.2% increase. Core prices, minus food and energy, also rose 0.1%, below the 0.2% consensus and June's 0.2% rise. It was the index's second straight year-over-year advance after flat action for the first five months of the year.

U.S. stocks may feel some early pressure European markets, trading lower after Germany's parliament approved the renewed bailout agreement for Greece. The debate rocked markets for months before finally securing Greek support in July and passed muster among eurozone finance ministers Aug. 14.

The German vote frees funds for release to the debt-stressed country later today. Greece owes the European Central Bank a $3.5 billion debt payment on Thursday. The DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris carried losses of more than 1% near midday.

Some China-based stocks trading on U.S. markets took post-earnings report beatings early Wednesday. Canadian Solar (CSIQ) dived 10%, Tarena International (TEDU) folded 12% after reporting second-quarter results late Tuesday. Sina (SINA), which also reported after Tuesday's close, rose a fraction.
Retailers were again busy in premarket action. American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) jumped 3% after posting healthy Q2 results. Staples (SPLS) dropped 2%. Lowe's (LOW) stumbled 1%.

Target (TGT) leapt 4% after a 33% jump in earnings and a 3% revenue gain topped analysts' Q2 expectations. The company boosted its full-year earnings outlook — a significant move following Tuesday's downgrade from Wal-Mart (WMT) — and same-store-sales comfortably beat forecasts. Shares rose almost 2% Tuesday, continuing the stock's rebound from support at its 200-day moving average.

Meat processor Hormel Foods (HRL) popped 2% ahead of the open. The Austin, Minn., company's adjusted Q2 earnings narrowly topped consensus views. Revenue dipped 4%, in line with expectations, and management raised its full-year EPS guidance. The stock finished Tuesday just below a Monday high after clearing a shallow, months-long consolidation.
Homebuilders were trading mixed in premarket action after a strong session on Tuesday. Toll Bros. (TOL) was down nearly 2%, while Lennar (LEN) and D.R. Horton (DHI) dipped a fraction each.
Thinly traded MI Homes (MHO) spiked 10% in premarket trade. The Columbus, Ohio-based builder ended Tuesday almost 3% past a 25.71 buy point after a breakout from a flat base on Monday.

Overseas, Asian markets were all over the map on Wednesday, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 taking a 1.6% loss, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 1.3%, the Shanghai Composite up 1.2% and the Shenzhen Composite posting a 2.2% gain. The Shanghai and Shenzhen markets dived 3% in early trade.

The dollar slipped vs. the euro and the yen. Commodities were mixed, with West Texas Intermediate oil down a bit less than 1% and Europe's Brent crude effectively flat. Gold rose a half-percent to $1,121 an ounce. The world's biggest provider of payroll and data processing services is up 20% this year, topping the S&P 500. It's risen 23% over the past year and has more than doubled from a low of…

Mortgage applications jump Home loan purchase applications soared 20% in the June 5 week, the Mortgage Bankers Assn. said. Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.
Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.
In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.

The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.
Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.

Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.

On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.

Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose about 1%.Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. Stocks groaned lower in hectic early trade Wednesday, following the lead of global markets after China continued letting its currency fall in line with currency market influences.
The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average slumped 1.3% each. The S&P 500 dropped 1.2%.
Volume rose, up 8% on the Nasdaq and 3% higher on the NYSE, compared with volume levels at the same time Tuesday.

The stock market today launched with the S&P 500 tearing a hole in support at its 200-day moving average, around the 2075 level. The index took a quick breath of air above its 50-day line on Monday and Tuesday before dropping back into its repeated pattern of 200-day tests begun June 29. In that time the index has finished two sessions below that line of support, on July 8 and 9. The Nasdaq is trading just below its 50-day moving average.
U.S. economic news was relatively minor, with the Labor Department's June Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey narrowing to 5.24 million unfilled positions vs. 5.35 million open jobs in May.

New York Federal Reserve chief William Dudley, speaking in Rochester, N.Y., said it was early to judge what was going on in China, that the country's currency could have been appreciating alongside the dollar and in need of adjustment.
"Obviously if the Chinese economy is weaker than maybe what the Chinese authorities anticipated, it's probably not inappropriate for the currency to adjust in consequence to that weakness," he said.
The Energy Information Administration reports weekly oil inventories at 10:30 a.m. ET. The Treasury Department reports its July budget at 2 p.m.
The Dow opened almost unanimously lower. Only Chevron (CVX) rose, up 0.2%, aided by a 1% rebound in oil prices. Apple (AAPL), Nike (NKE), JPMorgan (JPM) and Boeing (BA) fell more than 2%.

On the S&P 500, Fossil (FOSL) and Yahoo (YHOO) were worst hit, down 5% each. Fossil reported weaker-than-expected Q2 revenue growth and Q3 guidance. Yahoo's drop is likely attributable to its 384 million share stake in Alibaba, which has said it will spin off at some point as a separately traded entity.

At the top of the S&P 500, banking and payment software technologies firm Fidelity National Information Services (FIS) jumped nearly 6% after announcing it would pay $9.1 billion to acquire SunGard Data Systems. The privately held SunGard had registered for an initial public offering in June. The company reported $4.67 billion debt as of June 30. National reported that the cash-stock deal would create a company with $9.2 billion in combined revenue. Wednesday's gain hoisted shares to just below a 68.99 buy point in a shallow, five-month cup base.

China-based e-retail giant Alibaba (BABA) retreated 7% in opening trade after its second-quarter earnings narrowly topped expectations, while a 28% revenue jump stopped short of projections and the growth of total gross volume slowed to 34%. Management launched a two-year, $4.6 billion share buyback initiative. The loss put shares 40% below their November high and 6% above their September IPO price.

Among leaders, Ambarella (AMBA), a leading developer of video processing chips, skidded 4% lower, to the bottom of the IBD 50 list. Key client GoPro (GPRO) was also 4% lower in early trade. Ambarella is struggling to hold its 50-day line of support for a second time in a month.Stocks groaned lower in hectic early trade Wednesday, following the lead of global markets after China continued letting its currency fall in line with currency market influences.The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average slumped 1.3% each. The U.S. economy stalled out in Q1, as GDP rose at a 0.1% annual rate, the Commerce Department said Wednesday. But with other data showing rebounding growth in the spring, the Federal Reserve voted to taper its bond-buys by another $10 billion.

The Fed's decision, widely expected, cited ongoing improvement in the economy. But as previously signaled, the central bank left interest rates untouched and pledged to keep policy easy as long as the economy remained shaky .

"The employment trends are telling the real story on how to think about the economy. The rest is noise," said James Glassman, senior economist at JPMorgan Chase. "As weak as Q1 was, you shouldn't be shocked by the data. It doesn't mean anything to the Fed."

The central bank noted as much in its release. ".. . growth in economic activity has picked up recently, after having slowed sharply during the winter in part because of adverse weather conditions," its policymakers wrote. "There is sufficient underlying strength in the broader economy to support ongoing improvement in labor market conditions."

That underlying strength was nowhere to be found in the Q1 GDP data, which was weaker than expected. Residential investment fell hard for a second straight quarter, and business fixed investment declined at a 5.5% rate. Both sectors were expected to help lead the economy in 2014, and both were noted in the Fed's Wednesday statement. Exports declined 7.6%.

Consumer spending rose 3%, seemingly strong. But expenditures on autos and other durables rose just 0.8%, the weakest since Q2 2011. Utility spending rose during the harsh winter. Health care spending soared 9.9%, the most since 1980, largely on ObamaCare costs.
Growth In The Spring?

But more recent data suggest a bounceback may be under way. Jobless claims continue to drift down, and consumer confidence rises. ISM Chicago's regional manufacturing index on Wednesday showed the fastest growth in six months, led by new orders and production.

"We've been growing 2% or better with headwinds," Glassman said. "That means the underlying economy wants to grow and we are in a recovery mode. I think there are tailwinds building." For those reasons, he forecasts a 5% jump in GDP for Q2.
Mark Olson, chairman at Treliant Risk Advisors and a former Fed governor, said policymakers have been disappointed by businesses' reluctance to invest.
"It's so much a factor of confidence in the future," Olson said. It is not just capital spending that has lagged, but mergers and acquisitions and applications for credit are sluggish, he noted.

The Fed continues to worry more about inflation running too slow rather than too fast, Olson said, and for that reason it will leave rates low for a while. Policymakers need to give themselves the option of modifying the taper if there's a sudden change in the economy, Olson said, but otherwise a continuation of the $10 billion-per-meeting taper is a virtual certainty.
The predictability is a positive for the markets, Olson said.
The major averages picked up modestly after the Fed announcement, closing slightly higher.

The Fed also remains concerned about the health of the labor market. Jobless claims have hit multiyear lows. Analysts believe employers added 215,000 jobs in April, with the unemployment rate ticking down to 6.6%. The Labor Department releases its monthly report Friday.
ADP estimated Wednesday that private payrolls grew by 220,300 in April, though the survey hasn't done a great job of predicting Labor's results.
Still, there's considerable slack in the labor market that's not captured by the jobless rate alone.
Q1 employment costs rose just 1.8% vs. a year earlier, Labor said Wednesday. In a more normal economy, that should be closer to 4%, Glassman said, evidence of "hidden unemployment."

"If the labor market is really doing that well, why are wages doing what they're doing?" he said. "It just tells you, we have a lot of growing to do."The U.S. economy stalled out in Q1, as GDP rose at a 0.1% annual rate, the Commerce Department said Wednesday. But with other data showing rebounding growth in the spring, the Federal Reserve voted to taper its bond-buys by another $10 billion.The Fed's decision, widely expected, cited ongoing improvement in the economy. In a more normal economy, that should be closer to 4%, Glassman said, evidence of "hidden unemployment.""If the labor market is really doing that well, why are wages doing what they're doing?" he said. "It just tells you, we have a lot of growing to do."
Stock futures shed Thursday's premarket gains and reversed to moderate losses after mixed reports on unemployment claims and Q3 GDP growth.

Dow futures dropped 57.2 points below fair market value, down from a 44-point advance an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures shed an 18-point gain and dropped 20.7 points. S&P 500 futures also reversed, trading down 6.7 points.

The stock market today received a boost from the Federal Reserve Wednesday that left the Nasdaq up 1.3% so far this week and the S&P 500 showing a 0.7% gain. Both indexes are working on what would be a fifth straight weekly advance.

More important for growth investors, small caps are having a strong week. The Russell 2000 surged 2.9% Wednesday — it's strongest session since Dec. 17, 2014. That lifted the small cap gauge clear of its 50-day moving average and put it ahead 1.1% for the week. Even so, the index remains well below its next test of resistance at its 200-day line.
The IBD 50 Index popped 1.6% on Wednesday and is easily outpacing the market with a 3.6% gain for the week.

A big day of economic news was off to a mixed start, with a preliminary estimate from the Commerce Department putting Q3 GDP growth at 1.5%, less than half of the 3.9% jump in Q2 and just below forecasts for a 1.7% increase. Price inflation also softened, with the GDP price index rising 1.2%, down from 2.1% in Q2 and a shade below views for a 1.4% advance.

Unemployment claims inched fractionally higher, to 260,000, in the week ended Oct. 24, the Labor Department reported. That was better than the uptick to 265,000 claims forecast by economists. The prior week's tally was 259,000 claims. The four-week moving average dipped to 259,250, its sixth straight decline.

Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank President Dennis Lockhart is scheduled to speak in Washington, D.C., at 9:10 a.m. ET. The National Association of Realtors reports September pending home sales data at 10 a.m.

Big oil companies got the earnings ball rolling, with Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA), Total (TOT) and ConocoPhillips (COP) all down 2% after reporting results. Oil prices backed off 1%, with West Texas Intermediate at $45.51 a barrel after surging more than 6% Wednesday.

Drug maker Pfizer (PFE) climbed 3% and Allergan (AGN) soared 11% on news reports that the two companies are exploring a possible merger. The Wall Street Journal quoted unnamed sources saying the talks were in early stages and details were unclear. Pfizer ended Wednesday up 4% for the week and less than 2% above a 34.79 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Among the premarket session's wilder moves, identity security firm Lifelock (LOCK) soared 40% on healthy Q3 results reported late Wednesday, along with news that it had settled a Federal Trade Commission lawsuit. Digital video camera maker GoPro (GPRO) dived 18% on weaker-than-forecast Q3 sales and earnings, also reported after Wednesday's close.

Among leading stocks, O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) jumped 3%, Tesoro (TSO) rose 2% and Ellie Mae (ELLI) was flat after their Q3 reports. O'Reilly ended Wednesday's session in buy range, less than 2% above a 258.25 buy point. Tesoro was 3% below a 105.64 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

NXP Semiconductor (NXPI) dived 13%. The Netherlands-based chip maker reported Q3 earnings up a stronger-than-expected 16%, but revenue rose less than 1% — weaker than estimates. Management expanded its stock buyback initiative to 20 million shares. NXP finished Wednesday just below its 10-week moving average, and has been working to climb the right side of a four-month consolidation.
Cavium (CAVM) took an 11% hit after reporting in-line Q3 earnings and revenue late Wednesday. The chip maker has been chopping out an uneven consolidation, and fighting to hold support, since June.

Stocks turned mixed and mostly unchanged Wednesday afternoon, with the S&P 500 edging up to another intraday high amid generally positive economic data.
The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each rose 0.1%, while the Nasdaq slipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, with NYSE volume tracking 6% lower than Tuesday and Nasdaq volume rising 8%.

Private employers added 191,000 jobs in March, according to ADP, pretty much in line with the consensus estimate of 193,000. Figures from the prior month were revised sharply higher. The data came ahead of Friday's jobs report. Nonfarm payrolls are expected to increase by 206,000, with the unemployment rate ticking lower to 6.6%.
Orders for manufactured goods rose a better-than-expected 1.6% in February, the biggest increase in five months.

In the stock market today, Alliance Fiber Optic Products (AFOP) soared 11% in strong turnover after the maker of fiber-optic components for the optical network equipment market released preliminary Q1 results. Revenue for the period more than doubled to $24.8 million, above the Thomson Reuters consensus estimate of $22.5 million. The stock, which has been correcting since September, retook its 200-day moving average.

GasLog (GLOG), which transports liquefied natural gas, jumped 5% in more than double its average daily turnover. Investors should wait for the stock to form a new base, as it's risen far beyond a 15.34 buy point cleared in November.

On the downside, Five Below (FIVE), a discount retailer targeting teens, slumped 3% in heavy trade and dropped back below its 200-day line. The former leader, which went public in July 2012, is now 25% off its all-time high in November. Shares gapped up on March 26 after the company reported double-digit earnings and sales growth.Stocks turned mixed and mostly unchanged Wednesday afternoon, with the S&P 500 edging up to another intraday high amid generally positive economic data.The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each rose 0.1%, while the Nasdaq slipped 0.1%.
